001.name: Samsthiti
001.description:
Tadasana or Mountain Pose
This pose implies one stands firm and erect as a mountain.
Effects: Improves standing posture, increases spinal elasticity, firms hips and abdomen, develops mental agility.
001.technique: Stand erect with your feet together. Touch your heels and big toes. Rest the metatarsals on the floor. Stretch all the toes flat. Tighten your knees. Pull your knee-caps up. Contract your hips. Pull up the muscles at the back of your thighs. Pull your abdomen in. Bring your chest forward. Keep your spine stretched up. Maintain a straight neck. Distribute your body's weight evenly between your heels and toes. Stretch your arms over your head or keep them by the side of your thighs.

002.name: Vrksasana
002.description:
Vrksasana or Tree Pose
Vrksa means a tree.
Effects: Tones leg muscles, develops balance.
002.technique: Stand in Tadasana. Bend the right leg at the knee. Place the right heel at the root of the left thigh. Rest the right foot on the left thigh. Point the toes downwards. Balance only on the left leg. Join the palms together. Raise the arms straight over the head. Extend the spine upward. Stay in the pose for a few seconds. Breathe deeply. Lower the arms. Straighten the right leg. Stand again in Tadasana. Repeat the pose on the opposite side. Balance on the right leg. Place the left heel at the root of the right thigh.

003.name: Uttihita Trikonasana
003.description:
Uttihita Trikonasana or Extended Triangle Pose
This is the extended triangle pose.
Effects: Relieves backaches, tones legs, develops chest.
003.technique: Stand in Tadasana. Inhale deeply. Jump and spread the legs apart sideways. Raise the arms sideways in line with the shoulders. Keep palms facing down. Turn the right foot sideways ninety degrees to the right. Turn the left foot slightly to the right. Keep the left leg stretched from the inside. Tighten the left leg at the knee. Exhale. Bend the trunk sideways to the right. Bring the right palm near the right ankle. Rest the right palm completely on the floor if possible. Stretch the left arm up. Bring the left arm in line with the right arm and shoulders. Gaze at the thumb of the extended left hand. Stay in this position. Breathe deeply. Breathe evenly. Inhale. Return to the starting position. Repeat these actions on the left side.

004.name: Parivrtta Trikonasana
004.description:
Parivrtta Trikonasana
Parivrtta means revolved.
Effects: Increases blood supply to lower spine, expansion of chest.
004.technique: Stand in Tadasana. Jump to spread the legs apart sideways three to three and a half feet. Turn the right foot ninety degrees. Turn the left foot sixty degrees to the right. Exhale. Rotate the trunk to the right. Rest the left palm on the floor on the outer side of the right foot. Stretch the right arm up. Keep the right arm in line with the left. Gaze at the right thumb. Stay for thirty seconds. Breathe normally.

005.name: Uttihita Parsvakonasana
005.description:
Uttihita Parsvakonasana or Extended lateral angle pose
Parsva means side and kona means an angle, defining the pose as an extended lateral angle position.
Effects: Reduces fat at waist, aids digestion, tones knees and thighs.
005.technique: Stand in Tadasana. Jump your legs four to four and a half feet apart. Turn your right foot ninety degrees right. Bend your right knee until the thigh is parallel to the floor. Ensure the shin is perpendicular to the floor. Place your right palm on the floor by the outer side of the right foot. Stretch your left arm over the left ear. Keep your chest, hips, and legs in one line. Roll the biceps forward and out as the shoulder tip presses back. Press into the back heel. Inhale deeply to lengthen the arm. Stay in the pose for thirty to sixty seconds. Repeat the actions on the other side.

006.name: Parivrtta Parsvakonasana
006.description:
Parivrtta Parsvakonasana or Revolved lateral angle pose
This pose is the six type of Revolved lateral angle pose.
Effects: Rejuvenates spine and abdominal organs, aids colon waste removal.
006.technique: Begin in Tadasana. Jump the legs four to four and a half feet apart. Bend the right knee to ninety degrees. Exhale and rotate the trunk to the right. Place the left armpit over the outer right knee. Place the left palm on the floor. Stretch the right arm over the right ear. Twist the spine. Gaze up.

007.name: Virabhadrasana I
007.description:
Virabhadrasana I
Dedicated to the hero Virabhadra.
Effects: Relieves shoulder slash neck stiffness, tones ankles slash knees.
007.technique: Stand in Tadasana. Raise the arms over the head. Join the palms. Jump the legs four to four and a half feet apart. Turn the body to the right. Bend the right knee to a right angle. Ensure the front knee is stacked directly above the ankle. Stretch the left leg. Keep the left knee locked. Angle the left foot approximately forty-five degrees. Keep the hips at the same height, facing slightly diagonal. Keep the shoulders facing forward over the front knee. Lift the head. Gaze at the joined palms. Stay for twenty to thirty seconds. Press into the floor with the right foot. Step the left foot back up into Tadasana. Repeat the pose on the left side.

008.name: Virabhadrasana II
008.description:
Virabhadrasana II or Warrior Pose II
This pose is named after a fierce warrior from Hindu mythology, Virabhadra, a figure created by Lord Shiva to restore cosmic balance.
Effects: Relieves leg cramps, brings elasticity to back.
008.technique: Stand in Tadasana. Jump your legs four to four and a half feet apart. Stretch your arms out sideways. Turn your right foot ninety degrees to the right. Bend your right knee ninety degrees. Turn your face to the right. Gaze at your right palm. Hold the pose for twenty to thirty seconds.

009.name: Virabhadrasana III
009.description:
Virabhadrasana III or Warrior III
Virabhadrasana means fierce Warrior Pose, or namely the warrior named Virabhadra and asana meaning pose.
Effects: Develops harmony, poise, provides vigor for runners.
009.technique: Stand in Virabhadrasana I on the right side. Exhale, bend the trunk forward. Rest the chest on the right thigh. Simultaneously lift the left leg. Straighten the right leg. Keep the body and left leg parallel to the floor. Extend arms forward reaching into them. Turn the left heel toward the ceiling. Cut the outer seam of the standing leg back. Stay in the pose for 20 seconds. Develop harmony and poise. The pose provides vigor for runners.

010.name: Ardha Chandrasana
010.description:
Ardha Chandrasana or Half Moon Pose
Ardha means half, Chandra the moon.
Effects: Stronger knees, cures gastric troubles, tones lower spine.
010.technique: Perform Utthita Trikonasana on the right side. Place your right hand on the floor. Position your right hand about one foot in front of your right foot. Raise your left leg. Keep your left leg parallel to the floor. Turn your chest to the left. Establish your balance. Hold the pose for twenty to thirty seconds.

011.name: Uttithita Padangusthasana
011.description:
Uttithita Padangusthasana or Extended Hand to Big Toe Pose
This pose involves standing on one leg while holding the big toe of the raised leg.
Effects: Makes leg muscles powerful, develops poise.
011.technique: Stand in Tadasana. Exhale your breath. Raise the right leg upward. Catch the right big toe with your right hand. Inhale and lengthen your spine. Stretch the raised leg forward. Pull the leg up high toward the ceiling. Hold this posture for twenty seconds. Maintain steady balance throughout the pose. The pose strengthens the leg muscles. This action develops poise.

012.name: Parsvottanasana
012.description:
Parsvottanasana or Intense Side Stretch Pose
This pose involves a wide stance with the upper body folded over the front leg.
Effects: Elasticizes hip joints and spine, tones abdominal organs.
012.technique: Stand in Tadasana. Join your palms in Namaste behind your back. Jump your legs three to three and a half feet apart. Turn your body to the right. Exhale and bend your torso forward. Rest your head on your right knee. Hold the posture for twenty to thirty seconds.

013.name: Prasarita Padotanasana I
013.description:
Thirteen / Prasarita Padotanasana I or Wide-Legged Forward Bend Pose I
This pose is a deep forward bend performed while standing with the feet wide apart.
Effects: Brings blood to brain, increases digestive power.
013.technique: Begin in Tadasana. Place your hands on your waist. Jump your legs 4.5 to 5 feet apart. Exhale and fold forward from your hips. Place your palms on the floor between your feet. Inhale and lengthen forward through your spine. Maintain a concave back. Exhale and deepen the fold. Rest the crown of your head on the floor. Maintain the length of your spine. Firm your leg muscles. Activate your inner thigh muscles. Stay in the pose for a couple of breaths. Lift up on an inhale. Keep your legs and core engaged as you lift. Return to Standing Wide-Legged Pose Hands On Hips.

014.name: Prasarita Padotanasana II
014.description:
Prasarita Padotanasana II or Wide-Legged Standing Forward Bend Pose two
This is an advanced movement of the earlier pose where the hands are placed on the waist instead of on the floor or are folded at the back as if one is doing ‘namaste’ behind the back as described intensified.
Effects: Fully develops the hamstring and abductor muscles, causes blood to flow to the trunk and the head, benefits those who cannot do Sirsasana or Headstand, increases digestive powers
014.technique: Stand with feet wide apart and parallel. Place your hands on your waist. Inhale and lengthen your spine. Exhale and fold forward from your hips. Keep your back straight as you fold. Stop when your back is parallel to the floor. Alternatively, fold your hands behind your back in a reverse namaste. Keep your legs straight. Look toward the floor or slightly forward. Inhale to return to standing.

015.name: Parighasana
015.description:
Parighasana or Gate Pose
In this posture, the body resembles a cross beam used for locking a gate, hence the name of the pose.
Effects: stretches pelvic region, keeps abdominal muscles and organs in condition, keeps skin around abdomen healthy, helps persons suffering from stiff backs.
015.technique: Kneel on the floor with your ankles together. Stretch the right leg sideways to the right. Keep the right leg in line with the trunk and the left knee. Turn the right foot sideways to the right. Keep the right leg stiff at the knee. Extend the arms sideways with an inhalation. Take two breaths. Exhale and move the trunk and right arm down towards the extended right leg. Rest the right forearm on the right shin. Rest the right wrist on the right ankle. The right palm faces up. The right ear rests on the right upper arm. Move the left arm over the head. Touch the right palm with the left hand. The left ear touches the left upper arm. Stay in this position for thirty to sixty seconds. Breathe normally. Inhale and move the trunk and arms back to the starting position. Bend the right leg. Kneel on the floor. Keep the ankles together again. Repeat the pose on the other side. Substitute the right side for the left side and vice versa. Stay in the pose on both sides for the same amount of time.

016.name: Ustrasana
016.description:
Ustrasana or Camel Pose
Ustra means a camel.
Effects: Beneficial for people with drooping shoulders and hunched backs, the whole spine is stretched back and is toned, can be tried conveniently by the elderly and even by persons with spinal injury.
016.technique: Kneel on the floor. Keep your thighs and feet together. Your toes should point back and rest on the floor. Rest your palms on your hips. Stretch your thighs. Curve your spine back. Extend your ribs. Exhale. Place your right palm over your right heel. Place your left palm over your left heel. Place your palms on the soles of your feet if possible. Press the feet with your palms. Throw your head back. Push your spine toward your thighs. Keep your thighs perpendicular to the floor. Contract your buttocks. Stretch the dorsal region of your spine further. Stretch the coccyx region of your spine further. Keep your neck stretched back. Remain in this position for about half a minute. Maintain normal breathing. Release the hands one by one. Rest your hands on your hips. Sit on the floor. Relax.

017.name: Utkatasana
017.description:
Utkatasana
Utkata means powerful, fierce, uneven.
Effects: removes stiffness in the shoulders, corrects any minor deformities in the legs, the ankles become strong, the leg muscles develop evenly, the diaphragm is lifted up and this gives a gentle massage to the heart, the abdominal organs and the back are toned, the chest is developed by being fully expanded, it is a beneficial pose for horsemen.
017.technique: Stand in Tadasana. Stretch the arms straight over the head. Join the palms. Exhale. Bend the knees. Lower the trunk until the thighs are parallel to the floor. Do not stoop forward. Keep the chest far back. Breathe normally. Stay in the pose. Inhale. Straighten the legs. Lower the arms. Come back to Tadasana. Relax.

018.name: Padangusthasana
018.description:
Padangusthasana or Big Toe Posture
This posture is done by standing and catching the big toes.
Effects: Tones abdominal organs, makes leg muscles powerful.
018.technique: Stand in Tadasana. Spread the legs one foot apart. Exhale and bend forward. Hold the big toes between the thumbs and the first two fingers. Ensure the palms face each other and hold the toes tightly. Keep the head up. Stretch the diaphragm towards the chest. Make the back as concave as possible. Bend forward from the pelvic region. Keep the legs stiff. Do not slacken the grip at the knees and toes. Stretch the shoulder blades. Take one or two breaths in this position. Exhale and bring the head in between the knees. Tighten the knees. Pull the toes without lifting them off the floor. Remain in this pose for about twenty seconds maintaining normal breathing. Inhale and return to the bent forward position while holding the toes. Release the toes. Stand up. Return to Tadasana.

019.name: Padahasthasana
019.description:
Padahasthasana
Pada means the foot and Hasta means the hand, and this posture is done by bending forward and standing on one's hands.
Effects: Abdominal organs are toned, digestive juices increase, liver and spleen are activated.
019.technique: Stand in Tadasana. Spread the legs a foot apart. Exhale and bend forward. Do not bend the legs at the knees. Insert the hands under the feet. The palms should touch the soles. Keep the head up. Make the back as concave as possible. Do not slacken the grip at the knees. Take a few breaths in this position. Now exhale. Move the head in between the knees. Bend the elbows. Pull the feet up from the palms. Stay in the pose for about twenty seconds with normal breathing. Inhale and raise the head. Come back to the position with the head well up. Take two breaths. Inhale and stand up. Return to Tadasana.

020.name: Uttanasana
020.description:
Uttanasana
In this asana, the spine is given a deliberate and an intense stretch.
Effects: cures stomach pains, tones the liver, the spleen and the kidneys, relieves stomach pain during menstrual periods, the heart beats are slowed down, the spinal nerves rejuvenated, any depression felt in the mind is removed if one holds the pose for two minutes or more, the posture is a boon to people who get excited quickly, it soothes the brain cells.
020.technique: Stand in Tadasana. Keep the knees tight. Exhale and bend forward. Place the fingers on the floor. Place the palms on the floor by the side of the feet, behind the heels. Do not bend the legs at the knees. Try to hold the head up. Stretch the spine. Move the hips a little forward towards the head. Bring the legs perpendicular to the floor. Remain in this position. Take two deep breaths. Exhale and move the trunk closer to the legs. Rest the head on the knees. Do not slacken the grip at the knees. Pull the knee-caps well up. Hold this position for a minute. Breathe deeply and evenly. Inhale and raise the head from the knees. Do not lift the palms from the floor. Take two breaths. Take a deep inhalation. Lift the hands from the floor. Come back to Tadasana.

021.name: Urdhva Prasarita Ekapadasana
021.description:
Urhdva Prasarita Ekapadasana
This posture is done by standing on one leg, bending forward and lifting the other leg high up.
Effects: Tones the leg muscles, reduces fat around the hips.
021.technique: Stand in Tadasana. Exhale and bend the trunk forward. Catch the back of the right ankle with the left hand. Rest the right hand on the floor by the side of the right foot. Rest the head or chin on the right knee. Lift the left leg high up in the air. Tighten both knees. Keep the toes of the lifted leg pointed upwards. Stay in the pose for about twenty seconds with even breathing. Inhale. Bring the left leg down to the ground. Come back to Tadasana. Repeat the pose on the other side.

022.name: Ardha Baddha Padmottanasana
022.description:
Ardha Baddha Padmottanasana
Ardha means half, Baddha means bound, restrained, caught, or withheld, Padma is a lotus, and Uttana is an intense stretch.
Effects: Stiffness of the knees is cured by this asana, digestive powers increase, peristaltic activity helps to eliminate toxin creating waste matter, helps deep breathing.
022.technique: Stand in Tadasana. Inhale and raise the right leg from the floor. Bend the right knee. Rest the sole of the right foot on the left thigh. Hold the right foot with the left hand. Bring the right arm around the back. Catch the big toe of the right foot with the thumb, fore, and middle fingers of the right hand. Release the left hand. Exhale and bend the trunk forward. Place the left hand on the floor by the left foot. Keep the head up. Make the back as concave as possible. Take a few breaths. Exhale and rest the head or chin on the left knee. If the whole left palm cannot be placed on the floor, start with the tips of the fingers. Gradually place the fingers on the floor. Finally, place the whole palm on the floor. Repeat these steps on the other side.

023.name: Garudasana
023.description:
Garudasana or Eagle Pose
Garuda means an eagle and is the name of the king of birds and the vehicle of Visnu.
Effects: develops the ankles, removes stiffness in the shoulders, prevents cramps in the calf muscles
023.technique: Stand in Tadasana. Bend the right knee. Bring the left leg over the right thigh above the right knee. Rest the back of the left thigh on the front of the right thigh. Move the left foot behind the right calf. Ensure the left shin touches the right calf. Hook the left big toe just above the inner side of the right ankle. Bend the elbows. Raise the arms to the level of the chest. Rest the right elbow on the front of the left upper arm near the elbow joint. Join the palms. Remain in this position for a few seconds. Breathe deeply.

024.name: Vatayanasana
024.description:
Vatayanasana
Vatayana means a horse and the pose resembles a horse’s face hence the name.
Effects: Improves hip circulation, corrects minor hip deformities, good for stiffness in the sacroiliac region.
024.technique: Sit on the floor. Place the left foot at the root of the right thigh in half Padmasana. Place the hands on the floor by the side of the hips. Exhale. Raise the trunk off the floor. Place the top of the left knee on the floor. Place the right foot near the bent left knee. Keep the right thigh parallel to the floor. Stretch the pelvis forward. Keep the left thigh perpendicular to the floor. Raise the hands. Straighten the back. Balance the body. Bend the elbows. Raise the arms to the level of the chest. Entwine the forearms around one another. Join the palms. Hold this position for about thirty seconds with normal breathing.

025.name: Salabhasana
025.description:
Salabhasana or Locust Pose
The pose resembles that of a locust resting on the ground.
Effects: Aids digestion, relieves gastric troubles, relieves flatulence, makes spine elastic, relieves pain in the sacral regions, relieves pain in the lumbar regions, beneficial for persons suffering from slipped discs, tones bladder.
025.technique: Lie full length on your stomach. Face downwards. Stretch your arms back. Exhale completely. Lift your head simultaneously. Lift your chest simultaneously. Lift your legs off the floor simultaneously. Lift them as high as possible. Keep only the abdominal front portion of your body resting on the floor. Bear your weight on this area. Contract your buttocks. Stretch your thigh muscles. Keep both legs fully extended. Keep both legs straight. Stay in the position. Breathe normally.

026.name: Makarasana
026.description:
Makarasana or Crocodile Posture
This posture is described in Verse forty of the second chapter of the Gheranda Samhita.
Effects: increases bodily heat.
026.technique: Lie on the ground face down. Stretch both legs out. Let the chest touch the earth. Lie prone with legs spread hip distance apart. Rest the forehead on your crossed arms. Allow the entire body to deeply relax. Keep your neck long. Keep your hips grounded. Maintain soft feet and toes. Breathe softly and naturally.

027.name: Dhanurasana
027.description:
Dhanurasana or Bow Pose
The arms and hands act like a bow-string to tauten the body like a bent bow.
Effects: Stretches the spine backward, restores spinal elasticity preventing rigidity in elderly, tones abdominal organs, provides non-surgical relief for slipped discs.
027.technique: Lie full length on the floor on the stomach. Face downwards. Exhale. Bend the knees. Stretch the arms back. Hold the left ankle with the left hand. Hold the right ankle with the right hand. Take two breaths. Exhale completely. Pull the legs up. Raise the knees above the floor. Simultaneously lift the chest off the floor. Lift up the head. Pull the head as far back as possible. Do not rest the ribs on the floor. Do not rest the pelvic bones on the floor. Only the abdomen bears the body's weight.

028.name: Parsva Dhanurasana
028.description:
Parsva Dhanurasana
In this variation of Dhanurasana, one performs the posture lying on one’s side.
Effects: Massages the abdominal organs by pressing them against the floor.
028.technique: Perform Dhanurasana. Exhale and roll over to the right side. Stretch the legs and chest. Inhale and come back to the starting position. Exhale and roll over to the left side. Stay on the left side for a specific length of time. Stay on the right side for the same length of time.

029.name: Chaturanga Dandasana
029.description:
Chaturanga Dandasana
The name means four limbs staff pose, where four means four, Anga means a limb or a part thereof, and Danda means a staff.
Effects: Strengthens the arms and the wrists, develops mobility and power, contracts and tones the abdominal organs.
029.technique: Lie flat on the floor, face downwards. Bend the elbows. Place the palms by the side of the chest. Keep the feet about a foot apart. Exhale and raise the whole body a few inches above the floor. Balance the body on the hands and the toes. Gradually extend the whole body forward. Rest the feet on the upper portion of the toes on the floor. Keep the body parallel to the floor, stiff as a staff. Stay in the pose for about thirty seconds. Maintain normal or deep breathing.

030.name: Nakrasana
030.description:
Nakrasana
Nakra means a crocodile and this posture consists of several dynamic movements resembling those of a crocodile stalking its prey.
Effects: develops powerful wrists, throws off lethargy of the body, fatigue of the brain, rejuvenates the entire body.
030.technique: Lie flat on the floor, face downwards. Bend the elbows. Place the palms by the side of the waist. Exhale. Raise the whole body a few inches above the floor. Take a few breaths. Exhale and lunge the whole body a foot forward. Lift the hands and feet simultaneously off the floor. Repeat the forward lunges four or five times. Reverse the movements. Jump back.

031.name: Bhujangasana I
031.description:
Bhujangasana I
Bhujanga means a serpent.
Effects: The posture is a panacea for an injured spine and in cases of slight displacement of spinal discs the practice of this pose replaces the discs in their original position, the spinal region is toned and the chest fully expanded.
031.technique: Lie on the floor face downwards. Extend the legs. Keep the feet together. Press your hips firmly into the floor. Rest the palms by the side of the pelvic region. Place hands right beneath your shoulders. Inhale and press the palms firmly on the floor. Pull the trunk up. Lift the body up from the trunk. The pubis is in contact with the floor. Contract the anus. Contract the buttocks. Tighten the thighs. Maintain the pose.

032.name: Urdhva Mukha Svanasana
032.description:
Urdhva Mukha Svanasana
Urdhva Mukha means having the mouth upwards and Svana means a dog.
Effects: Rejuvenates the spine, specially recommended for people suffering from a stiff back, good for lumbago, sciatica, those suffering from slipped or prolapsed discs, makes the lungs gain elasticity, cures backaches, sciatic pain, and expands lungs.
032.technique: Lie on the floor on your stomach with your face down. Place your palms on the floor by the side of your waist. Inhale and raise your head. Raise your trunk. Stretch your arms completely. Push your head and trunk as far back as possible. Do not rest your knees on the floor. Balance the weight of your body on your palms. Balance the weight of your body on your toes only. Stay in the pose for half a minute. Stay in the pose for a minute. Breathe deeply while holding the pose.

033.name: Adho Mukha Svanasana
033.description:
Adho Mukha Svanasana
Adho Mukha means having the face downwards, and Svana means a dog.
Effects: Removes fatigue, brings back the lost energy, relieves pain and stiffness in the heels, helps to soften calcaneal spurs, strengthens the ankles, makes the legs shapely, abdominal muscles are drawn towards the spine and strengthened, persons suffering from high blood pressure can do this pose, soothes brain cells.
033.technique: Lie full length on the floor on your stomach. Place your face downwards. Rest your palms by the side of your chest. Exhale and raise your trunk from the floor. Straighten your arms. Move your head inwards towards your feet. Place the crown of your head on the floor. Keep your legs stiff. Do not bend your knees. Press your heels down. Stay in the pose for about a minute. Breathe deeply.

034.name: Paripurna Navasana
034.note: Plate in book not quite in numerical order with its corresponding asana
034.description:
Paripurna Navasana or Complete Boat Pose
The posture here resembles that of a boat with oars.
Effects: Gives relief to persons who feel a bloating sensation in the abdomen due to gas, gives relief to those suffering from gastric complaints, reduces fat around the waistline, tones the kidneys.
034.technique: Sit on the floor. Stretch the legs straight in front. Exhale completely. Recline the trunk slightly backward. Simultaneously raise the legs from the floor. Keep the legs straight and stiff. Balance the body on the buttocks. Maintain an angle of sixty to sixty-five degrees between the trunk and legs. Remove the hands from the floor. Stretch the arms forward near the thighs. Hold the pose for thirty seconds.

035.name: Dandasana
035.description:
Dandasana
Danda means a staff or rod.
Effects: Improves posture, foundation for seated poses.
035.technique: Sit on the floor. Stretch the legs straight in front. Place the palms on the floor. Position the palms by the hips. Point the fingers toward the feet. Stretch the hands straight. Keep the back erect. Press the hands down to lengthen the trunk. Extend the heels away from the pelvis. Draw the tops of the thighs down. Release the shoulders away from the ears. Look straight ahead.

037.name: Gomukhasana
037.description:
Gomukhasana
Gomukha means one whose face resembles a cow.
Effects: The pose cures cramp in the legs and makes the leg muscles elastic, the chest is well expanded, the back becomes erect, the shoulder joints move freely.
037.technique: Sit on the floor. Bend the left knee back. Sit on the left foot. Place the right thigh over the left one. Raise the left arm over the head. Bend the left arm at the elbow. Place the left palm below the nape of neck. Lower the right arm. Bend the right arm at the elbow. Raise the right forearm up behind the back. Clasp the hands. Hold the pose for thirty to sixty seconds.

038.name: Lolasana
038.description:
Lolasana
Lola means tremulous, moving to and fro or dangling like an earring.
Effects: strengthens the wrists and hands, the muscles of the back and the abdominal organs.
038.technique: Sit on the floor. Place your palms on the floor beside your hips. Bend your right knee. Place your right sole beneath your left buttock. Sit on your right foot. Bend your left knee. Place your left sole beneath your right buttock. Sit on your left foot. Cross your feet. Exhale fully. Raise your trunk and legs off the floor. Balance your body on your hands. Gently rock your trunk and legs forward. Gently rock your trunk and legs backward.

039.name: Siddhasana
039.description:
Siddhasana
Siddha means a semi-divine being supposed to be of great purity.
Effects: Keeps the pubic region healthy, is one of the most relaxing of asanas, recommended for meditation and pranayama, tones the lower region of the spine and abdominal organs, purifies seventy-two thousand nadis, ideal for meditation.
039.technique: Sit on the floor. Bend your left leg. Place your left heel near the perineum. Bend your right leg. Place your right foot over your left ankle. Position your right heel against your pubic bone. Stretch your arms. Rest the back of your hands on your knees in Ja Mudra. Gaze at the tip of your nose.

040.name: Virasana
040.description:
Virasana or Hero Pose
Vira means a hero or warrior.
Effects: Cures rheumatic pains in the knees, gout, is also good for flat feet, and will relieve heaviness in the stomach.
040.technique: Kneel on the floor. Spread the feet about eighteen inches apart. Rest the buttocks on the floor between the feet. The inner side of each calf should touch the outer side of its respective thigh. Keep the back erect. Interlock the fingers. Stretch the arms straight overhead with palms facing up. Exhale completely. Place the palms on the soles of the feet. Bend forward from the hips. Rest the chin on the knees.

041.name: Supta Virasana
041.description:
forty one / Supta Virasana
Supta means lying down.
Effects: stretches the abdominal organs, stretches the pelvic region, relieves aching legs, athlete recovery, aids digestion.
041.technique: Sit in Virasana. Exhale completely. Recline the trunk back. Rest the elbows on the floor. Rest the crown of the head on the floor. Rest the back of the head on the floor. Rest the back on the floor. Stretch the arms out straight.

042.name: Paryankasana
042.description:
Paryankasana
In it the body resembles a couch.
Effects: Dorsal region is fully extended so that the lungs are well expanded, thyroids and parathyroids are stimulated.
042.technique: Sit in Virasana. Exhale completely. Recline slowly onto your back. Arch your back upwards. Rest only the crown of your head on the floor. Hold your opposite elbows behind your head.

043.name: Bhekasana
043.description:
Bhekasana or Frog Pose
Bheka means a frog.
Effects: Abdominal organs benefit, relieves pain in knee joints due to rheumatism, cures flat feet, relieves pain in heels, relieves knee pain, tones abdomen.
043.technique: Lie face down on your stomach. Exhale as you bend your knees. Bring your heels toward your hips. Hold the soles of your feet with your hands. Turn your hands so your palms touch the upper part of your feet. Point your toes toward your head. Push your hands down.

044.name: Baddha Konasana
044.description:
Baddha Konasana or Indian Cobbler Seat
Baddha means caught.
Effects: Recommended for urinary disorders, keeps kidneys, prostate and bladder healthy, blessings to women, checks irregular periods and helps ovaries, pregt women will have much less pain during delivery.
044.technique: Sit on the floor. Sit firmly with your sit bones on the mat. Join the soles of your feet. Bring your heels as close to the hips as possible. Grip your feet firmly. Widen your thighs. Lower your knees toward the floor. Exhale and bend your torso forward. Rest your chin on the floor.

045.name: Padmasana
045.description:
Padmasana or Lotus posture
This is the forty-fifth pose described.
Effects: One of the most relaxing poses, keeps mind attentive and alert, good for curing stiffness in knees and ankles, spine and abdominal organs are toned, basic meditation pose, tones abdominal organs/spine.
045.technique: Sit with your legs straight. Place your right foot at the root of your left thigh. Bring your right heel near your navel. Place your left foot at the root of your right thigh. Bring your left heel near your navel.

046.name: Sanmukhi Mudra
046.description:
Sanmukhi Mudra or Closing Up
San means six and mukha means mouth.
Effects: The senses are turned inwards, rhythm calms the mind, prepares practitioner for Pratyahara, turns senses inward, brings inner peace, prepares for Pratyahara.
046.technique: Sit in Padmasana. Raise your hands to your face. Place your thumbs on your earholes. Place your fingers on your eyelids. Press your nostrils with your ring fingers. Place your little fingers on your upper lip.

047.name: Parvatasana
047.description:
Parvatasana
Parvata means a mountain.
Effects: Relieves rheumatic pains and stiffness in shoulders, chest expands fully, relieves shoulder stiffness, expands chest.
047.technique: Sit in Padmasana. Interlock the fingers. Stretch the hands vertically up over the head. Maintain a straight back and lifted chest. Lengthen the spine. Ground the sitting bones.

048.name: Tolasana
048.description:
Tolasana
Tola means a pair of scales.
Effects: Strengthens wrists, hands, abdominal walls
048.technique: Sit in Padmasana. Place palms on the floor by your hips. Exhale completely. Raise your trunk upwards. Balance only on your hands.

049.name: Simhasana I
049.description:
Simhasana One
Simha means a lion and the pose is dedicated to the Narasimha incarnation.
Effects: Cures foul breath, cleans the tongue, recommended to stammerers, clears speech for stammerers.
049.technique: Kneel on the floor in Vajrasana. Sit on your heels. Place your palms on your knees. Spread your fingers apart. Take a deep inhalation through the nose. Exhale completely as you open your jaws wide. Stretch your tongue out towards your chin. Gaze at the spot between your eyebrows. Roar two or three times while exhaling. Release the pose. Sit down again in Vajrasana.

050.name: Simhasana II
050.description:
Simhasana Two or Lion Pose Two
The descriptive meaning of the name is not available in the provided text.
Effects: Exercises the liver, controls bile, relieves a painful coccyx.
050.technique: Sit in Padmasana. Place palms on the floor. Stand on your knees. Push your pelvis toward the floor. Open your mouth. Stretch your tongue out.

051.name: Matsyasana
051.description:
Matsyasana or Fish incarnation
This is also known as the Fish incarnation.
Effects: Dorsal region fully extended, chest expanded, relieves inflamed and bleeding piles, full breathing, stimulates thyroids, relieves piles.
051.technique: Sit in Padmasana. Lie flat on your back. Exhale and arch your back. Rest the crown of your head on the floor. Hold your elbows with your hands behind your head.

052.name: Kukkutasana
052.description:
fifty-two / Kukkutasana
Kukkuta means a cock.
Effects: Strengthens wrists and abdominal walls.
052.technique: Sit in Padmasana. Insert hands between the thigh and calf near the knees. Exhale slowly. Raise the entire body off the floor. Balance the body on the palms of the hands.

053.name: Garbha Pindasana
053.description:
Garbha Pindasana or Embryo in the Womb
The descriptive meaning of the name is Embryo in the womb.
Effects: Abdominal organs contracted completely, blood circulates well around organs, contracts abdominal organs, improves blood circulation.
053.technique: Sit in Lotus Pose. Insert arms between thighs and calves. Exhale completely. Lift your thighs upward. Balance your body on your coccyx. Reach out with your hands. Grab your ears with your fingers. Maintain your balance on the sit bones. Keep breath awareness to maintain balance.

054.name: Goraksasana
054.description:
Goraksasana
Goraksa means a cowherd.
Effects: Achieves sense of balance, coccyx gets elasticity, develops balance, provides coccyx elasticity.
054.technique: Sit on the floor in Padmasana. Stretch your arms forward and place them on the floor. Raise your trunk. Lift your hips off the floor. Keep your trunk straight. Stand up with your knees still bent. Stretch your thighs. Gradually lift your hands off the floor one by one. Maintain the balance of your spine. Join your hands in a prayer position in front of your chest.

055.name: Baddha Padmasana
055.description:
Baddha Padmasana
Baddha means bound.
Effects: Expands the chest, increases range of shoulder movements, increases shoulder mobility.
055.technique: Sit in Padmasana. Exhale deeply. Swing your arms behind your back. Catch your big toes. The chest expands. Shoulder mobility increases.

056.name: Yoga Mudrasana
056.description:
Yoga Mudrasana
This pose is a continuation of Baddha Padmasana.
Effects: Intensifies peristaltic activity, relieves constipation, awakens Kundalini.
056.technique: This pose is a continuation of Baddha Padmasana. Exhale completely. Bend forward from the hips. Rest the head upon the floor.

057.name: Supta Vajrasana
057.description:
Supta Vajrasana or Lying thunderbolt
This pose is the lying thunderbolt.
Effects: Dorsal region fully extended, Pelvic joints become elastic, Intense chest expansion, benefits thyroids.
057.technique: Sit in Baddha Padmasana. Exhale. Raise both knees. Recline your back onto the floor. Arch the chest. Rest the crown of your head on the floor.

058.name: Maha Mudra
058.description:
Maha Mudra or Great seal
Great seal is the descriptive meaning of the name.
Effects: Tones abdominal organs, kidneys and adrenal glands, Relieves prolapsed womb, Destroys death and many other pains, Destroyer of death/decay, cures consumption and leprosy.
058.technique: Sit on the floor in a comfortable position. Extend the right leg straight out in front. Keep the left foot tucked against the right inner thigh. Inhale deeply. Lift the arms overhead and stretch upwards. Bend forward toward the extended leg. Hook the big toe of the right leg with the thumb and forefingers. Tuck the chin so it rests in the hollow of the collar bones. Perform Jalandhara Bandha. Tighten the entire abdomen. Perform Uddiyana Bandha. Hold the breath inside. Perform Mula Bandha. Exhale slowly. Lift the head and release the hands. Straighten the arms. Raise the arms above the head. Bring the arms down to the sides as you finish breathing out. Relax the body. Repeat on the other side.

059.name: Janu Sirsasana
059.description:
Janu Sirsasana
Janu means knee and Sirsa means head.
Effects: Tones liver and spleen, beneficial for enlargement of prostate gland, aids digestion.
059.technique: Sit with one leg straight. Place the other heel near the perineum. Inhale and lengthen your spine. Exhale and reach for the outstretched foot. Catch the outstretched foot. Exhale fully as you bend forward from the hips. Rest your chin beyond your knee.

060.name: Parivrtta Janu Sirsasana
060.description:
Parivrtta Janu Sirsasana or Revolved knee-head pose
This pose involves one leg straight with the other heel near the perineum, twisting the trunk to the left, and holding the foot with both hands while resting the back of the head on the knee.
Effects: Stimulates blood circulation to the spine, invigorating, stimulates spinal circulation, invigorates abdominal organs.
060.technique: Extend one leg straight out. Place the other heel near the perineum. Twist the trunk toward the left. Hold the extended foot with both hands. Rest the back of the head on the knee.

061.name: Ardha Baddha Padma Paschimottanasana
061.description:
Ardha Baddha Padma Paschimottanasana or Half bound lotus back stretch
This pose is known as the Half bound lotus back stretch.
Effects: Navel pull tones organs, Recommended for drooping shoulders, Stimulates Svadhisthana Chakra, cures drooping shoulders.
061.technique: Begin seated in Dandasana. Extend one leg straight forward. Bend the other leg and place the foot in half lotus on the opposite hip crease. Turn your torso slightly towards the bent leg. Reach the hand from the bent leg around your back. Clasp the big toe of the lotus foot from behind your back. Lift the ribcage to lengthen the spine. Exhale and fold forward over the straight leg. Catch the extended straight foot with your free hand. Rest your chin or forehead upon your knee. Maintain alignment of the spine while folding. Engage the navel pull to tone organs. Hold the pose while maintaining mindful breathing. Release the pose with an inhale. Repeat on the opposite side.

062.name: Trianga Mukhaikapada Paschimottanasana
062.description:
Trianga Mukhaikapada Paschimottanasana or Three-limbed back stretch
This pose is a three-limbed back stretch.
Effects: Recommended for flat feet and dropped arches, reduces swelling in legs, cures ankle/knee sprains, reduces leg swelling.
062.technique: Begin in Staff Pose. Keep one leg straight. Bend the other knee backward. Position the top of the bent foot on the ground near the hip. Press the top of the bent foot into the floor. Ground both sitting bones equally. Lengthen your spine. Stretch both arms forward. Grab the extended foot with both hands. Flex the extended foot. Fold forward. Bring your chin to your knee. Deepen the stretch on each exhale.

063.name: Krounchasana
063.description:
Krounchasana or Heron pose
The technique involves one leg bent back and the other leg raised vertically while holding the raised foot and bringing the chin to the knee.
Effects: Harder than Paschimottanasana, rejuvenates abdominal organs, full leg extension.
063.technique: Start in Dandasana. Bend one leg back into Virasana. Keep the opposite leg straight. Extend the back of the straight leg up to the heel. Move the front of the thigh to the back of the thigh. Bend the knee of the straight leg. Hold the raised foot with your hands. Raise the foot vertically toward the ceiling. Straighten the knee completely. Pull the leg closer to your body. Bring your chin to your knee. Keep your torso long. Extend up through the crown of your head. Pull your navel back. Release the pose gently.

064.name: Marichyasana I
064.description:
Marichyasana I
Dedicated to sage Marichi.
Effects: Finger strength, contraction keeps abdominal organs healthy, strengthens fingers, creates vigorous abdominal contraction.
064.technique: Sit in Dandasana. Extend one leg straight forward. Bend the other knee. Place the bent foot flat on the floor close to the hip. Wrap the arm around the bent knee. Clasp the hands behind the back. Inhale and lengthen the torso. Exhale and fold the torso forward. Bring the chin toward the straight knee. Stay in the pose. Release the hands. Straighten the bent leg. Return to Dandasana.

065.name: Marichyasana II
065.description:
Marichyasana Two or Pose Dedicated to the Sage Marichi Two
The posture is an intensified form of pose one.
Effects: Intensified form of one, heel at navel increases abdominal pressure, intensified version of one, tones abdominal organs better.
065.technique: Sit in Staff Pose. Place one leg in half lotus position. Bend the other knee. Keep the foot flat on the floor. Wrap the arm around the bent knee. Clasp the hands behind the back. Bring the chin to the knee in lotus position. Extend and expand the body for space. Lower the wrist towards the ground. Raise the head and lift the sternum. Exhale and extend the trunk over the straight leg. Hold the pose and take slow, deep breaths. Carefully rise with an inhale. Straighten the bent leg. Use the hands to release the lotus foot. Change sides.

066.name: Upavistha Konasana
066.description:
Upavistha Konasana or Seated angle
The descriptive meaning of the pose is Widen legs sideways, catch big toes, and rest chin and chest on floor.
Effects: Improves blood circulation in pelvic region, Boons to women, controls menstrual flow, Regularizes menstrual flow, prevents hernia and sciatica.
066.technique: Widen legs sideways. Catch big toes. Rest chin on floor. Rest chest on floor.

067.name: Brahmacharyasana
067.description:
Brahmacharyasana or Intense back stretch
This pose is also known as Ugrasana.
Effects: Tones abdominal organs, kidneys and spine, Increases vitality, helps cure impotency, Massages the heart, Massages heart/spine, control of sex appetite.
067.technique: Sit with your legs straight. Catch your big toes. Concave your back. Fold your body forward. Touch your chin to your shins.

068.name: Parivrtta Paschimottanasana
068.description:
Parivrtta Paschimottanasana or Revolved back stretch
This pose is a revolved back stretch.
Effects: Rejuvenates entire spine, helps to cure impotency, promotes sex control, rejuvenates spine/kidneys.
068.technique: Sit in Staff Pose. Exhale and fold forward from the hips, bringing the abdomen to the thighs. Inhale and keep the spine long. To twist right, place the left palm up. Lean forward. Grasp the outside of the right foot with the left hand. Position the left forearm outside the right leg. Take the right arm back. Catch the top of the right foot with the left hand. Shift the head back. Extend the crown of the head toward the top of the feet. Twist the abdomen and chest toward the sky. Gaze straight ahead.

069.name: Urdhva Mukha Paschimottanasana I
069.note: Plate in book not quite in numerical order with its corresponding asana
069.description:
Urdhva Mukha Paschimottanasana I or Upward face back stretch
The descriptive meaning of the name is Upward face back stretch.
Effects: Helps balance and poise, stretches legs fully, Develops balance and poise, stretches legs fully.
069.technique: Balance on the buttocks. Stretch the legs up. Catch the heels. Rest the forehead on the knees. Engage the pelvic floor muscles. Pull the tummy in. Extend the spine fully. Balance on the sit bones. Bring the chin to the knee. Lift the spine from the base. Lengthen the spine up. Stay in the pose for several breaths. Release the grip on the feet. Gently lower the legs down. Relax in Dandasana.

070.name: Ubhaya Padangusthasana
070.description:
Ubhaya Padangusthasana or Both big toes pose
This pose involves balancing on the buttocks while catching the big toes and straightening the legs in the air.
Effects: Develops balance, abdominal strength.
070.technique: Sit on the floor with your legs outstretched. Bend your knees. Draw your heels in towards your buttocks. Balance on your sit bones. Engage your core. Hold on to each of your big toes with your thumb and forefinger. Lift and straighten your legs into the air. Open your chest. Lift your lower back upwards. Flex through your heels. Gaze at your toes. Hold this position. Gently release your arms and legs back to the floor.

071.name: Urdhva Mukha Paschimottanasana II
071.description:
Urdhva Mukha Paschimottanasana II
The technique involves lying flat, bringing the legs over the head, clasping the soles, and lowering the legs beyond the head with the chin touching the knees (Image one hundred seventy).
Effects: Benefits same as Paschimottanasana, prevents hernia, relieves backaches, prevents hernia, relieves severe backaches.
071.technique: Lie flat on the floor. Bring your legs up over your head. Clasp your soles with your hands. Rest your entire back on the floor. Exhale your breath. Lower your legs beyond your head. Bring your chin to your knees.

072.name: Purvottanasana
072.description:
Purvottanasana
The descriptive meaning is an intense stretch of the East (front).
Effects: Strengthens wrists and ankles, relieves fatigue from forward bends, expands chest.
072.technique: Sit on the floor with your legs straight in front of you. Place your palms on the floor behind your hips. Point your fingers toward your feet. Press your hands into the floor. Press your feet and legs down into the floor. Lift your hips off the floor. Straighten your arms. Lift your chest toward the ceiling. Throw your head back.

073.name: Akarna Dhanurasana
073.description:
Akarna Dhanurasana or Archer Pose

The name is derived from the Sanskrit word karna which means ear and the prefix a which means toward or near. Dhanu translates to a bow. The posture describes the physical action of pulling the foot near the ear which resembles an archer pulling back a bow string to its full extent.

Effects: adjusts minor hip deformities, exercises the lower spine, aids bowel movement.
073.technique: Sit on the floor with the legs stretched straight in front in dandasana. Press the heels and the backs of the knees firmly into the mat. Lift the sides of the waist and the chest vertically. Reach forward and hold the right big toe between the right thumb and the index and middle fingers. Hold the left big toe with the left thumb and the index and middle fingers in the same manner. Keep the spinal column erect and the legs fully extended. Exhale and bend the left elbow to lift the left foot. Bend the left knee and bring the leg upward. Take one breath. Exhale and pull the left foot toward the head until the heel rests near the left ear. Draw the left arm back from the shoulder as if pulling a bow string. Maintain a firm grip on the right big toe. Keep the right leg straight and pinned to the floor. Ensure the back of the right knee does not lift. Hold this position for fifteen to twenty seconds while breathing normally. Exhale and stretch the left leg up vertically toward the ceiling. Take one breath. Exhale and draw the straightened left leg further back until the calf touches the left ear. Grip both big toes firmly throughout the movement. Extend both legs fully without bending the knees. Balance the trunk and the head in this vertical stretch. Remain in this position for ten to fifteen seconds with normal breathing. Exhale and bend the left knee to bring the left heel back to the left ear. Lower the left leg carefully to the floor. Stretch both legs straight in front in the starting position. Repeat the entire process on the right side by pulling the right foot toward the right ear. Raise the right leg vertically while the left leg remains straight on the floor. Maintain the pose on the right side for an equal length of time. Release the grip on the big toes. Relax the arms and legs completely.

074.name: Salamba Sirsasana I
074.description:
Salamba Sirsasana I or Supported headstand
It is the king of all asanas.
Effects: Tonic for the brain cells, ensures proper blood supply to pituitary and pineal glands, boon to memory and vitality, improves hemoglobin.
074.technique: Interlock your fingers and cup your palms. Place the crown of your head on the blanket. Lift your knees off the floor. Walk your feet toward your head. Swing your legs up into the pose. Straighten your body to stand perpendicular to the floor. Press your forearms firmly into the floor. Lift your shoulders away from your ears. Extend through the heels of your feet. Maintain steady and even breathing. Slowly lower your legs back down to the floor.

075.name: Urdhva Dandasana
075.note: Plate 188 appears in the middle of the sequence of plates for Salamba Sirasana I
075.description:
Urdhva Dandasana or Upward staff
The pose is performed in headstand by lowering the legs parallel to the floor.
Effects: Strengthens neck, shoulders, abdomen, and spine.
075.technique: Begin by following the instructions for Headstand Pose. Upon release, exhale slowly. Lower your legs slowly. Engage your core. Engage your shoulders. Engage your neck. Pause halfway. Position your legs parallel to the floor. Position your legs perpendicular to your torso. Bring your knees close to each other. Engage your pelvis. Engage your hips. Press your hands into the floor. Lift your hips up. Come into a reverse tabletop position. Straighten your arms. Lift your chest up. Keep your legs straight. Engage your core to maintain the pose. Hold the pose for a few breaths. Release back down to the floor.

076.name: Salamba Sirsasana II
076.description:
Salamba Sirsasana Two or Headstand Two
Technique involves placing palms on the floor parallel and the crown of the head between them, then swinging legs up.
Effects: Essential for advanced arm balances like Bakasana, foundation for advanced balances.
076.technique: Place the palms on the floor parallel to each other. Position the crown of the head between the palms. Lift the pelvis. Bend the legs. Extend the sacrum. Swing the legs up. Maintain a straight back. Lift the heels. Resist the chest. Extend the body upwards.

077.name: Salamba Sirsasana III
077.description:
Salamba Sirsasana three or Headstand three
This posture is the supported headstand variation three.
Effects: Firmness and confidence in balance.
077.technique: Place your palms on the blanket. Ensure your fingers point toward your feet. Tuck your toes. Lift your knees off the floor. Straighten your legs. This forms Dolphin Pose. Walk your feet toward your head. Your hips should align above your shoulders. Keep pressing firmly through your arms. Place the crown of your head on the blanket. Press down through your arms. Draw your shoulder blades away from your ears. Lift your legs up. Bring your legs perpendicular to the floor. Maintain a steady gaze. Breathe evenly in the pose.

078.name: Baddha Hasta Sirsasana
078.description:
Baddha Hasta Sirsasana or Bound hand headstand
This posture involves folding the arms, catching the upper arms, placing the crown of the head on a blanket beyond the forearms, and pulling the legs up.
Effects: Puts strain on neck, eventually brings lightness, Builds spinal and neck strength.
078.technique: Begin in a kneeling position. Place your forearms on the mat. Fold your arms. Catch your upper arms with your hands. Place the crown of your head on a blanket. Position the blanket beyond your forearms. Tuck your toes. Straighten your legs. Walk your feet in towards your head. Engage your core. Pull your legs up toward the ceiling. Press your elbows into the ground. Press your shoulder girdle down. Suck your ribs in. Point your feet. Maintain the balance. Switch the hand grip. Maintain balance on your head. Bend at your waist. Exhale. Jump back to Chaturanga Dandasana.

079.name: Mukta Hasta Sirsasana
079.description:
Mukta Hasta Sirsasana or Free hand headstand
This is a Free hand headstand.
Effects: Most difficult headstand variation, complete mastery of head stand.
079.technique: Place the top of your head on the floor. Position your arms straight in front of your head. Put your wrists on the floor. Your palms face up. Engage your core. Walk your feet towards your hands. Lift your legs up towards the ceiling. Find your centerline alignment. Keep your arms and shoulders strong. Maintain a strong core. Hold the pose. Slowly bring your legs back down. Rest your feet on the floor. Come out of the pose.

080.name: Parsva Sirsasana
080.description:
Parsva Sirsasana or Side headstand.
This pose is known as a side headstand.
Effects: Makes spine strong and elastic, elasticity of spine and floating ribs.
080.technique: Enter Sirsasana. Maintain balance. Tilt your feet to the side. Use your core to twist. Twist your spine ninety degrees right. Return to center. Twist your spine ninety degrees left. Return to center. Maintain alignment of the head, sternum, navel, and pelvis while twisting.

081.name: Parivrttaikapada Sirsasana
081.description:
Parivrttaikapada Sirsasana or Revolved one-leg headstand
The descriptive meaning of the name is Revolved one-leg headstand.
Effects: Tones kidneys, bladder, prostate, intestines, develops leg muscles.
081.technique: Enter Headstand pose. Spread the legs wide apart. Twist the spine in a clockwise direction. Maintain the position. Exit the pose.

082.name: Eka Pada Sirsasana (Variation)
082.description:
Eka Pada Sirsasana or One-leg headstand
The descriptive meaning of the name is One-leg headstand.
Effects: Strengthens neck, strengthens abdominal walls.
082.technique: Begin in Headstand. Engage your core. Lower your right leg slowly towards the floor. Place your right foot on the floor in front of you. Press your left toes down. Feel a stretch in your left hip flexor. Keep both legs extended upwards. Keep the spine aligned with your shoulders and head. Exhale and bring the right leg down slowly to release. Place your right foot close to your left foot. Return to Headstand. Inhale and raise your left leg up following the same steps. Hold the posture. Exhale and release the left leg slowly. Settle the body down in Child Pose.

083.name: Parsvaika Pada Sirsasana
083.description:
Parsvaika Pada Sirsasana or Side one-leg headstand
This is a side one-leg headstand.
Effects: Tones intestines, and tones spine.
083.technique: Hold in Sirsasana. Maintain your Tadasana line. Lower one leg over to the side. Repeat the pose on both sides. Avoid shifting the body to the side as the leg is lowered.

084.name: Urdhva Padmasana in Sirsasana
084.description:
Urdhva Padmasana in Sirsasana or Lotus in headstand
This pose involves crossing the legs in lotus position while inverted in a headstand, with the thighs held vertically.
Effects: Expands the chest, circulates blood in pelvic region.
084.technique: Start in a kneeling position. Place your forearms on the mat. Interlace your fingers. Place the crown of your head on the mat. Cradle your head with your hands. Lift your knees. Walk your feet towards your head. Slowly lift your legs into a regular headstand position. Establish balance in the headstand. Bend your right knee. Place your right foot on your left thigh. Bend your left knee. Place your left foot on your right thigh. Cross your legs in the lotus position while in the headstand. Straighten your folded legs upward with the thighs moving vertically. Maintain balance. Slowly bring your legs back to the ground.

085.name: Parsva Urdhva Padmasana in Sirsasana
085.description:
Parsva Urdhva Padmasana in Sirsasana or Lateral twist in inverted lotus
This pose is number eighty-five and is described as a lateral twist in inverted lotus.
Effects: Intensifies inverted lotus benefits.
085.technique: Begin in Sirsasana. Bend the knees. Cross the legs into Padmasana. Hold the legs firmly together. Maintain the balance. Initiate a lateral twist of the torso. Draw the ribs towards one side. Keep the head stable. Extend the twist fully. Hold the pose. Return the torso to center. Release the legs. Straighten the legs. Return to Sirsasana.

086.name: Pindasana in Sirsasana
086.description:
Pindasana in Sirsasana or Embryo in headstand.
The descriptive meaning is Embryo in headstand.
Effects: Tones abdominal organs by contraction.
086.technique: Begin in Sirsasana. Bring your right leg into a fold from the knee. Place the right foot over the opposite thigh. Fold your left leg from the knee. Place the left foot over the right thigh. Bring your lower body into Lotus Pose. Inhale and exhale to gently bend your lower body forward. Contact your stomach deeply to enter the Embryo Pose. Lower your legs to touch your armpits. Hold the pose focusing on balance and breathing. Inhale and bring your lower body up. Release the Lotus Pose. Gently bring your body down. Relax the body in Child Pose.

087.name: Salamba Sarvangasana I
087.description:
Salamba Sarvangasana I or Supported shoulderstand
This is known as the Mother of asanas and is a panacea for common ailments.
Effects: Panacea for common ailments, stimulates thyroid and parathyroid glands, relieves asthma, bronchitis and throat ailments, soothes nerves, relieves hypertension and insomnia.
087.technique: Lie flat on your back. Use blankets or bolsters to support your shoulders. Bend your knees and lift your hips. Bring your thighs toward your chest. Press down through your hands or arms. Lift your torso up. Place your palms on your lower back for support. Keep your elbows shoulder-width apart. Straighten your legs upward. Stack your hips over your shoulders. Press your elbows into the blankets. Lift your chest toward your chin. Maintain vertical alignment. Engage the chinlock (Jalandhara Bandha). Keep your neck relaxed. Hold the pose with smooth breath. Slowly roll your spine to the floor to exit the pose.

088.name: Salamba Sarvangasana II
088.description:
Salamba Sarvangasana II
The technique involves interlocking fingers, turning wrists, and extending arms behind the head on the floor from Sarvangasana I, which is shown in Image two hundred thirty-five.
Effects: Back and neck gain strength, strengthens back and neck.
088.technique: Begin from Sarvangasana I. Interlock your fingers. Turn your wrists. Extend your arms behind your head on the floor. Press your arms firmly into the earth. Press the pinky side of your hand into the earth.

089.name: Niralamba Sarvangasana I
089.description:
Niralamba Sarvangasana I or Unsupported shoulderstand I
This is a variation of the shoulderstand where the hands are released.
Effects: Muscles of neck, back, and abdomen strengthened, strengthens neck, back, and abdomen via weight balance.
089.technique: Start from Sarvangasana. Release the hands from the back. Rest the extended arms on the floor beside the body. Use abdominal strength to lift the legs and arms skyward. Keep the legs straight. Keep the arms straight beside the body. Engage the core for stability. Rest the weight solely on the shoulders. Tuck the chin to the chest. Keep the neck pressed on the ground. Elongate the spine. Focus the gaze up at the toes. Breathe deep and slow.

090.name: Niralamba Sarvangasana II
090.description:
Niralamba Sarvangasana II or Unsupported shoulderstand II.
This pose is the unsupported version of the second shoulderstand.
Effects: Hardest Sarvangasana, extends vertebrae more than others, hardest shoulderstand, maximum vertebral extension.
090.technique: Lie down on your back facing the ceiling. Outstretch your legs parallel to each other. Outstretch your arms parallel to your body beside you. Transition from Sarvangasana into the unsupported pose. Release your arms from supporting your back. Engage your abdominal strength to lift your legs and arms skyward. Rest your body weight solely on your shoulders. Keep your legs elevated and straight. Keep your feet and toes together. Point your toes up towards the ceiling. Broaden and engage your shoulders. Press your neck against the ground in a forward bend. Keep your hips squared and lifted. Keep your palms on or by the side of your knees.

091.name: Halasana
091.description:
Halasana or Plough pose
This pose involves lowering the legs over the head until the toes touch the floor.
Effects: Abdominal organs rejuvenated, Relieves backache, lumbago, arthritis, Good for high blood pressure tendency, Relieves arthritic spine.
091.technique: Start from Sarvangasana I. Slowly lower the legs backward over the head. Bring your toes to the floor behind you. Interlock your fingers. Stretch your arms opposite your legs. Press your outer upper arms into the floor. Press your shoulders into the floor. Create lift along the spine. Keep your legs firm.

092.name: Karnapidasana
092.description:
Karnapidasana or Ear pressure pose.
Ear pressure pose is the descriptive meaning of this pose.
Effects: Rests trunk, heart and legs, rests heart and legs, circulates blood around waist.
092.technique: Begin the pose from Halasana. Bend the knees. Lower the knees toward the floor beside the ears. Press the knees gently against the ears.

093.name: Supta Konasana
093.description:
ninety-three / Supta Konasana or Reclining angle
The descriptive meaning is Reclining angle.
Effects: Tones legs, contracts abdominal organs.
093.technique: Begin from Halasana. Widen the legs apart. Keep the legs straight. Push the heels forward. Hold the big toes. Maintain the balance at the shoulders. Breathe steadily while holding the pose.

094.name: Parsva Halasana
094.description:
Parsva Halasana or Lateral plough
This is the name of the yoga pose, which is done by moving both legs as far as you can to the left or right from Halasana.
Effects: Spine moves laterally, benefits chronic constipation, cures chronic constipation, lateral spinal movement.
094.technique: Begin in a variation of Shoulder Stand Pose. Exhale and gently lower your feet to the floor. Twist your hips completely. Extend your legs towards the side. Place your toes on the floor. Support your hips with your hands. Move both legs as far as you can to the left or right from Halasana.

095.name: Eka Pada Sarvangasana
095.description:
Eka Pada Sarvangasana or One-leg shoulderstand
This is a one-leg shoulderstand posture.
Effects: Tones kidneys, tones leg muscles.
095.technique: Lie down on your back. Bring your legs together and raise them up. Lift your hips up into shoulderstand pose. Support your body with your hands on your back. Keep one leg straight up toward the ceiling. Lower the other leg down overhead. Touch the toes of the lowered leg to the floor behind your head. Hold the pose for a few breaths. Inhale and raise the lowered leg back up. Exhale and lower the opposite leg down overhead. Touch the toes of the opposite leg to the floor behind your head. Inhale and bring both legs back up. Exhale and slowly lower your back to the floor. Release your hands and relax.

096.name: Parsvaika Pada Sarvangasana
096.description:
Parsvaika Pada Sarvangasana or Side one-leg shoulderstand
The technique involves lowering one leg sideways to the floor in line with the trunk.
Effects: Relieves constipation, tones kidneys.
096.technique: Begin in Shoulderstand Pose. Maintain the vertical extension of the body. Keep one leg extended upwards. Lower the other leg sideways toward the floor. Keep the lowered leg in line with the trunk. Keep the shoulders engaged. Push the tailbone upwards. Gaze toward the foot that is in the air. Return to Shoulderstand. Repeat the process on the opposite side.

097.name: Parsva Sarvangasana
097.description:
Parsva Sarvangasana or Side shoulderstand
The technique involves a lateral twist of the trunk and weight on one elbow and wrist.
Effects: Strengthens wrists, exercises liver, pancreas, and spleen.
097.technique: Lie down with your shoulders on blankets. Place your head on the floor. Lift your hips and bring your thighs toward your chest. Place your hands on your lower back for support. Straighten your legs upward. Press your weight into your shoulders and upper arms. Walk your hands higher up your back. Lift your chest toward your chin. Perform a lateral twist of the trunk. Place weight on one elbow. Place weight on the corresponding wrist. Extend your legs toward the horizon.

098.name: Setu Bandha Sarvangasana
098.description:
Setu Bandha Sarvangasana or Bridge formation
This is the ninety-eighth pose, which is a bridge formation.
Effects: Backward movement removes neck strain, sound mind and body, backward movement of spine, healthy nervous system.
098.technique: Begin in Sarvangasana. Drop your legs back straight to the floor. Place your feet close to your hips. Press your feet down. Raise your buttocks up. Move your back ribs in and up. Coil the back ribs in. Move your tailbone in. You can hold your ankles. Lift the legs higher up.

099.name: Eka Pada Setu Bandha Sarvangasana
099.iast: Eka Pāda Setu Bandha Sarvāngāsana (Eka Pāda Uttāna Mayūrāsana)
099.note: ; Alternate names: Eka Pada Uttana Mayurasana
099.description:
Eka Pada Uttana Mayurasana or One-leg bridge
This pose is also known as One-leg bridge.
Effects: Strengthens legs, increases spinal flexibility.
099.technique: Begin by lying down in a supine position. Align your body into Bridge Pose Variation Bound Hands. Inhale and press the right foot firmly into the ground. Exhale and engage your core. Lift your left foot off the ground. Extend the left leg. Point your toes to the sky. Lift the pelvis to keep the hips high. Press your chest up and back. Apply Chin Lock (Jalandhara Bandha). Stay in the pose for several breaths. Exhale and lower the left leg. Return to the Bridge Pose. Slowly bring your upper back down. Lower your middle back next. Bring your lower back down last. Repeat the pose with the other leg.

100.name: Urdhva Padmasana in Sarvangasana
100.description:
Urdhva Padmasana in Sarvangasana
Urdhva means above, high, and Padma means a lotus.
Effects: No benefits listed.
100.technique: Begin in Sarvangasana or Shoulderstand Pose. Release your hands from supporting the back. Slowly cross your legs into Padmasana. Maintain balance on your shoulders and head. Place your right foot on your left thigh. Place your left foot on your right thigh. With legs in Lotus Pose, use your hands to push the legs upwards. Balance in Urdhva Padmasana or Upward Lotus Pose. Place your hands on your knees or thighs. Push the knees upwards. Extend your arms straight. Keep your spine long.

101.name: Parsva Urdhva Padmasana in Sarvangasana
101.description:
Parsva Urdhva Padmasana in Sarvangasana
Parsva means flank, and this is the lateral-twist variation of Urdhva Padmasana in Sarvangasana (Images two-hundred-sixty-two–two-hundred-sixty-five).
Effects: No benefits listed.
101.technique: Begin the practice in Shoulderstand Pose. Cross the legs into Lotus Pose. Stretch the crossed legs vertically up to enter Upward Lotus Pose. Slowly lower the knees down while moving the hips. Twist the hips and spine laterally towards the left side. Support the left buttocks with the left hand. Come back to the center by lifting the hips higher. Drop the knees and hips down towards the floor. Take the hips and spine in a lateral side bend and stretch towards the right side. Support the right buttocks with the right hand. Return to the center. Release the legs and stretch them to return to Shoulderstand Pose. Continue into an arched-back variation. Lower the feet toward the floor above the head. Press the upper arms down into the mat. Broaden the collarbones and roll the shoulders underneath the back. Clasp the hands behind the back. Press the pinky fingers into the mat. Press down firmly through the heels. Draw the thighs toward one another. Reach the backs of the thighs toward the knees to lengthen the spine. Release the hands slowly. Lower the body one vertebra at a time back to the mat.

102.name: Uttana Padma Mayiirasana
102.description:
Uttana Padma Mayiirasana or Intense lotus peacock bridge.
The name is descriptive of the intense lotus peacock bridge pose, which is depicted in image two hundred sixty-seven.
Effects: Deep abdominal stretch, advanced extension.
102.technique: Lie on your back on the floor. Bend your knees toward your chest. Cross your right leg over your left leg. Bring your feet toward your hips to create a lotus position. Exhale and lift your hips. Support your hips with your hands. Walk your hands toward your upper back. Rest your weight on your shoulders. Extend your trunk and legs upward. Maintain the lotus position with your legs. Firm your abdominal muscles. Stretch your torso deeply. Hold the pose. Release your hands from your back. Slowly lower your torso and legs to the floor. Release the lotus position.

103.name: Pindasana in Sarvangasana
103.description:
Pindasana in Sarvangasana or Embryo in shoulderstand
This pose resembles an embryo in the womb.
Effects: Resembles embryo, tones spine through forward movement.
103.technique: Begin in Shoulderstand with hands supporting the back. Form Lotus Pose in Shoulderstand. Exhale and lower the knees toward the head. Slowly release the hands from the back. Wrap the arms around the legs. Clasp the hands or wrists around the legs. Draw the legs closer to the torso. Hold the pose. Return the hands to the back. Inhale and gently release the arms. Roll down onto the mat. Release the legs.

104.name: Parsva Pindasana in Sarvangasana
104.description:
Parsva Pindasana in Sarvangasana or Side embryo in shoulderstand
This pose is a side embryo variation performed while in a shoulderstand position.
Effects: Relieves chronic constipation, relieves stomach griping.
104.technique: Begin in Pindasana. Maintain a strong Sarvangasana foundation. Slowly turn the hips sideways. Lower both knees towards the floor. Hold the pose and breathe evenly. Return to Pindasana.

105.name: Jathara Parivartanasana
105.description:
Jathara Parivartanasana or Belly turning
The descriptive meaning of the name is Belly turning.
Effects: Reduces excess fat, eradicates sluggishness of liver and spleen, eradicates pancreas sluggishness.
105.technique: Lie flat on your back. Stretch your arms out to the sides at shoulder level. Bring your legs perpendicular to your torso. Keep your core strong. Exhale and lower both legs sideways to the floor. Ensure your shoulders remain grounded. Continue twisting the abdomen and chest. Bring your toes toward your hand. Inhale and gently bring the legs back to the center. Exhale out completely.

106.name: Urdhva Prasarita Padasana
106.description:
Urdhva Prasarita Padasana or Upward extended foot
The descriptive meaning of the name is upward extended foot.
Effects: Strengthens lumbar region, tones organs, reduces abdominal fat.
106.technique: Begin the practice lying down on your back. Stretch your legs keeping the toes flexed. Inhale and take your arms above your head. Stretch your arms out straight. Exhale, lengthen the neck. Tuck your chin lightly. Inhale to lift both legs to ninety degrees. Hold the legs for a few breaths. Exhale, lower your legs to sixty degrees. Lower your legs further to thirty degrees. Engage your lower abdominal muscles. Tuck your chin. Maintain the actions of the legs and the upper body. Firm your arms. Exhale as you swing your arms overhead. Rotate your upper arms from the inside out. Face your palms towards one another. Spread your fingers. Keep your shoulder blades down in the back. Lengthen your neck. Roll your front thighs in. Extend through the inner edges of your feet. Spread your toes. Pull your outer thighs down into the floor. To come out, take your hands back down by your sides. Bend your knees. Take your right arm overhead. Roll onto your right side. Push yourself up to a seated position.

107.name: Chakrasana
107.description:
Chakrasana or Wheel pose (rolling)
This pose involves rolling over the head from Halasana with hands placed by the ears into Downward Dog.
Effects: Blood circulates around spinal column, Tones abdominal organs and spine.
107.technique: Begin lying on your back. Bend your knees and bring your heels near your buttocks. Position your palms near your ears with your fingers pointing toward your shoulders. Press through your hands and feet. Lift your hips and chest off the mat. Roll from Halasana over your head. Finish in Downward Dog.

108.name: Supta Padangusthasana
108.description:
Supta Padangusthasana or Reclining big toe
This is the name of the pose.
Effects: Benefits sciatica and leg paralysis, removes hip stiffness.
108.technique: Lie down on your back. Extend both legs straight out. Inhale and bend your right knee toward your chest. Grip your right big toe with your right hand. Place your left hand on your left thigh to anchor it. Straighten your right leg toward the ceiling. Keep your left leg pressed firmly into the floor. On an exhalation, pull your chin toward your right knee. Inhale and return your head to the floor. Open your right leg out to the side toward the floor. Keep your left buttock grounded. Avoid lifting your left hip off the floor. Hold the posture. Release the big toe. Draw your right knee back to your chest. Straighten your right leg onto the floor. Repeat on the left side.

109.name: Atasana
109.description:
one hundred nine / Atasana
Dedicated to Visnu's couch.
Effects: Pelvic region benefits, tones hamstrings.
109.technique: Lie on your side. Catch your big toe. Stretch your leg up vertically.

110.name: Uttana Padasana
110.description:
Uttana Padasana or Extended foot
The descriptive meaning of the name is extended foot.
Effects: Expansion of chestwall, tones neck/back, expansion of chest wall, regulates thyroid activity.
110.technique: Lie down on your back. Arch your back. Rest the crown of your head on the floor. Lift your legs up. Lift your arms up. Extend your arms parallel to your thighs. Hold your legs and arms at a forty-five degree angle from the floor. Keep the crown of your head on the floor. Balance on your head and hips. Breathe slowly. Bring your arms down. Release your head. Lower your legs down to the floor. Relax completely.

111.name: Setu Bandhasana
111.description:
Setu Bandhasana or Bridge construction
The descriptive meaning of the name is Bridge construction.
Effects: Back extensor muscles grow powerful, adrenal glands bathed in blood, strengthens neck, tones entire spine, bathes glands in blood.
111.technique: Lie on your back. Bend your knees toward the ceiling. Place the soles of your feet flat on the mat. Keep your feet hip-width apart. Reach down with your fingertips to skim your heels. Press into the soles of your feet. Lift your pelvis away from the floor. Arch your trunk. Tuck your shoulders under one at a time. Broaden your chest. Press your upper arms down. Fold your arms across your chest. Keep your gaze toward the ceiling. Keep your head and neck still.

112.name: Bharadvajasana I
112.description:
Bharadvajasana I
The pose is dedicated to Bharadvaja.
Effects: Blessing for arthritis, works dorsal/lumbar spine, supplemental for stiff backs.
112.technique: Sit on the floor. Place your feet beside your right hip. Twist your trunk to the left. Place your right hand under your left knee. Clasp your right arm with your left hand from behind your back.

113.name: Bharadvajasana II
113.description:
Bharadvajasana II
This is the hundred and thirteenth pose in the sequence.
Effects: Knees and shoulders flexible, increases knee/shoulder flexibility, blessing for arthritic.
113.technique: Begin in Staff Pose. Extend your legs straight out in front of you. Bend your left leg and bring your left foot outside your left hip. The top of your left foot rests on the mat in a Hero Pose position. Bend your right knee. Bring your right foot across your lap to your left hip crease in a Half Lotus position. Release your right knee toward the floor. Inhale to lengthen your spine. Exhale and twist your upper body to the right. Reach back with your right hand. Catch your right foot from behind.

114.name: Marichyasana III
114.description:
Marichyasana three or Sitting lateral twist.
This is a sitting lateral twist performed with one knee bent up and the other leg straight.
Effects: Splitting backaches and lumbago disappear, liver and spleen toned, cures splitting backaches, tones liver and spleen.
114.technique: Bend one knee up. Keep the other leg straight. Twist your trunk ninety degrees. Wrap your arm around the bent knee. Clasp your hands behind your back.

115.name: Marichyasana IV
115.description:
Marichyasana IV
This pose is a seated twist, which includes one leg in half lotus and the opposite knee bent up, with the hands clasped behind the back.
Effects: Rejuvenates nerves around the navel, rejuvenates nerves at navel, calcium deposits in shoulders.
