115.technique: Begin seated in Dandasana. Extend both legs straight in front. Ground the sitting bones evenly. Lengthen the spine. Place one leg in half lotus. Bend the opposite knee. Bring the sole of the foot flat to the floor. Keep the foot close to the sitting bone. Inhale and lengthen the spine. Exhale and twist the torso towards the bent knee. Wrap the arm around the shin of the bent knee. Sweep the opposite arm around the back. Clasp the hands behind the back. Hold the pose for a few breaths. Release the bind. Straighten the bent leg.

116.name: Ardha Matsyendrasana I
116.description:
Ardha Matsyendrasana I or Half Lord of the Fishes pose
Dedicated to Matsyendra.
Effects: Range of movement intensified, Lower part of abdomen benefits, Prostate and bladder health, Intensified abdominal squeeze, prostate/bladder health.
116.technique: Bend the left knee. Sit on the left foot. Place the right foot outside the left thigh. Twist the trunk ninety degrees. Wrap the arm around the knee. Clasp the hands together.

117.name: Malasana I
117.description:
Malasana I or Garland pose I
The technique involves squatting, wrapping arms around bent legs and clasping behind, and resting the head on the floor.
Effects: Relieves backaches, Tones abdominal organs.
117.technique: Stand with feet hip distance apart. Squat. Lower your hips toward the floor. Bring your arms inside your bent legs. Wrap your arms around your bent legs. Clasp your hands behind your back. Rest your head on the floor.

118.name: Malasana II
118.description:
Malasana II or Garland pose II
The technique involves squatting, catching the back of the ankles, and resting the forehead on the toes.
Effects: Soothes back during menstrual periods, exercises abdominal organs, relieves menstrual back pain.
118.technique: Stand in Mountain Pose with feet and legs together. Spread the soles and toes of both feet. Bend your legs and keep your legs parallel. Press your heels into the floor. Maintain even weight on both feet. Once your knees are completely bent, spread your knees. Move your chest forward between your thighs. Squat down. Catch the back of your ankles. Rest your forehead on your toes.

119.name: Pasasana
119.description:
Pasasana or Noose pose
The technique involves squatting, twisting the trunk, wrapping the arm around both thighs, and clasping the hands.
Effects: Recommended for persons suffering from diabetes, strengthens ankles, reduces abdominal fat, recommended for diabetes.
119.technique: Bend your knees and squat. Tone your legs. Stretch your spine long. Twist your torso. Place your outer right armpit to your outer left knee. Eliminate the gap between your shoulder and knee. Bring your arm around both thighs. Clasp your hands behind your back. Continually push your right heel down into the floor. Stretch your spine up. Take your arm bones back. Twist more.

120.name: Ardha Matsyendrasana II
120.description:
Ardha Matsyendrasana Two Variation of One
The technique involves the right foot in half lotus at the root of the left thigh, twisting the trunk ninety degrees, and grasping the right ankle with the left hand from behind the back.
Effects: Backaches rapidly disappear, lumbago rapidly disappears, hip pain rapidly disappears, greater lateral twist, prevents prostate hypertrophy, prevents bladder hypertrophy.
120.technique: Bend the right leg back into Padmasana. Place the right foot into the left thigh crease. Extend the left leg forward. Twist the trunk ninety degrees. Reach the left arm behind the back. Grasp the right ankle with the left hand. Use a belt if necessary.

121.name: Ardha Matsyendrasana III
121.description:
Ardha Matsyendrasana Three
This is a challenging seated pose with a beautiful and releasing twist.
Effects: massages abdominal organs, exercises abdominal organs.
121.technique: Place the left foot in half lotus. Extend the right leg out. Place the right leg outside the left thigh. Sit tall and lengthen the spine. Inhale and extend the arms. Exhale and twist the trunk to the right. Take the left arm over the right thigh. Hold the right foot with the left hand. Press the right thigh into the trunk. Turn the head and neck to the right. Stay in the pose. Inhale and release the twist. Return to the starting position. This pose exercises and massages the abdominal organs.

122.name: Paripurna Matsyendrasana
122.description:
Paripurna Matsyendrasana or Complete Lord of the Fishes pose
The technique involves maximum lateral twist involving full wrap of arms around legs in lotus and twisted seat.
Effects: Fans gastric fire, destroys terrible diseases, rouses Kundalini.
122.technique: Sit in a lotus position. Wrap your arms completely around your legs. Achieve a twisted seat. Perform a maximum lateral twist.

123.name: Astavakrasana
123.description:
Astavakrasana
Dedicated to sage Astavakra, who was born crooked in eight places.
Effects: Strengthens wrists and arms, develops abdominal muscles.
123.technique: Enter an arm balance position. Interlock the legs sideways. Press the hands firmly into the floor. Engage the core muscles. Lower the trunk toward the floor. Bring the head parallel to the floor. Maintain the leg interlock. Hold the body in balance.

124.name: Eka Hasta Bhujasana
124.description:
Eka Hasta Bhujasana or Single hand-arm pose
The descriptive meaning of the name is single hand-arm pose.
Effects: Exercises abdominal organs, strengthens arms.
124.technique: Place the leg on the back of the upper arm. Bring the hands to the floor. Spread the fingers wide apart. Press the palms firmly into the floor. Draw the lower belly in. Lift the hips off the floor. Extend the opposite leg straight out. Balance the body on the palms. Hold the pose.

125.name: Dwi Hasta Bhujasana
125.description:
Dwi Hasta Bhujasana or Both hands-arms pose
This is a pose where both hands and arms are utilized to support the body.
Effects: Strengthens arms, core.
125.technique: Begin in Staff Pose. Bend your left knee. Push the left knee behind your shoulder. Repeat the action with your right knee. Place your palms firmly on the floor. Lift your buttocks off the floor. Push your palms on the floor. Balance on your hands. Focus on one point. Hold your core. Release your legs to come back. Place your buttocks on the floor. Relax.

126.name: Bhujapidasana
126.description:
Bhujapidasana or Arm pressure pose
This pose is known as the arm pressure pose.
Effects: Hands and wrists grow strong, Tones minor arm muscles, strengthens wrists and hands.
126.technique: Start in Uttanasana. Fold forward. Bend your knees. Plant your hands behind your feet. Tuck your shoulders behind your legs. Bring your feet together. Interlock your ankles. Balance your weight on your hands. Straighten your arms. Maintain your balance.

127.name: Mayurasana
127.description:
Mayurasana or Peacock pose
The pose is called Peacock pose.
Effects: Kills toxins like a peacock destroys snakes, beneficial for diabetes, kills toxins, improves digestive power, beneficial for diabetes.
127.technique: Kneel on the floor. Turn the palms to face the feet. Place the hands flat on the floor. Bring the elbows together. Rest the torso on the upper arms. Rest the diaphragm on the elbows. Extend the legs straight back. Tighten the glutes. Engage the core muscles. Shift the weight forward into the hands. Slowly lift the legs off the floor. Keep the body parallel to the floor. Hold the pose. Breathe slowly. To release, lower the legs down. Rest the knees on the floor.

128.name: Padma Mayurasana
128.description:
Padma Mayurasana or Lotus peacock
The technique is Mayurasana with legs in Padmasana.
Effects: Superior abdominal organ toning.
128.technique: Begin in Lotus Pose. Come onto your knees. Place your palms on the floor with fingers pointing toward your feet. Bend your elbows slightly. Press your forearms together. Lean forward. Rest your torso on your upper arms. Press your elbows into your belly below your navel. Rest your forehead on the ground. Shift your weight forward. Exhale and slowly raise your folded legs off the floor. Lift your knees. Extend your thighs. Lift your head. Gaze forward. Maintain balance. Inhale and lower your body back onto the floor.

129.name: Hamsasana
129.description:
Hamsasana or Swan pose
The technique involves positioning the body similar to Mayurasana, but with fingers pointing forward.
Effects: Tones abdominal region, stronger work for wrists and forearms.
129.technique: Begin on your hands and knees in Table Top Pose. Ensure your knees are hip-width apart. Place your palms on the mat. Spread your fingers wide. The fingers should point forward. Exhale and bend your elbows. Lower your torso. Rest your forehead between your palms. Roll your head so the crown rests on the mat. Tuck your elbows under your abdomen. Keep your elbows close together. Shift your weight forward. Engage your core muscles. Straighten your knees one by one. Keep your toes curled on the mat. Hold the pose. To exit, lower your knees to the mat. Release your arms and legs. Come to the Vajrasana pose. Take relaxed breaths.

130.name: Pincha Mayurasana
130.description:
Pincha Mayurasana or Peacock feather pose
The technique involves balancing on elbows and forearms and swinging legs up.
Effects: Develops muscles of shoulders and back, tones spine.
130.technique: Balance on your elbows. Balance on your forearms. Swing your legs up into the pose. Align your shoulders over your elbows. Press your forearms into the floor. Extend your legs straight up toward the ceiling. Engage your core muscles. Maintain a steady gaze.

131.name: Sayanasana
131.description:
Sayanasana or Repose posture
This posture is known as a position of rest or being asleep.
Effects: Advanced balance, extremely firm stability
131.technique: Begin the practice in Dolphin Pose. Walk the feet toward the elbows. Transition into Feathered Peacock Pose. Press the elbows down into the floor. Maintain stability on the elbows. Release the hands from the floor. Bring the palms up to the chin or cheeks. Balance the entire body in this inverted position. Hold the advanced balance firmly. Exit by returning the hands to the floor. Assume Chaturanga.

132.name: Adho Mukha Vrksasana
132.description:
Adho Mukha Vrksasana or Downward facing tree
The pose is known as the downward facing tree.
Effects: Harmonious development of body, strengthens shoulders, wrists.
132.technique: Align the body in Downward Facing Dog. Walk the toes close to your chest. Take a step back with one leg. Press the shoulders. Hop up completely. Straighten the legs up. Adjust the head position to look toward the room. Draw the lower ribs into the body. Lift the back of the pelvis vertically. Lift the legs vertically.

133.name: Kurmasana
133.description:
Kurmasana or Tortoise incarnation
This pose is known as the Tortoise incarnation.
Effects: Mind becomes calm and composed, prepares aspirant for Pratyahara, withdraws senses (Pratyahara), develops mental equanimity.
133.technique: Sit in Dandasana with your legs straight in front of you. Place your hands on the floor alongside your hips. Press your thighs into the floor. Flex your feet. Lift your chest. Bring your legs to the edges of the mat. Bend your knees. Bring your feet closer to your hips while keeping them flexed. Extend your chest and arms forward and down between your legs. Bend your legs even more. Put your right shoulder under your right knee. Put your left shoulder under your left knee. Stretch your arms out to the sides. Roll your thighs inward. Extend your inner heels. Push your inner heels down and forward to straighten your legs. Bring your chin and chest to the floor. Inhale to stretch your arms and chest out to your sides. Exhale to extend your spine farther forward.

134.name: Supta Kurmasana
134.description:
Supta Kurmasana or Sleeping tortoise
The name describes a sleeping tortoise.
Effects: Soothes nerves of brain, soothes brain nerves, provides extreme refreshment.
134.technique: Sit with your legs apart. Bring your arms below your thighs. Exhale and bring your chest and head toward the floor. Bring your shoulders under your knees. Slide your hands around behind your back. Clasp your hands together in a lock. Slowly take your legs over your head. Cross your ankles. Bring your forehead to the floor. Hold the pose.

135.name: Eka Pada Sirsasana
135.description:
Eka Pada Sirsasana or Single leg-behind-head
The technique involves placing the leg on the back of the neck and folding the palms at the chest.
Effects: Digestive power increases, strengthens neck and back.
135.technique: Sit up straight on the floor. Extend both legs straight in front of you. Bend one knee. Bring the sole of the foot toward the chest. Rotate the hip to bring the leg up. Place the leg on the back of the neck. Fold the palms at the chest. Keep the body straight.

136.name: Skandasana
136.description:
Skandasana or Skanda pose
Skanda is the name of the war god.
Effects: deeper abdominal contraction, spine exercise.
136.technique: Place the leg behind the neck. Bend the trunk forward. Hold the outstretched leg. Bring the chin to the knee. This sequence enables a deeper abdominal contraction. This also provides spine exercise.

137.name: Buddhasana
137.description:
Buddhasana or Enlightened pose
This is an enlightened pose.
Effects: Shoulder and neck flexibility, intense stretch.
137.technique: Place one leg behind the neck. Reach the opposite arm around the back. Clasp the ankle with the hand.

138.name: Kapilasana
138.description:
Kapilasana or Sage Kapila's pose
This pose is Sage Kapila's pose.
Effects: stretches the hips, hamstrings, glutes, psoas, strengthens the neck and lower back, tones the core, enhances flexibility and range of motion in the hips and back, improves mental clarity, reduces injury risk, improves posture, and boosts overall energy levels.
138.technique: Assume Buddhasana. Fold your body forward. Bring your chin toward your knee. This pose involves a forward fold. Combine the forward fold with the complexity of placing the leg behind the head.

139.name: Bhairavasana
139.description:
Bhairavasana
The name means Terrible aspect of Siva.
Effects: Supine hip and spine stretch.
139.technique: Begin by sitting in Staff Pose (Dandasana). Bend your right knee. Turn the right knee slightly out to the side. Lift your right leg. Place the right leg behind your neck. Extend the left leg straight on the floor. Hold the pose. This is a supine hip and spine stretch.

140.name: Kala Bhairavasana
140.description:
Kala Bhairavasana or Destroyer of universe pose
This intense arm balancer is named after Siva the destroyer.
Effects: Balances the body sideways on one palm, helps balance, strengthens the arm.
140.technique: Balance the body sideways on one palm. Place one leg behind the neck. This is an intense arm balance. Engage your core. Keep your lower leg straight.

141.name: Chakorasana
141.description:
Chakorasana
Bird feeding on moonbeams.
Effects: Develops powerful wrists, core compression.
141.technique: Begin in Dandasana. Transition into Eka Pada Sirsasana. Place one leg behind the neck. Ground your palms firmly. Lift your hips. Lift the extended leg up to sixty degrees. Maintain an arm balance on your palms. Keep the extended leg straight and active. Point the toes up towards the sky. Engage your core. Maintain a straight back. Distribute your weight evenly on your palms. Develop powerful wrists. Develop core compression.

142.name: Durvasasana
142.description:
Durvasasana or Irascible sage pose
The technique involves standing on one leg with the other leg placed behind the back of the neck.
Effects: Extreme hip flexibility, advanced standing balance.
142.technique: Stand up. Place one foot on the floor. Bring the other leg behind the back of the neck. Set the calf muscle and shin bone far behind the shoulder. Keep the neck super strong. Push the head back. Move the knee further back. Keep the standing leg nice and strong. Maintain integrity in the standing pose.

143.name: Ruchikasana
143.description:
Ruchikasana or Sage Richika's pose
This is pose number one hundred forty-three.
Effects: Tones muscular/nervous/circulatory systems, increases energy in chakras, intense forward stretch in standing balance.
143.technique: Begin in Door Pose. Fold forward from the hips. Bring your palms down to the floor. Perform an intense forward stretch. Maintain a standing balance.

144.name: Viranchyasana I
144.description:
Viranchyasana I
This pose is dedicated to Brahma.
Effects: strengthens back, strengthens neck.
144.technique: Assume a seated position. Place one leg in half lotus. Bring the other leg behind the neck. Clasp the hands behind the back. Hold the pose. Breathe steadily. Release the hands from the clasp. Bring the leg down from behind the neck. Release the half lotus position.

145.name: Viranchyasana II
145.description:
Viranchyasana Two
This pose combines Virasana with leg-behind-head complexity.
Effects: Shoulder movements freer.
145.technique: Assume Virasana with one leg. Take the other leg. Bring the other leg behind your neck. Hold this combination of poses. Perform the pose on the opposite side. This movement frees the shoulders.

146.name: Yoganidrasana
146.description:
Yoganidrasana or Yogic sleep
The descriptive meaning of the name is Yogic sleep.
Effects: Warms up the body rapidly, Best front bending pose, Exercises gonads, Tones all abdominal organs, Energy storage.
146.technique: Lie flat. Place both legs behind the neck. Lock the ankles together. Clasp your hands behind your back.

147.name: Dwi Pada Sirasana
147.description:
Dwi Pada Sirasana or Both feet-behind-head
This pose involves placing both feet behind the head.
Effects: Tightly contracts lungs, abdominal muscles, vertical balance.
147.technique: Sit on the ground. Find seated balance on your tailbone. Bend your right leg. Place your right foot behind your right shoulder. Bend your left leg. Place your left foot behind your left shoulder. Lock your ankles behind your neck. Place your hands on the floor next to your hips. Press into your hands for balance. Contract your lungs and abdominal muscles tightly. Lift your body off the floor. Establish vertical balance. Maintain this position. Gently lower your body to release the pose. Release your legs.

148.name: Tittibhasana
148.description:
Tittibhasana or Firefly pose.
The technique is an arm balance where both legs are over the upper arms, with the legs vertically up, shown in image three hundred ninety-five.
Effects: Powerful arm strength, core stability.
148.technique: Begin in a Standing Forward Bend with feet wide apart. Bend your knees slightly. Slide your right shoulder behind your right knee. Place your right hand through your legs to clasp your right calf. Repeat this action on the left side. Carefully lower your legs onto the backs of your upper arms. Tilt your chest forward. Inhale and lift your feet off the mat. Straighten your legs. Hold the arm balance. Maintain powerful arm strength. Engage your core stability. Exhale to release your feet to the floor.

149.name: Vasisthasana
149.description:
Vasisthasana or Sage Vasistha's pose
This pose is named after Sage Vasistha.
Effects: Strengthens wrists, tones lumbar and coccyx spine.
149.technique: Enter into a side plank balance. Engage the core muscles. Extend the top arm up. Gaze forward or toward the raised hand. Catch the big toe of the top foot. Pull the top arm and leg up vertically. Hold the final pose. Release the pose with control.

150.name: Kasyapasana
150.description:
Kasyapasana or Progenitor pose
The technique involves a side plank with the top foot in half lotus, catching the big toe from behind the back.
Effects: Relieves sacral stiffness, strengthens hands.
150.technique: Begin in a side plank position. Place the top foot into half lotus. Catch the big toe from behind the back. This relieves sacral stiffness. This strengthens the hands.

151.name: Visvamitrasana
151.description:
Visvamitrasana or Sage Visvamitra's pose
This pose is known as Sage Visvamitra's pose.
Effects: Strengthens hands, strengthens abdominal organs, thigh exercise.
151.technique: Balance on one hand. Balance on one foot. Place one leg over the same-side arm. Extend the other arm up vertically.

152.name: Bakasana
152.description:
Bakasana or Crane pose
It is an arm balance where the shins rest on the back of the upper arms and the arms are stretched straight.
Effects: Strengthens arms, abdominal organs.
152.technique: Place your palms down on the mat. Spread your fingers wide. Press every finger equally to the floor. Walk your toes forward onto your toes. Tuck your knees near your armpits. Squeeze your knees to your upper arms. Move your hips upward and forward. Lift your feet towards your buttocks. Balance on your hands. Stretch your arms straight. Keep your gaze fixed at a point. Stay strong. Exhale and drop your toes down. Place your heels on the mat. Come up to standing position.

153.name: Parsva Bakasana
153.description:
Parsva Bakasana or Side crane
This pose is technique number one hundred fifty-three.
Effects: Intestines grow stronger, develops lateral abdominal muscles, strengthens arms.
153.technique: Begin in Chair Pose with hands in Anjali Mudra. Exhale and twist your torso to the left. Plant your hands flat on the floor shoulder-width apart. Engage your shoulder girdle. Bend your elbows like Chaturanga arms. Stack both knees on the shelf of the opposite upper arm near the armpit. Lean forward into your hands. Lift your feet from the floor. Extend your legs straight back if possible. Maintain a strong core engagement. Keep your gaze forward. Release slowly back to a squatting position. Come to Downward Facing Dog. Rest in Child's Pose.

154.name: Urdhva Kukkutasana
154.description:
Urdhva Kukkutasana or Upward cock pose
The technique involves a lotus headstand transition to an arm balance on hands.
Effects: Spine stretched fully, intense full spinal stretch, core strength.
154.technique: Assume Lotus Pose. Enter Headstand Two. Transition from Headstand Two to an arm balance on the hands. Tighten the arms and shoulders. Extend the arms fully. Maintain balance on the hands. Move the torso up and down. Support the crossed legs with your arms. Hold the final pose.

155.name: Parsva Kukkutasana
155.description:
Parsva Kukkutasana or Side cock pose
The technique involves a lotus headstand, followed by a twist, resting the thigh on the opposite upper arm, and then lifting the body.
Effects: Lateral spinal twist, increased vital power.
155.technique: Begin in Lotus headstand. Perform a twist. Rest the thigh on the opposite upper arm. Lift the body.

156.name: Galavasana
156.description:
Galavasana or Sage Galava's pose
This pose is named after Sage Galava.
Effects: Combined effects of Sirsasana, Padmasana, and Paschimottanasana, combined effects of headstand and lotus forward fold.
156.technique: Perform a Lotus Headstand. Cross your shins. Rest the crossed shins on one upper arm. Lift the body.

157.name: Eka Pada Galavasana
157.description:
Eka Pada Galavasana or One-leg Galava
The technique involves balancing on hands with one leg in a half lotus position on the arms, and the other leg straight back in the air.
Effects: Strengthens wrists, massages abdominal organs.
157.technique: Begin the practice in Half Chair Pose. Stay in Half Chair Pose for a few breaths. Exhale and lean forward to bring your hands to the floor. Place your hands on the floor in Standing Figure Four Pose Hands Floor. Place your elbows by the front ankle and bent knee. Rest your shins on the back of your arms. Engage your chest and abdomen. Press your palms down into the floor. Bend your elbows. Lean forward. Support your back leg knee. Lift your back foot. Balance on your hands. Extend one leg straight back in the air.

158.name: Dwi Pada Koundinyasana
158.note: Typo in book: final pose is 438, not 458
158.description:
Dwi Pada Koundinyasana or Sage Koundinya's pose
The technique involves balancing on the hands with the legs together sideways and parallel to the floor on one arm.
Effects: Colon moves properly, Aids colon elimination, improves spinal elasticity.
158.technique: Place your hands on the mat to the left side of your hips. Your fingers point forward. Your hands are shoulder-width apart. Shift your weight onto your hands. Lean forward. Engage your core muscles. Place your knees on your upper arms. Lift your feet off the mat. Balance on your hands. Stretch your legs out sideways. Keep your legs parallel to the floor. Maintain the arm balance. Focus your gaze forward. Slowly bend your legs. Relax your body.

159.name: Eka Pada Koundinyasana I
159.description:
Eka Pada Koundinyasana I or One-leg Koundinya I
The technique involves balancing on hands with one leg forward on an arm and the other leg back in the air.
Effects: Rejuvenates the spine, strengthens the spine.
159.technique: Begin seated in Garland Pose. Lift the heels off the floor. Turn toward the right side. Come to Side Crow Pose. Inhale to extend the left leg sideways as far as possible. Exhale to extend the right leg behind you. Balance on your hands. Place one leg forward on your arm. Hold the other leg back in the air. Find balance. Return the right knee on top of the left. Bend the left leg. Lower the feet back down to the floor. Change sides.

160.name: Eka Pada Koundinyasana II
160.description:
Eka Pada Koundinyasana II or One-leg Koundinya II
The technique involves balancing on the hands with one leg positioned sideways across an arm and the other leg extended backward.
Effects: Strenuous arm and thigh balancer.
160.technique: Place your hands on the floor. Balance your weight on your hands. Extend one leg sideways across one arm. Extend the other leg backward. Maintain this arm balance position. Engage your arm muscles strongly. Tighten your thigh muscles. Keep your breath steady.

161.name: Eka Pada Bakasana I
161.description:
Eka Pada Bakasana I or One-leg crane I
The technique involves having one shin on the arm and the other leg straight back in the air parallel to the floor.
Effects: Abdominal organs contracted on one side, deep unilateral core contraction, exercises organs.
161.technique: Begin in Downward-Facing Dog. Bend your elbows slightly. Place one shin on the corresponding arm. Squeeze the knee strongly against the arm. Lean your upper body forward. Push forward through your back foot. Lift the back foot off the ground. Extend the other leg straight back in the air. Keep the extended leg parallel to the floor. Lift your hips. Your hands bear the full weight. Keep your palms grounded. Hold this position.

162.name: Eka Pada Bakasana II
162.description:
Eka Pada Bakasana II or One-leg crane II
The body acts as a weight-lifting apparatus.
Effects: Strengthens core, hands, chest, and back.
162.technique: Begin in Garland Pose with hands grounded. Inhale, lean forward onto your toes. Shift your weight to your hands. Place one knee on the same side upper arm. Lift your feet from the floor. Extend the opposite leg straight forward parallel to the floor. Press the earth away through your palms. Straighten your arms as much as possible. Hug your legs into your arms. Engage your abdominal muscles. Gaze slightly forward to lengthen the neck and spine.

163.name: Yogadandasana
163.description:
Yogadandasana or Staff of a Yogin
The technique involves sitting with one foot under the armpit like a crutch.
Effects: Restful pose, rests spine and relaxes body, ankle elasticity.
163.technique: Begin in Staff Pose. Stretch your legs together in front. Roll your shoulders back and down. Place your palms by the side of your hips. Sit tall with your back erect. Ground your hip bones. Bend your knees. Catch hold of your right foot. Raise the leg close to your body. Bend your trunk slightly forward while exhaling. Extend your right arm up. Place your right foot under your right armpit. Use your left hand to assist the alignment. Rest your spine. Relax your body. Increase your ankle elasticity.

164.name: Supta Bhekasana
164.description:
Supta Bhekasana or Reclining frog
This is pose number one hundred sixty-four.
Effects: Internal derangement of knee joints relieved, tones spine, improves knee/ankle circulation, cures flat feet.
164.technique: Sit in Virasana. Keep your shins and knees on the floor. Allow your sitting bones to descend between the heels. Press your sitting bones down. Lift the front of your hips. Move your lumbar spine inward. Exhale and arch back to rest on your elbows. Extend your spine back. Press your buttocks forward. Lower your forearms to the floor. Walk your elbows in. Bring the crown of your head to the floor. Hold your feet with your hands.

165.name: Mulabhandasana
165.description:
Mulabhandasana or Root lock.
The descriptive meaning of the name is Root lock.
Effects: Controls excessive sexual desire, controls sexual desire, sublimates energy, stills the mind.
165.technique: Begin by aligning to Bound Angle Pose. Gradually bring the feet near the groins. Slowly tilt the calf muscles outwards with assistance from the hands. Slowly lift the hips off the floor. Place the arms on the floor as support. Place the feet so the soles and heels touch each other. Rest the hips and be seated. Turn the feet by grasping the toes. Point the toes straight downwards. Point the heels upwards. Place the hands near the groins. Keep the spine alert. Exhale completely. Tighten the anus for the root lock. Pull the abdomen in for the abdominal lock. Lock the chin to the neck for the chin lock. Keep the perineum tight. Stay with breath retention. Release the root lock first. Release the abdominal lock next. Release the chin lock last. Inhale after the chin lock release. Release the foot alignment. Release the legs gradually.

166.name: Vamadevasana I
166.description:
Vamadevasana I
This pose is dedicated to sage Vamadeva/Siva.
Effects: Cures leg stiffness, keeps genital organs healthy.
166.technique: Begin in a seated posture. Place one leg in Mulabandhasana. Place the other leg in Padmasana. Clasp the corresponding foot's toe. Maintain the position for several breaths. Release the pose gently. Repeat on the opposite side.

167.name: Vamadevasana II
167.description:
Vamadevasana Two
The technique involves one leg in Bhekasana and the other in Padmasana, then joining the soles.
Effects: Relieves leg pain and stiffness, improves digestion.
167.technique: Assume Bhekasana with one leg. Assume Padmasana with the other leg. Join the soles of the feet. This completes the pose.

168.name: Kandasana
168.description:
Kandasana or Bulbous knot pose
The technique involves bringing the feet up and placing the heels and outer sides of the feet against the navel and chest.
Effects: Restores sexual energy, stimulates hypogastric plexus.
168.technique: Bring feet up. Place heels and outer sides of feet against the navel. Place heels and outer sides of feet against the chest.

169.name: Hanumanasana
169.description:
Hanumanasana or Monkey chief
This pose is described as performing splits with the legs spread laterally, followed by a Namaste.
Effects: Recommended for runners, sprinters, cures sciatica, tones leg muscles, recommended for runners.
169.technique: Spread your legs laterally into splits. Square your hips. Extend your spine. Raise your hands above your head. Bring your hands together in Namaste position. Hold the pose. Release the pose.

170.name: Samakonasana
170.description:
170 / Samakonasana
Sama means the same, like, even or straight. Kona means an angle and a point of a compass. In this asana the split is performed with the legs spread apart sideways, and the hands are folded in front of the chest. It is harder to perform than Hanumanasana. (Image 475.) Both the legs and the pelvic region of the body are in one straight line.

Technique

Stand in Tadasana (Image 1), rest the hands on the hips and spread the legs apart sideways to your capacity. (Image 29)

Place the palms on the floor (Image 30) and with an exhalation stretch the legs further and further until you sit on the floor with both legs spread sideways in a straight line. The entire back of the legs, especially the back of the knees, should rest on the floor.

Join the palms in front of the chest (Image 477) and stay in the pose for a few seconds.

Place the palms on the floor, raise the hips and bring the legs closer and closer to each other until you stand up again in Uttanasana. (Image 47.) Then stand in Tadasana (Image 1) and relax.

Effects: In this pose the hip joints are exercised and the legs are made to move freely in all directions. The spine is stretched and any defect in the lower part of the spine is cured. The pose, like Hanumanasana (Image 475), tones the leg muscles and makes the legs shapely. It prevents the development of hernia and relieves sciatic pains. It helps the blood to circulate in the pelvic region and genital organs and keeps them healthy.
170.technique: Be seated on the yoga mat. Keep your legs straight and extended in front of you. Slowly inhale and lengthen your spine. Keep your head to buttocks in one line. Engage your core. As you exhale, split your legs wide apart. Exhale and bend forward from your hips slowly. Lower your upper body until it is parallel to the ground. Keep your legs straight with a very slight bend at the knees. Do not hunch your back. Keep your spine straight. Gaze forward.

171.name: Supta Trivikramasana
171.description:
Supta Trivikramasana or Vishnu's stride (reclining)
The technique involves lying flat, pulling one leg down behind the head, and touching the big toe to the floor.
Effects: Stills the mind, fully stretches legs, cures hernia.
171.technique: Begin the practice from a seated pose, Dandasana. Press the heels firmly. Point the toes downwards. Lie back on the floor. Inhale and raise the right leg to ninety degrees. Hold the big toe with your right hand. Push the left thigh down with your left hand. Slowly pull the right leg down behind your head. Place the big toe to the floor. Release the pose slowly. Repeat the actions with the left leg.

172.name: Urdhva Dhanurasana I
172.description:
Urdhva Dhanurasana I or Upward bow (wheel).
The technique involves an arched back supported on palms and soles.
Effects: Strengthens back/limbs, expands chest, tones spine.
172.technique: Lie on your back on the floor. Place your hands flat on the mat either side of your head. Point your fingers toward your shoulders. Point your elbows up. Press your feet into the ground. Engage your legs and glutes. Press the shoulders down into the floor. Inhale and press into your hands. Lift your body up. Straighten your arms as much as possible. Maintain steady breathing. Focus on expanding your chest. Open your heart. Hold the pose for a few breaths. Exhale and look up to the ceiling. Lower your body back to the floor. Tuck your chin to your chest.

172a.name: Urdhva Dhanurasana II
172a.description:
Urdhva Dhanurasana II or Upward bow (wheel)
The pose is performed by lying flat with an arched back supported on palms and soles.
Effects: Strengthens back/limbs, expands chest, tones spine.
172a.technique: Lie flat. Place your hands beside your ears with your fingers pointing toward your shoulders. Root yourself through your feet and hands. Lift your body up off the floor. Keep your feet and knees hip width apart. Press your knees over your heels so your shins remain vertical. Draw your outer shins inward toward each other. Draw your triceps inward toward each other. Take your shoulder blades deeply into your back. Lift your shoulder blades away from your hands toward the ceiling. Press your chest toward the wall it faces. Walk your hands and feet towards each other to capacity.

173.name: Viparita Chakrasana in Urdhva Dhanurasana
173.description:
Viparita Chakrasana in Urdhva Dhanurasana or Reversed wheel
The technique involves a reverse somersault from Urdhva Dhanurasana.
Effects: Soothing effect on the head, advanced backbend, tones entire spine, energy/lightness.
173.technique: Lie down on your back. Bend your knees. Place your heels close to your buttocks. Place your palms near your ears. Point your fingers toward your shoulders. Press your feet and hands into the floor. Inhale to lift your hips. Straighten your arms and legs to enter Urdhva Dhanurasana. Hold the full wheel pose. Perform a reverse somersault movement from Urdhva Dhanurasana. Swing your leg up and back. Swing your body down. Lower your legs to the floor. Stand in Tadasana. Relax your body.

174.name: Eka Pada Urdhva Dhanurasana
174.description: Eka Pada Urdhva Dhanurasana or One-leg wheel.
174.technique: Lie flat on your back. Bend your knees. Place your feet flat on the floor. Keep your feet hip-width apart. Place your hands beside your head. Keep your palms wide. Press through your feet. Lift your hips toward the ceiling. Push through your hands. Lift your chest. Enter Wheel Pose (Urdhva Dhanurasana). Center one leg for stability. Mindfully lift the other leg. Draw the knee to the chest. Straighten the leg toward the ceiling. Contract the thigh muscle. Reach through the ball of the raised foot. Maintain balance on one hand and one foot.

175.name: Kapotanasana
175.description:
Kapotanasana or Dove pose
Kneel, arch back, catch heels, rest crown of head on soles.
Effects: Masses heart gently, tones spine, heart massage, healthy genital organs.
175.technique: Kneel down. Face your back to a wall. Walk your hands down the wall towards your feet. Bend your back into an arch. Catch your heels with your hands. Rest the crown of your head on the soles of your feet.

176.name: Laghuvajrasana
176.description:
Laghuvajrasana or Little thunderbolt
The technique involves kneeling, arching the back until the head rests on the feet, and placing the hands on the knees.
Effects: Tones spinal nerves, tones spinal nerves and coccyx, relieves disc displacement.
176.technique: Kneel on the floor. Inhale to lift the torso. Extend the spine upward. Begin to arch the back deeply. Keep the thighs and glutes engaged. Lower the head toward the feet. Rest the crown of the head on the soles or near the heels. Place the hands on the knees. Alternatively, place the hands on the feet or ankles for support. Lift the chest. Push the hips forward. Hold the posture. Exhale to slowly come up.

177.name: Dwi Pada Viprarita Dandasana
177.description:
Dwi Pada Viprarita Dandasana
This posture is a two-leg inverted staff.
Effects: Soothing effect on mind, relieves coccyx pain.
177.technique: Start in an arched bridge position. Bend your elbows. Bring your head near the floor. Support the crown of your head with your inner palms. Interlock your fingers behind your head for stability.

178.name: Eka Pada Viprarita Dandasana I
178.description:
Eka Pada Viprarita Dandasana I
Lift one leg vertically.
Effects: Intense spinal toning, chest expansion.
178.technique: Keep your shoulders strong. Bend your back to capacity. Keep your hips aligned. Lift one leg vertically. Stretch from the thorax. Use the neck efficiently. Open the throat chakra. Maintain all aspects of Viparita Dandasana. Lift the back ribs strongly upward. Extend the lifted leg. Balance the body. Quiet the mind.

179.name: Eka Pada Viprarita Dandasana II
179.description:
Eka Pada Viprarita Dandasana II or One-leg inverted staff II
Walk feet to head, catch one ankle, lift other leg.
Effects: Strenuous abdominal and spinal exercise.
179.technique: Start in Viparita Dandasana. Keep your shoulders strong. Bend your back to capacity. Walk your feet closer to your head. Catch one ankle with your hand. Lift your other leg up towards the ceiling. Maintain balance in the pose. Align your hips. Ensure your back ribs lift upward. Extend the lifted leg fully. Hold the pose for several breaths. Quiet your mind. Release the pose carefully.

180.name: Chakra Bandhasana
180.description:
Chakra Bandhasana or Nerve-centre bound pose.
This pose is known as the nerve-centre bound pose.
Effects: Stimulates all seven chakras, benefits adrenals, benefits kidneys.
180.technique: Begin in inverted staff pose. Walk your feet slowly toward your head. Bring the heels closer to your palms and fingers. Reach back with one hand. Grasp your ankle firmly. Repeat with the other hand. Adjust the grip to find stability. Press your ankles against your hands. Lift your chest. Allow your spine to arch deeply.

181.name: Mandalasana
181.description:
Mandalasana Wheel/Orbit
The technique involves circling the legs three hundred sixty degrees around the stationary head in a headstand.
Effects: Promotes longevity, keeps spine in trim.
181.technique: Enter headstand. Stabilize the head in a stationary position. Circle the legs 360 degrees around the head. Maintain the circle motion.

182.name: Vrschikasana I
182.description:
Vrschikasana I or Forearm scorpion
The technique involves a Pincha Mayurasana transition, where the heels move towards the head.
Effects: Stamps out pride/anger, tones spine, vigorous health.
182.technique: Press your inner wrists down. Lift your shoulders. Press your wrists down. Lift your collar bones up. Lift the space between your collar bones up. Slide your sternum bone and chin towards the wall. As you slide your sternum towards the wall, lift the back of your pelvis upwards. Move your tailbone towards your inner groins. Move your inner groins towards your tail bone. Lift your legs away from your spine. Kick both feet up to the wall into Pincha Mayurasana. Bend both knees. Bring your heels towards your head.

183.name: Vrschikasana II
183.description:
Vrschikasana II or Handstand Scorpion
This technique is described as a handstand balance where the heels reach towards the head.
Effects: Kicking head seeks to develop humility, subjugation of ego, tremendous wrist strength, eradicates ego.
183.technique: Find balance in a handstand position. Engage your entire body. Draw your ribs toward your abdomen. Maintain a fixed gaze between your palms. Once balanced, move your heels toward your head. Kicking the head develops humility. This action requires tremendous wrist strength.

184.name: Eka Pada Rajakapotasana I
184.description:
Eka Pada Rajakapotasana I or King pigeon I
One leg is forward bent, the other is back, and the foot is caught over the head.
Effects: rejuvenates lumbar, dorsal spine.
184.technique: Begin in Half Pigeon Pose. Fold one leg in front with the heel near the perineum. Extend the other leg straight behind you. Sit up tall. Lengthen your spine. Roll your shoulders back. Open your chest. Bend the back leg at the knee. Raise the lower back leg. Bring the foot toward your body. Use the same side hand to hook the foot in the elbow. Keep the opposite arm straight on the side. Press the buttock forward. Pull the heel away from the buttock. Lift the chest well. Press the shin bone toward the wall behind you.

185.name: Valakhilyasana
185.description:
Valakhilyasana or Thumb-sized spirits pose
This pose is a continuation of King Pigeon one with the rear leg flat on the floor.
Effects: Disorders of urinary system rectified, helps urinary system.
185.technique: Begin in Half Pigeon Pose. Extend the left leg back flat on the floor. Bring the right foot towards the body. Extend the hands behind you. Interlock the fingers on the raised leg. Sit tall with a long spine. Roll the shoulders back to open the chest. Keep the hips square and facing forward. Maintain balance and equilibrium in the posture.

186.name: Eka Pada Rajakapotasana II
186.description:
Eka Pada Rajakapotasana II or King pigeon II
One leg is in Marichyasana style, the other is back, and the foot is caught.
Effects: Rejuvenates nerves at navel, tones liver and spleen.
186.technique: Begin in a low lunge position. Place the right leg bent in front. Keep the right knee over the ankle. Extend the left leg behind you. Rest the left knee on the floor. Inhale and lift the torso upward. Prepare for a backbend. Raise the left lower leg. Bring the left foot within reach. Reach back with the left arm. Grasp the left foot. Keep the chest lifted. Relax the shoulders. Push the hips gently downward. Push the torso gently upward. To release, bring the head back to the center. Release the hands one after the other. Lower the back leg to the ground. Tuck the back toes under. Lift the hips. Align the body in Adho Mukha Svanasana.

187.name: Eka Pada Rajakapotasana III
187.description:
Eka Pada Rajakapotasana three or King pigeon three
This pose involves one leg in Virasana style and the other leg back, catching the foot.
Effects: Rejuvenates spine, strengthens thighs, strengthens ankles.
187.technique: Begin in Ardha Kapotasana, or Half Pigeon Pose. Fold the left leg in front. Extend the right leg back. Lengthen the spine and the hips. Inhale and lift the torso. Draw the shoulder blades down and in. Open your heart forward. Bend the right knee slowly and mindfully. Draw the right foot toward your head. Hold the right ankle with your right hand. Gently twist right. Inhale again and backbend the torso. Bring the chest out and shoulders back. Hold the foot. Twist the shoulders. Reach the left hand back if possible. Hold the foot with both hands if comfortable. Flex the quadriceps and glute muscles. Engage your shoulders and abdomen for support.

188.name: Eka Pada Rajakapotasana IV
188.description:
Eka Pada Rajakapotasana Four or King pigeon Four
This pose is done from Hanumanasana splits by bending the back leg and catching the foot over the head.
Effects: Deepest extension, vitalizes thyroids and adrenals.
188.technique: Begin in Hanumanasana splits. Extend one leg forward and one leg back. Square the hips. Lengthen the spine. Bend the back knee. Draw the back foot toward the head. Catch the back foot over the head. Maintain the deepest extension. This pose vitalizes the thyroids. This pose also vitalizes the adrenals.

189.name: Bhujangasana II
189.description:
Bhujangasana II or intensified cobra
This pose is an intensified cobra where the knee-caps are caught from a stomach backbend.
Effects: benefits pubic region, vitality.
189.technique: Lie on your belly with your legs hip-distance apart. Press the tops of your feet down to activate your quadriceps. Rotate your inner thighs toward the ceiling. Place your hands beside your ribs with bent elbows. Inhale and peel your chest away from the floor. Keep your shoulders away from your ears. Extend your spine into a backbend. Catch your knee-caps from the stomach. This intensifies the cobra pose. Keep your buttocks relaxed to protect your lower back. Look straight ahead or slightly down to keep your neck long. Release the pose on an exhale.

190.name: Rajakapotanasana
190.description:
Rajakapotanasana or Full King Pigeon
This pose involves arching the head to the soles and catching both knee-caps.
Effects: Recommended for controlling sexual desire, lumbar and dorsal stretch, increases vitality, controls sex desire.
190.technique: Start in a comfortable seated pigeon pose. Keep your front leg folded. Your front knee should point forward. Your front ankle should extend. Bring your back knee in line with your hips. Bend your back leg at the knee. Point the toes up towards the ceiling. Reach back with your arms. Arch your head toward your soles. Catch both kneecaps with your hands. Extend your spine with a slight backbend. Lift your chest upward. Engage your abdominal muscles. Breathe deeply into the pose. Exit the pose mindfully.

191.name: Padangustha Dhanurasana
191.description:
Padangustha Dhanurasana or Big toe bow
This is an intense Dhanurasana pose where you catch the big toes and pull the heels to the head.
Effects: Shoulder-blades well stretched, blood circulates properly in navel, passive/still mind.
191.technique: Lie flat on the stomach in a prone position. Bend both knees. Bring the heels close to the buttocks. Reach back and catch the big toes. Lift the head and chest from the floor. Use the backward movement of the legs to assist the lift. Pull the heels toward the head. Keep the knees aligned with the hips. Stretch the shoulder blades. Hold the pose. Release the pose and return to the starting position.

192.name: Gherandasana I
192.description:
Gherandasana I
The pose is dedicated to sage Gheranda.
Effects: Combined leg work, tones spinal column.
192.technique: Lie prone on the floor. Bend one leg into Bhekasana. Reach back and grab the foot of the bent leg. Bring the bent foot toward the hip. Lie the thigh of the bent leg on the ground. Keep the pubic bone pressing on the ground. Inhale and lift the head and chest. Bring the other leg up into Padangustha Dhanurasana. Reach back with the corresponding arm. Grab the big toe of the lifted leg. Lift the foot and arms up as much as possible. Keep breathing continuously. The combined leg work tones the spinal column.

193.name: Gherandasana II
193.description:
Gherandasana II
This is a pose with one leg in Baddha Padmasana and the other in Padangustha Dhanurasana, which can be seen in image five hundred sixty-four and five hundred sixty-five.
Effects: Corrects flat feet, relieves calcaneal spurs, relieves rheumatism.
193.technique: Lie on your abdomen. Fold the left leg into half lotus. Bring the left foot into the right hip crease. Bind the left hand behind the back to grasp the left big toe. This is Baddha Padmasana preparation for one leg. Bend the right knee. Raise the right thigh off the floor. Reach the right hand back. Grasp the right big toe with the right hand. Lift the head and chest off the floor. Lift the right knee and thigh off the floor. Pull the right leg back to deepen the spinal arch. Hold the posture. Release the right big toe. Release the left big toe. Unfold the legs.

194.name: Kapinjalasana
194.description:
Kapinjalasana or Partridge pose
It is a combination of Vasisthasana and Padangustha Dhanurasana, which is illustrated in image five hundred sixty-seven.
Effects: Wrists strengthened, vertebrae benefit, expanded chest.
194.technique: Begin in Vasisthasana or Side Plank Pose. Hold the pose for six breaths. Engage your core muscles. Gently bring your top foot behind you. Rest the toes on the floor. Allow your hips and shoulders to turn upward. Bend the top leg at the knee. Kick the top leg back. Grab the top foot with your top hand. Adjust your balance. Maintain a long, straight bottom leg. Keep your bottom hand grounded. Lift your hips away from the floor. Open your chest to the side. Turn your head to align with your shoulders. Stay in the pose for a few breaths. Release the foot. Return to Side Plank Pose.

195.name: Sirsa Padasana
195.description:
Sirsa Padasana
Arch from headstand, heels to neck, catch toes.
Effects: Nerves do not degenerate, copious blood supply to spine, nerves do not degenerate.
195.technique: Support your forearms on the floor. Place your elbows shoulder-width apart. Place the crown of your head gently on the floor. Raise your hips. Walk your feet towards your torso. Extend your legs into Sirsasana. Slowly bend your legs. Take your feet back towards your head. Arch your body from the headstand position. Bring your heels toward your neck. Catch your toes.

196.name: Ganda Bherundasana
196.description:
Ganda Bherundasana or Formidable side face.
Balance on chin/neck, feet to floor in front of head.
Effects: Improved vitality, rejuvenates pelvic plexuses, rejuvenates pharyngeal plexuses, vital power.
196.technique: Begin in Downward Facing Dog Pose. Transition forward to Four Limbed Pose. Lie down in a prone position. Place your chin on the floor. Inhale. Place palms under the hips. Thumbs should touch. Palms should face down. Roll onto your shoulders. Inhale. Pivot forward with your back strength. Send your legs up high towards the ceiling. Point your toes to the ceiling. Walk your legs towards your face. Lift your hips high. Straighten one leg at the back. Use core and back strength. Kick the bent leg up. Reach up high with both legs simultaneously. Keep your knees forward in the backbend. Keep breathing naturally. Release your hands. Place your hands close to your chest.

197.name: Viparita Salabhasana
197.description:
Viparita Salabhasana or Inverted locust
This is a chin balance with the feet to the floor beyond the head in the style of Halasana (Image five hundred eighty-four).
Effects: Awaken Kundalini, releases ego.
197.technique: Begin in a prone position. Bring your chin to center. Place your hands by your side body. Walk your palms underneath you. Position your palms to the top part of your thighs. Face your palms down. Rock your hips side to side. Ensure your palms are close together. Press down into your palms. Lift your hips upward. Bring your feet to the floor beyond your head. Balance on your chin. Keep your legs engaged. Press the tops of your feet down. Release your shoulders away from your ears. Draw your shoulder blades toward your spine. Maintain a steady breath.

198.name: Tiriang Mukhottanasana
198.description:
Tiriang Mukhottanasana or Upside down face stretch
This pose is achieved by catching the shins from a standing backbend and is depicted in Image five hundred eighty-six.
Effects: Strengthens legs, vitalizes spine, vitalizes organs.
198.technique: Begin standing tall in Mountain Pose Namaste. Activate your core. Lift your ribs. Gently send your pelvis forward. Arch your back slightly. Look up. Consciously engage your back muscles. Slowly let gravity open your spine. Reach the hands down towards the ankles. Grab the ankles firmly. Let your pelvis move forward.

199.name: Natarajasana
199.description:
Natarajasana or Lord of the Dance
This pose is named after Lord Siva.
Effects: Poise and graceful carriage, tones legs, expands chest.
199.technique: Stand on one leg. Catch the big toe of the lifted foot. Externally rotate the hip joint. Spin the hip all the way around. Start to arch the back. Externally rotate the shoulder. Flip the shoulder around. Hold on to the top of the foot. Extend the opposite arm forward. Reach back with the kicking leg. Pull forward with the arms. Deepen the back bend.

200.name: Mrtasana
200.description:
Savasana or Corpse pose
The technique involves motionless conscious relaxation with energy flow from the back of the head to the heels.
Effects: Antidote to stresses of modern civilisation, removes fatigue, antidote for modern stress, invigorates body and mind.
200.technique: Sit on a level floor with a blanket spread beneath the body. Draw a straight line on the blanket to ensure accurate physical alignment. Sit on the center of this line with the knees drawn up and the feet placed together. Lower the back vertebra by vertebra along the line until the entire spine rests on the floor. Lift the hips and use the hands to move the flesh of the buttocks away from the waist. Extend the legs fully one by one until the heels and knees are joined. Align the heels, knees, crotch, coccyx, spinal column, and the base of the skull on the straight line. Adjust the front of the body so the bridge of the nose, chin, sternum, navel, and pubis are in a single vertical plane. Check that the ears, outer corners of the eyes, and the jawbone are parallel to the floor. Stretch the back of the neck centrally and pin the inner points of the shoulder blades to the floor. Roll the skin of the upper chest from the collarbones toward the shoulder blades to broaden the chest. Rest the center of the sacrum on the floor to allow the buttocks to relax evenly. Let the feet fall outwards evenly so the big toes feel weightless. Place the hands fifteen to twenty degrees away from the body with the palms facing upwards. Bend the arms at the elbows to touch the shoulder tops before extending the triceps toward the feet. Lower the forearms and extend the hands from the wrists to the knuckles with passive fingers. Relax the muscles of the back from the trunk to the neck and the front of the body from the pubis to the throat. Close the eyelids gently and move the upper lids toward the inner corners of the eyes. Release any tightness in the forehead by slightly raising the eyebrows. Keep the root of the tongue passive and resting on the lower palate. Soften the skin of the temples, cheekbones, and the lower jaw to quieten the brain. Exhale softly and deeply while ensuring the breath flows evenly through both nostrils. Keep the head straight and parallel to the ceiling to remain anchored in the present moment. Observe the internal silence and keep the senses of knowledge passive and receptive. Maintain this state of complete physical and mental stillness for ten to fifteen minutes. Remain as a silent observer until normal activity returns to the brain. Open the eyes slowly and gently without focusing them immediately. Bend the knees and turn the head and body to one side. Stay in this side lying position for one or two minutes before repeating on the other side. Rise slowly to a seated position to avoid strain or heaviness in the head.

201.name: Uddiyana Bandha
201.description:
Uddiyana Bandha
It is said to be the lion that kills the elephant named death.
Effects: The practitioner becomes young again, it exercises the diaphragm, prana is forced to fly up through the sushumna nadi.
201.technique: Stand in the mountain pose with the feet parallel. Spread the legs about one foot apart. Stoop the torso slightly forward and bend both knees. Spread the fingers wide. Grip the middle of the thighs firmly with the hands. Bend the arms slightly at the elbows. Lower the chin as far down as possible to form the chin lock (Jalandhara Bandha). Inhale deeply through the nose. Exhale quickly so the air is expelled from the lungs in a single rush. Hold the breath without allowing any inhalation. Pull the whole abdominal region back towards the spine. Lift the abdominal muscles upwards toward the diaphragm. Keep the chest broad without hollowing it. Raise the lumbar and dorsal spine forwards and upwards. Squeeze the abdominal organs towards the back of the body. Press the organs firmly against the spine. Lift the hands from the thighs while maintaining the abdominal grip. Rest the hands higher on the pelvic rim. Press the hands into the pelvic rim to create a firmer contraction. Straighten the back while keeping the abdominal grip tight. Keep the chin lowered in the chin lock (Jalandhara Bandha). Hold the grip for ten to fifteen seconds. Avoid holding the breath beyond the limit of endurance. Relax the abdominal muscles first without moving the chin or the head. Allow the abdomen to return to its normal relaxed position. Inhale slowly and quietly. Refrain from any inhalation during the contraction and holding phases. Take a few normal breaths to recover. Repeat the entire cycle not more than six to eight times at a single stretch. Practice this sequence once a day only. Master this standing technique before introducing the abdominal lock (Uddiyana Bandha) into seated pranayama during the interval after exhalation.

202.name: Nauli
202.description:
Nauli or Lauliki
The process conveys some idea of a large wave or surge, where the abdominal muscles and organs are made to move laterally and vertically in a surging motion, similar to the pitching of a boat on a stormy sea.
Effects: The abdominal recti are strengthened, the other effects are the same as those of Uddiyana Bandha.
202.technique: Stand in Tadasana. Spread the legs a foot apart. Bend slightly at the knees. Stoop forward. Place the hands with the fingers spread wide on the thighs. The hands should be just above the knees. Lower the head until the chin rests in the notch between the collar-bones. Inhale deeply. Exhale quickly so all air is forced from the lungs in a rush. Hold the breath without any inhalation. Pull the whole abdominal region back towards the spine. The area between the pelvic rim and the floating ribs on both sides should be made passive to create hollowness. Push the abdominal recti forward at the same time. Maintain this position from five to ten seconds. Relax the grip on the recti. Go back to the position described in paragraph six. Relax the abdomen. Inhale slowly. Take a few deep breaths. Repeat the cycle six to eight times at a stretch. Repeat the entire process only once every twenty-four hours. Practise Nauli on an empty stomach. Practise Nauli after evacuating the bladder. Practise Nauli after evacuating the bowels.

203.name: Ujjayi Pranayama
203.description:
Ujjayi Pranayama
This is a method of breathing which can be done at all times of the day and night.
Effects: Aerates the lungs, removes phlegm, gives endurance, soothes the nerves, and tones the entire system, beneficial for high blood pressure and coronary troubles when done without retention in a reclining position.
203.technique: Sit in a comfortable position. Keep the back erect and rigid. Lower the head to the trunk. Rest the chin in the notch above the breast-bone. Stretch the arms out straight. Rest the back of the wrists on the knees. Join the tips of the index fingers to the tips of the thumbs. Keep the other fingers extended. Close the eyes. Look inwards. Exhale completely. Take a slow, deep steady breath through both nostrils. Fill the lungs up to the brim. Do not bloat the abdomen during inhalation. Pull the entire abdominal area back towards the spine. Hold the breath for a second or two. Exhale slowly, deeply and steadily until the lungs are completely empty. Keep your grip on the abdomen as you begin to exhale. Gradually and slowly relax the diaphragm after two or three seconds of exhalation. Wait for a second before drawing a fresh breath. Repeat the cycles for five to ten minutes. Keep the eyes closed throughout. Lie on the floor in Savasana.

I.title: Stage I
I.technique:
Stage I
Spread a blanket folded lengthwise on the floor. Lay another blanket folded three or four times over the first one to support the head and trunk. Lie flat on the back with the spine positioned exactly in the middle of the folded blanket. Keep the body in a straight line. Prevent the rib cage from caving in toward the floor. Close the eyes. Place a soft cloth over the eyes to relax the facial muscles. Stay quiet and still for one or two minutes. Breathe through the nose at a normal pace. Observe the internal sensation of the breath as it enters and leaves the body. Inhale while ensuring that both lungs fill with an equal volume of air. Expand the chest in an upward and outward direction simultaneously. Synchronize the upward lift of the sternum with the lateral expansion of the ribs. Exhale quietly and release the air. Empty both lungs at an even speed. Adjust the movement of the chest if one side of the lungs moves faster than the other. Maintain this conscious observation of even breathing for ten minutes. Keep the eyes closed and the body motionless throughout the practice.
I.shorthand: [Lying] [Both In - Normal] ↔ [Both Out - Normal] -> [Normal breathing lying down, just becoming aware of the breath]

II.title: Stage II
II.technique:
Stage II
Spread a blanket folded lengthwise on the floor. Lay another blanket folded three or four times over the first one to support the head and trunk. Lie flat on the back with the spine positioned exactly in the middle of the folded blanket. Keep the body in a straight line. Prevent the rib cage from caving in toward the floor. Close the eyes without tensing the eye-balls. Direct the gaze inwards toward the heart. Keep the inner ears alert and receptive. Place a soft cloth over the eyes to relax the facial muscles. Stay quiet and still for one or two minutes. Exhale quietly through the nose until the lungs feel empty. Avoid pressing down upon the abdominal organs during this initial out-breath. Inhale normally through the nose to fill the lungs. Exhale slowly and deeply through the nose. Maintain a steady and consistent flow of air during the exhalation. Empty the lungs completely without force. Coordinate the release of the breath with the gradual settling of the rib cage. Continue this practice of normal inhalation and deep exhalation for ten minutes. Release all effort and relax the body completely.
II.shorthand: [Lying] [Both In - Normal] ↔ [Both Out - Deep] -> [Deep breathing, training to lengthen the exhalation]

III.title: Stage III
III.technique: Spread a blanket folded lengthwise on the floor. Lay another blanket folded three or four times over the first one to support the head and trunk. Lie flat on the back with the spine positioned exactly in the middle of the folded blanket. Keep the body in a straight line without caving in the rib cage. Close the eyes without tensing the eye-balls and direct the gaze inwards. Keep the inner ears alert and receptive. Exhale quietly until the lungs feel empty without pressing down upon the abdominal organs. Relax the diaphragm and stretch it sideways. Take a slow and deep in-breath through the nose. Maintain a steady and sibilant sound during the inhalation. Ensure that both lungs fill evenly from the bottom to the top. Keep the abdomen from inflating by preventing the diaphragm from moving above the floating ribs. Listen to the sound of the breath attentively to maintain a constant rhythm. Fill the lungs completely until the sound of the inhalation becomes inaudible. Draw the eye-balls consciously downward to gaze into the lungs. Immobilize the diaphragm at the very start of the exhalation. Breathe out slowly and allow the out-breath to be slightly longer than a normal breath. Continue this pattern of deep inhalation and controlled exhalation for ten minutes. Release the blankets and lie flat in savasana to relax the entire body.
III.shorthand: [Lying] [Both In - Deep] ↔ [Both Out - Normal] -> [Deep breathing, training to lengthen the inhalation]

IV.title: Stage IV
IV.technique: Spread a blanket folded lengthwise on the floor. Lay another blanket folded three or four times over the first one to support the head and trunk. Lie flat on the back with the spine positioned exactly in the middle of the folded blanket. Keep the body in a straight line without caving in the rib cage. Close the eyes without tensing the eye-balls and direct the gaze inwards. Keep the inner ears alert and receptive. Exhale quietly through the nose until the lungs feel empty without pressing down upon the abdominal organs. Relax the diaphragm and stretch it sideways. Take a slow and deep in-breath through the nose. Maintain a steady and sibilant sound during the inhalation. Ensure that both lungs fill evenly from the bottom to the top. Keep the abdomen from inflating by preventing the diaphragm from moving above the floating ribs. Listen to the sound of the breath attentively to maintain a constant rhythm. Fill the lungs completely until the sound of the inhalation becomes inaudible. Draw the eye-balls consciously downward to gaze into the lungs. Grip the diaphragm at the start of the exhalation. Release the diaphragm gradually as the air leaves the body. Exhale slowly and deeply through the nose until the lungs feel empty. Maintain a steady and consistent flow of air throughout the out-breath. Continue this cycle of deep inhalation and deep exhalation for ten to fifteen minutes. Release all effort and lie flat in savasana to relax the entire body.
IV.shorthand: [Lying] [Both In - Deep] ↔ [Both Out - Deep] -> [Prolonged inhlation and exhalation]

V.title: Stage V
V.technique: Sit in padmasana, siddhasana, swastikasana, virasana, or any convenient and comfortable meditative position. Keep the back and the spinal column firm. Soften the spinal muscles to allow the torso to adjust during the breath. Balance the firmness of the spine with the mobility of the back muscles. Lower the head toward the trunk. Lift the inner frame of the chest toward the descending chin. Rest the chin in the notch just above the breastbone to form the chin lock (Jalandhara Bandha). Keep the head down as low as possible without strain if the chin does not reach the chest. Rest the back of the wrists on the knees with the arms down. Join the tip of the index finger of each hand with the tip of the thumb to form jnana mudra. Keep the other fingers extended. Close the eyes and keep the eye-balls passive and receptive. Direct the gaze inwards toward the heart. Keep the inner ears alert and receptive. Exhale quietly as far as possible through the nose. Avoid pressing down upon the abdominal organs during this out-breath. Inhale while ensuring that both lungs fill with an equal volume of air. Expand the chest in an upward and outward direction simultaneously. Synchronize the upward lift of the sternum with the lateral expansion of the ribs. Exhale quietly and release the air. Empty both lungs at an even speed. Adjust the movement of the chest if one side of the lungs moves faster than the other. Maintain this conscious observation of even breathing for ten minutes. Lie down in savasana and relax the body for a few minutes.
V.shorthand: [Sitting] [Both In - Normal] ↔ [Both Out - Deep] -> [Training to lengthen the exhalation while sitting]

VI.title: Stage VI
VI.technique: Sit in padmasana, siddhasana, swastikasana, virasana, or any convenient and comfortable meditative position. Keep the back and the spinal column firm. Soften the spinal muscles to allow the torso to adjust during the breath. Lower the head toward the trunk. Lift the inner frame of the chest toward the descending chin. Rest the chin in the notch just above the breastbone to form the chin lock (Jalandhara Bandha). Place the back of the wrists on the knees with the arms down. Join the tip of the index finger of each hand with the tip of the thumb to form jnana mudra while keeping the other fingers extended. Close the eyes and keep the eye-balls passive and receptive. Direct the gaze inwards toward the heart. Keep the inner ears alert and receptive. Exhale whatever breath is currently in the lungs until they feel empty. Inhale normally through the nose. Exhale slowly, deeply, and steadily until the lungs feel empty again. Attend to the stability of the posture throughout the out-breath. Listen carefully to the aspirate sound of the breath as it leaves the nostrils. Maintain a consistent rhythm and smoothness in the flow of air. Complete each cycle by fully emptying the lungs without collapsing the chest. Repeat these cycles of normal inhalation and deep exhalation for ten minutes. Take a final inhalation to finish the sequence. Lie down in savasana and rest for a few minutes.
VI.shorthand: [Sitting] [Both In - Deep] ↔ [Both Out - Deep] -> [Training to lengthen the inhalation while sitting]

VII.title: Stage VII
VII.technique: Sit in padmasana, siddhasana, swastikasana, virasana, or any convenient and comfortable meditative position. Keep the back and the spinal column firm. Soften the spinal muscles to allow the torso to adjust. Lower the head toward the trunk. Lift the inner frame of the chest toward the descending chin. Rest the chin in the notch just above the breastbone to form the chin lock (Jalandhara Bandha). Place the back of the wrists on the knees with the arms down. Join the tip of the index finger of each hand with the tip of the thumb to form jnana mudra while keeping the other fingers extended. Close the eyes and keep the eye-balls passive and receptive. Direct the gaze inwards toward the heart. Keep the inner ears alert and receptive. Exhale quietly until the lungs feel empty without pressing down upon the abdominal organs. Relax the diaphragm and stretch it sideways. Take a slow and deep in-breath through the nose. Maintain a steady and sibilant sound during the inhalation. Ensure that both lungs fill evenly from the bottom to the top. Keep the abdomen from inflating by preventing the diaphragm from moving above the floating ribs. Listen to the sound of the breath attentively to maintain a constant rhythm. Fill the lungs completely until the sound of the inhalation becomes inaudible. Draw the eye-balls consciously downward to gaze into the lungs. Immobilize the diaphragm at the very start of the exhalation. Breathe out slowly but not deeply. Allow the out-breath to be slightly longer than a normal breath. Repeat such cycles of deep inhalation and controlled exhalation for ten minutes. Finish with a final inhalation. Lie down in savasana and rest the body for a few minutes.
VII.shorthand: [Sitting] [Both In - Deep] ↔ [Both Out - Deep] -> [Ujjayi proper with prolonged inhlation and exhalation while sitting]

VIII.title: Stage VIII
VIII.technique: Sit in padmasana, siddhasana, swastikasana, virasana, or any convenient and comfortable meditative position. Keep the back and the spinal column firm. Soften the spinal muscles to allow the torso to adjust during the breath. Lower the head toward the trunk. Lift the inner frame of the chest toward the descending chin. Rest the chin in the notch above the breastbone to form the chin lock (Jalandhara Bandha). Place the back of the wrists on the knees with the arms down. Join the tip of the index finger of each hand with the tip of the thumb to form jnana mudra while keeping the other fingers extended. Close the eyes and keep the eye-balls passive and receptive. Direct the gaze inwards toward the heart. Keep the inner ears alert and receptive. Exhale whatever breath is currently in the lungs until they feel empty. Take a slow, deep, and steady in-breath through the nose. Listen to the sibilant sound of the breath to control the flow and rhythm. Fill the lungs from the bottom to the top up to the collarbones. Channel the breath to the remotest parts of the lungs. Keep the body and brain receptive to the incoming breath without using force. Draw the entire abdominal area from the pubis to the breastbone toward the spine. Lift the abdominal area up toward the head to massage the internal organs. Keep the diaphragm below the floating ribs to prevent the abdomen from inflating. Lift the inner intercostal muscles at the front of the chest during the inhalation. Create a further fractional lift of these muscles just before starting the exhalation. Maintain the lift of the intercostal muscles and the diaphragm as the air begins to leave the nostrils. Allow the breath to go out slowly, deeply, and steadily. Relax the grip of the trunk gradually as the lungs reach a passive and empty state. Be aware of the fractional pause as the torso muscles adjust between breaths. Repeat these cycles of deep inhalation and deep exhalation for ten to fifteen minutes. Finish the session with a final inhalation. Lie down in savasana and rest for several minutes.
VIII.shorthand: [Sitting] [Both In - Normal] -> [Hold (5s)] -> [Both Out - Normal] -> [Includes Antara Kumbhaka]

IX.title: Stage IX
IX.technique: Sit in padmasana, siddhasana, swastikasana, virasana, or any convenient and comfortable meditative position. Keep the back and the spinal column firm. Soften the spinal muscles to allow the torso to adjust during the breath. Lower the head toward the trunk. Lift the inner frame of the chest toward the descending chin. Rest the chin in the notch above the breastbone to form the chin lock (Jalandhara Bandha). Place the back of the wrists on the knees with the arms down. Join the tip of the index finger of each hand with the tip of the thumb to form jnana mudra while keeping the other fingers extended. Close the eyes and keep the eye-balls passive and receptive. Direct the gaze inwards toward the heart. Keep the inner ears alert and receptive. Exhale quietly until the lungs feel empty without pressing down upon the abdominal organs. Inhale slowly and deeply through the nose until the lungs are full. Hold the breath after the inhalation is complete. Keep the trunk firm and alert during this internal retention. Refrain from raising the bridge of the nose or the head while holding the breath. Keep the eyes steady and directed toward the lungs. Feel the breath percolating to the remotest pores of the skin of the torso. Observe the internal grip of the consciousness until it begins to lose its hold. 204.name: Surya Bhedana Pranayama
204.description:
204 / Sūrya Bhedana Prānāyāma
Technique

1. Sit in any comfortable position like Padmasana (Image 104), Siddhasana (Image 84) or Virasana (Image 89).

2. Keep the back erect and rigid. Lower the head to the trunk. Rest the chin in the notch between the collar-bones just above the breast-bone. (This is Jalandhara Bandha.)

3. Stretch the left arm. Rest the back of the left wrist on the left knee. Perform Jñāna Mudra with the left hand (as stated in stage 3 of the technique of Ujjayi).

4. Bend the right arm at the elbow. Bend the index and middle fingers towards the palm, keeping them passive. Bring the ring and little fingers towards the thumb. (Image 598)

5. Place the right thumb on the right side of the nose just below the nasal bone, the ring and little fingers on the left side of the nose just below the nasal bone, just above the curve of the fatty tissue of the nostrils above the upper jaw.

6. Press the ring and the little finger to block the left side of the nose completely.

7. With the right thumb, press the fatty tissue on the right side so as to make the outer edge of the right nostril parallel to the lower edge of the cartilage of the septum.

8. The right thumb is bent at the top joint and the tip of the thumb is placed at a right angle to the septum. (Image 599)

9. Now inhale slowly and deeply controlling the aperture of the right nostril with the tip of the thumb nearer the nail. Fill the lungs to the brim (pūraka).

10. Then block the right nostril so that both are now blocked.

11. Hold the breath for about 5 seconds (antara kumbhaka) while practising Mūla Bandha (see p. 366).

12. Keeping the right nostril completely blocked, open the left nostril partially and exhale through it slowly and deeply (rechaka).

13. During the exhalation regulate the rhythmic flow of air from the left nostril by adjusting pressure with the ring and little fingers, so that the outer edge of the left nostril is kept parallel to the septum. The pressure should be exerted from the inner sides of the tips of the fingers (away from the nails).

14. This completes one cycle of Sūrya Bhedana Prānāyāma. Continue with more cycles at a stretch from 5 to 10 minutes, according to capacity.

15. All the inhalations in Sūrya Bhedana are from the right nostril and all the exhalations from the left nostril.

16. Throughout the process, the passage of air is felt at the tips of the fingers and the thumbs and in the nasal membranes where pressure is applied. The passage of air makes a sound similar to air escaping from a cycle tube. This sound should be maintained constant throughout by varying pressure on the nostrils.

17. The eyes, temples, eyebrows and the skin on the forehead should remain completely passive and show no sign of strain.

18. The mind should be absorbed completely in listening to the proper sound of the passage of air and in maintaining a proper rhythm in breathing.

19. Each inhalation and exhalation should last for the same length of time.

20. The inhalation and the exhalation should not be forced. An even and slow rhythm should be maintained throughout.

21. Lie down in Savasana after completing pranayama. (Image 592)

Effects Increases digestive power, soothes and invigorates the nerves, and cleans the sinuses. Fills lungs more slowly and fully than Ujjayi. Beneficial for persons with low blood pressure.

Note: Those with high blood pressure or heart trouble should not perform breath retention (kumbhaka).

Sit in a comfortable meditative posture such as the lotus pose or the hero pose. Keep the back erect and rigid. Lift the chest toward the chin. Lower the head toward the trunk.
