205.name: Nadi Sodhana Pranayama
205.description:
205 / Nāḍī Śodhana Prānāyāma

Technique

1. Sit in any comfortable position like Padmasana (Image 104), Siddhasana (Image 84) or Virasana (Image 89).

2. Keep the back erect and rigid. Lower the head to the trunk. Rest the chin in the notch between the collar-bones just above the breast-bone. (This is Jalandhara Bandha.)

3. Stretch the left arm. Rest the back of the left wrist on the left knee. Perform Jñāna Mudra with the left hand (as stated in stage 3 of the technique of Ujjayi).

4. Bend the right arm at the elbow. Bend the index and middle fingers towards the palm, keeping them passive. Bring the ring and little fingers towards the thumb. (Image 598)

5. Place the right thumb on the right side of the nose just below the nasal bone, the ring and little fingers on the left side of the nose just below the nasal bone, just above the curve of the fatty tissue of the nostrils above the upper jaw.

6. Press the ring and the little finger to block the left side of the nose completely.

7. With the right thumb, press the fatty tissue on the right side so as to make the outer edge of the right nostril parallel to the lower edge of the cartilage of the septum.

8. The right thumb is bent at the top joint and the tip of the thumb is placed at a right angle to the septum. (Image 599)

9. Empty the lungs completely through the right nostril. Control the aperture of the right nostril with the inner side of the right thumb, away from the nail.

10. Now inhale slowly, steadily and deeply through the right nostril, controlling the aperture with the tip of the right thumb near the nail. Fill the lungs to the brim (pūraka). During this inhalation the left nostril is completely blocked by the ring and little fingers.

11. After full inhalation, block the right nostril completely with the pressure of the thumb and release the pressure of the ring and little fingers on the left nostril. Readjust them on the outer edge of the left nostril and keep it parallel to the septum. Exhale slowly, steadily and deeply through the left nostril. Empty the lungs completely. The pressure should be exerted from the inner sides of the tips of the ring and little fingers (away from the nails) (rechaka).

12. After full exhalation through the left nostril, change the pressure on it by adjusting the fingers. In the changed position, the tips of the ring and little fingers nearer the nails exert the pressure.

13. Now inhale through the left nostril slowly, steadily and deeply, filling the lungs to the brim (pūraka).

14. After full inhalation through the left nostril, block it and exhale through the right nostril, adjusting the pressure of the right thumb on the right nostril as stated in para. 2 above (rechaka).

15. This completes one cycle of Nāḍī Śodhana Prānāyāma. Here the rhythm of breathing is as follows: 

===>a. Exhale through the right nostril. 
===>b. Inhale through the right nostril. 
===>c. Exhale through the left nostril. 
===>d. Inhale through the left nostril. 
===>e. Exhale through the right nostril. 
===>f. Inhale through the right nostril. 
===>g. Exhale through the left nostril. 
===>h. Inhale through the left nostril. 
===>i. Exhale through the right nostril. 
===>j. Inhale through the right nostril ... and so on.

Stage (a) above is the preparatory one. The first real Nāḍī Śodhana Prānāyāma cycle starts at stage (b) and ends at stage (e). The second cycle starts at stage (f) and ends at stage (i). Stage (j) is the safety measure to be observed after the completion of the cycles in order to prevent gasping, breathlessness and strain on the heart.

Do 8 to 10 cycles at a stretch as described above. This may take 6 or 8 minutes.

Inhalation and exhalation from each side should take the same time. In the beginning the duration will be unequal. Persevere until equality is achieved.

After achieving mastery over the equal duration and precision over inhalation and exhalation on either side an attempt may be made to retain breath (antara kumbhaka) after inhaling.

This precision is only achieved after long practice.

Retention should not disturb the rhythm and equality of inhalation and exhalation. If either are disturbed curtail the period of retention or hold the breath on alternate cycles.

During retention after inhalation practise Mūla Bandha (see p. 366).

Do not attempt to hold the breath after exhalation (bāhya kumbhaka, Image 600) until you have mastered retention after inhalation (antara kumbhaka). Then during bāhya kumbhaka practise Uddiyana (Images 593, 594) with Mūla Bandha (see p. 366).

Retention and the lengthening of inhalation and exhalation should only be attempted with the help and under the guidance of an experienced Guru.

Always conclude by lying down in Savasana. (Image 592)

Effects Increases oxygen supply to the blood, refreshing the body; calms and purifies the nerves; stills and clears the mind (lucidity).

Note: Persons with high blood pressure or heart trouble should not hold their breath (kumbhaka). Persons with low blood pressure benefit from internal retention.
205.technique: Sit in a comfortable meditative posture such as the lotus pose or the hero pose. Keep the back erect and rigid. Lift the chest toward the chin. Lower the head toward the trunk. Rest the chin in the notch between the collarbones to form the chin lock (Jalandhara Bandha). Stretch the left arm forward. Rest the back of the left wrist on the left knee. Join the index finger and thumb of the left hand to form the ja mudra. Bend the right arm at the elbow. Fold the index and middle fingers of the right hand toward the palm. Keep the right thumb near the right nostril. Place the right ring and little fingers on the left side of the nose. Position the fingertips just below the nasal bone and above the fatty tissue, inhale through both nostrils. Empty the lungs completely through the right nostril. Control the aperture of the right nostril with the inner side of the right thumb, away from the nail. Now inhale slowly, steadily, and deeply through the right nostril. Control the aperture with the tip of the right thumb near the nail. Fill the lungs to the brim, which is pūraka. 206.name: Bhastrika Pranayama

Bhastrikā Prānāyāma
The sound made resembles air rushing through bellows.
Effects: rests the lungs and the diaphragm, prepares them for fresh cycles of Bhastrikā.
206.technique: Sit comfortably with an erect spine in Siddhasana, Sukhasana, or Padmasana. Prepare by following the initial Ujjayi breathing technique. Take a fast, vigorous breath through both nostrils. Exhale fast and forcefully through both nostrils. Complete the inhalation and exhalation for ten to twelve cycles in a continuous flow. Take a slow, deep breath using the Ujjayi technique. Retain the breath with Mūla Bandha for two to three seconds. Exhale slowly and deeply as in Ujjayi. Repeat the cycles of Bhastrikā three to four times, interspersed with Ujjayi breathing. Alternatively, adjust the thumb and finger pressure on the nostrils following the Sūrya Bhedana technique. Completely close the left nostril. Keep the right nostril partially open. Inhale and exhale vigorously only through the right nostril for ten to twelve cycles. Close the right nostril. Partially open the left nostril. Repeat the vigorous inhalation and exhalation through the left nostril for an equal number of cycles. Release the fingers from the nostrils. Take a few deep breaths as in Ujjayi. Repeat the cycles on both sides three or four times, performing Ujjayi breathing between repetitions. Lie down in Savasana after completion.

I.title: Stage I
I.technique: Sit in padmasana, siddhasana, swastikasana, virasana, or any convenient and comfortable meditative position. Keep the back and the spinal column firm. Soften the spinal muscles to allow the torso to adjust during the breath. Lower the head toward the trunk. Lift the inner frame of the chest toward the descending chin. Take a short and strong breath through both open nostrils. Expel the air with a quick and strong blast through the nose. Repeat this forceful inhalation and exhalation rhythmically. Perform four to eight such blasts at a stretch to complete one cycle. End the cycle with a final forceful out-breath. Inhale slowly and deeply through both nostrils as in ujjayi. Contract the muscles of the perineum and lift them toward the navel to perform the root lock (Mula Bandha). Hold the breath within for five to eight seconds. Release the root lock (Mula Bandha) gradually. Exhale slowly and deeply through the nose as in ujjayi. Repeat these cycles of bhastrika blasts interspersed with ujjayi three or four times. Take one final deep breath through both nostrils. Raise the head to a neutral position. Lie down flat in savasana and rest the entire body.

207.name: Kapalabhati Pranayama
207.description:
Kapālabhāti Prānāyāma
The process or kriya of Kapālabhāti is a milder form of Bhastrikā Prānāyāma, where the inhalation is slow but the exhalation is vigorous, with a split second of retention after each exhalation.
Effects: Both Bhastrikā and Kapālabhāti activate and invigorate the liver, spleen, pancreas and abdominal muscles, thus digestion is improved, the sinuses are drained, the eyes feel cool and one has a general sense of exhilaration.

Allow the abdomen to expand as you inhale. In Kapālabhāti, perform slow inhalation. Exhale vigorously. Retain the breath for a split second after each exhalation. Do a few cycles of Kapālabhāti. Lie down in Savasana after finishing Kapālabhāti. In Bhastrikā, inhale and exhale quickly ten times like the bellows of the blacksmith. Constantly dilate and contract. Stop immediately if the nose starts to bleed. Stop immediately if the ears throb and ache.

Repeat these cycles of kapalabhati blasts interspersed with ujjayi three or four times. Take one final deep breath through both nostrils. Raise the head to a neutral position. 208.name: Bhramari Pranayama
208.description:
Bhramari Pranayama
It is a breathing technique where a soft humming sound like the murmuring of bees is made during exhalation.
Effects: The soft humming sound produced during exhalation is helpful in treating cases of insomnia, it also soothes the nerves, and tones the entire system.
208.technique: Sit in padmasana, siddhasana, swastikasana, virasana, or any convenient and comfortable meditative position. Keep the back and the spinal column firm. Soften the spinal muscles to allow the torso to adjust during the breath. Lower the head toward the trunk. Lift the inner frame of the chest toward the descending chin. Rest the chin in the notch above the breastbone to form the chin lock (Jalandhara Bandha). Place the back of the wrists on the knees with the arms down. Join the tip of the index finger of each hand with the tip of the thumb to form ja mudra while keeping the other fingers extended. Close the eyes and keep the eye-balls passive and receptive. Direct the gaze inwards toward the heart. Keep the inner ears alert and receptive. Exhale whatever breath is in the lungs through both nostrils. Raise the hands to the face to perform sanmukhi mudra. Lift the elbows to the level of the shoulders. Place the thumb tips in the ear holes to block out external sounds as part of sanmukhi mudra. Press the tragi over the ear holes if the thumb tips cause pain. Bring the index and middle fingers over the closed eyelids. Draw the upper lids down with the pads of the middle finger tips. Cover the remaining space above with the pads of the index finger tips to keep out light. Press the eye balls gently with the fingers while keeping them passive. Place the ring finger tips on the nostrils to narrow the nasal passages. Rest the little fingers on the upper lips to monitor the flow of the breath. Inhale slowly and deeply through both nostrils with a soft sibilant sound. Expand the chest fully without using force. Exhale slowly while creating a steady humming or murmuring sound like a bee. Feel the vibrations of the sound throughout the head. Complete these cycles for ten to fifteen minutes or until no strain is felt. Finish the final cycle by inhaling normally through both open nostrils. Lower the hands from the sanmukhi mudra position to the knees. Raise the head to a neutral position. Lie down flat in savasana and rest the entire body.

209.name: Sitali Pranayama
209.description:
Sitali Pranayama
The descriptive meaning of the name is not explicitly provided in the text.
Effects: Cools the system, soothes eyes and ears, beneficial for low fever, biliousness, and thirst, activates liver and spleen, improves digestion.
209.technique: Sit in Padmasana, Siddhasana, or Virasana. Keep the back erect and rigid. Keep the head level. Perform the Ja Mudra with the hands. Open the mouth. Form the lips into an 'O'. Lift and curl up the sides and tip of the tongue so it touches the teeth. Protrude the curled tongue out of the lips. Draw in air past the curled tongue with a sibilant sound to fill the lungs completely. Withdraw the tongue. Close the mouth. After full inhalation, lower the head from the nape of the neck to the trunk. Rest the chin in the notch between the collar-bones. Hold the breath for about five seconds. Practice Mula Bandha while holding the breath. Exhale slowly with an aspirate sound through the nose as in Ujjayi. Lift the head. Repeat the cycle for five to ten minutes. Lie down in Savasana after completion.

I.title: Stage I
I.technique: Sit in padmasana, siddhasana, swastikasana, virasana, or any convenient and comfortable meditative position. Keep the back and the spinal column firm. Soften the spinal muscles to allow the torso to adjust during the breath. Lift the inner frame of the chest. Keep the head level and looking forward. Exhale whatever breath is in the lungs through both nostrils until they feel empty. Open the mouth and form the lips into the shape of an O. Push the tongue out beyond the lips. Curl the tongue lengthwise so that its shape resembles a fresh curled leaf about to open. Stretch the curled tongue further out from the mouth. Draw in air through the curled tongue as if drinking with a straw. Fill the lungs completely with the air cooled by the moisture of the tongue. Withdraw the tongue into the mouth. Close the mouth. 211.name: Sama Vrtti Pranayama
211.description:
Sama Vrtti Pranayama
Sama means the same or identical, straight, entire, whole and complete, also similarly or in the same manner, while Vrtti means action, movement, function or operation, a course of conduct or method.
Effects: Establishes uniformity in the duration of inhalation, retention, and exhalation, trains the lungs to handle vacuum and pressure without strain, prepares the mind for concentration (dharana) and meditation.
211.technique: Breathe through your nose only. Try not to move your shoulders, neck, chest, or upper body. Expand your lower belly outwardly on your inhale. Contract your lower belly inwardly on your exhale. Confine the practice initially only to inhalation and exhalation. First, achieve uniformity of length of time in inhalation and exhalation. Then, only attempt retention of breath after full inhalation. Start the retention gradually. In the beginning, keep the ratio time for inhalation, retention, and exhalation at one to one half to one. Very slowly increase the proportions to one to three quarters to one. After this is firmly established, attempt one to one to one. Only after mastering this, increase the proportion of retention so as to achieve the ratio of one to one to one. Do not attempt restraint of breath after full exhalation until you have achieved the desired ratio of one to one to one in inhalation, retention, and exhalation. Do not do both retentions together in the beginning. Practice retention after full inhalation and restraint after full exhalation separately or alternately. Practice retentions first by interspersing them after two or three cycles of deep breathing with inhalation and exhalation alone. Start with three retentions after full inhalation and three restraints after full exhalation. Increase the number of retentions very gradually.

212.name: Visama Vrtti Pranayama
212.description:
Visama Vrtti Pranayama
Visama means irregular and difficult.
Effects: interruption of rhythm, difficulty and danger for the pupil, all the systems of the body especially the respiratory and nervous ones are overtaxed and unduly strained.
212.technique: Sit in a stable meditative asana with the spinal column firm. Lift the inner frame of the chest and lower the head toward the trunk to form the chin lock (Jalandhara Bandha). Place the back of the wrists on the knees and keep the eyes and ears passive. Form mrigi mudra with the right hand. Inhale through the right nostril for a count of five seconds. Block both nostrils completely and perform the root lock (Mula Bandha). Hold the internal breath for twenty seconds. Release the root lock (Mula Bandha). Open the left nostril partially. Exhale through the left nostril for a count of ten seconds. Maintain the ratio of one to four to two for each cycle. Inhale through the left nostril for a count of ten seconds. Block both nostrils and perform the root lock (Mula Bandha). Hold the breath for twenty seconds. Release the root lock (Mula Bandha). Open the right nostril. Exhale through the right nostril for a count of five seconds. Perform the next cycle by inhaling for twenty seconds. Block both nostrils and hold the breath for ten seconds. Exhale through the opposite nostril for five seconds. Ensure the right hand stays in mrigi mudra for all digital control. Keep the septum stable to prevent the nose from tilting. Synchronize the movements of the rib cage with the flow of air. Maintain a soft and smooth sound during each breath. End the practice with a quiet inhalation. Lower the right hand. Raise the head. Relax the body in savasana.

213.name: Viloma Pranayama
213.description:
Viloma Prānāyāma
Viloma Prānāyāma is a breathing technique performed in two stages, involving either interrupted inhalation or interrupted exhalation.
Effects: Stage one helps those with low blood pressure, Stage two (lying down) benefits those with high blood pressure.
213.technique: Viloma Prānāyāma can be done seated or lying down. If seated, keep the back erect. Lower the head to the trunk. Rest the chin in the notch between the collar-bones and the breastbone for Jalandhara Bandha. Keep the hands in Jñāna Mudra. Inhale for two seconds. Pause for two seconds holding the breath. Again inhale for two seconds. Again pause for two seconds holding the breath. Continue this until the lungs are completely full. Practice Mūla Bandha during the pauses in inhalation. Hold the breath for five to ten seconds according to capacity, practicing Mūla Bandha. Exhale slowly and deeply as in Ujjayi with an aspirate sound. Relax Mūla Bandha during exhalation. This completes one cycle of the first stage. Repeat ten to fifteen cycles of this first stage at a stretch. Rest for one or two minutes. For Stage two, take a deep breath without any pauses as in Ujjayi with a sibilant sound. Keep the chin on the top of the breast-bone. Fill the lungs completely. Hold the breath from five to ten seconds, keeping the Mūla Bandha grip. Exhale for two seconds. Pause for two seconds. Again exhale for two seconds. Again pause for two seconds. Continue this until the lungs are completely emptied. Maintain the Mūla Bandha grip during the pauses. This completes one cycle of the second stage. Repeat the second stage of Viloma ten to fifteen times at a stretch. Lie down in Savasana.

I.title: Stage I
I.technique: Spread a blanket folded lengthwise on the floor. Lay another blanket folded three or four times over the first one to support the head and trunk. Lie flat on the back with the spine positioned exactly in the middle of the folded blanket. Keep the body in a straight line without caving in the rib cage. Close the eyes without tensing the eye-balls and direct the gaze inwards. Keep the inner ears alert and receptive. Place a soft cloth over the eyes to relax the facial muscles. Stay quiet and still for one or two minutes. Exhale quietly through the nose until the lungs feel empty without pressing down upon the abdominal organs. Inhale for two or three seconds through the nose. Immobilize the diaphragm lightly to pause the breath. Hold the breath for two or three seconds. Inhale again for another two or three seconds without letting the diaphragm loose. Pause and hold the breath for another two or three seconds. Continue this process of interrupted inhalation until the lungs are completely full. Repeat the pauses four or five times until full capacity is reached. Ensure no strain is felt in the head or chest throughout the practice. Exhale slowly, steadily, and deeply through the nose until the lungs are empty. Release the grip of the diaphragm gradually during the out-breath. Complete one cycle of interrupted inhalation and deep exhalation. Repeat these cycles for seven to ten minutes. Finish by breathing normally through the nose two or three times. Lie down flat in savasana and rest the entire body.
I.shorthand: [Lying] [Both In - Pauses] ↔ [Both Out - Strong Deep] -> [Inhalation with pauses lying down]

II.title: Stage II
II.technique: Spread a blanket folded lengthwise on the floor. Lay another blanket folded three or four times over the first one to support the head and trunk. Lie flat on the back with the spine positioned exactly in the middle of the folded blanket. Keep the body in a straight line without caving in the rib cage. Close the eyes without tensing the eye-balls and direct the gaze inwards. Keep the inner ears alert and receptive. Place a soft cloth over the eyes to relax the facial muscles. Stay quiet and still for one or two minutes. Exhale quietly through the nose until the lungs feel empty without pressing down upon the abdominal organs. Inhale one long deep breath through the nose to fill the lungs completely. Avoid over-straining the chest or lungs during this inhalation. Exhale through the nose for two or three seconds. Pause the breath and hold it for two or three seconds. Exhale again for another two or three seconds. Pause the breath and hold it for another two or three seconds. Continue this process of interrupted exhalation until the lungs feel completely emptied. Repeat the pauses four or five times until the air is fully expelled. Release the grip on the abdomen gradually throughout the out-breath. Complete one cycle of deep inhalation and interrupted exhalation. Repeat these cycles for seven to ten minutes or for as long as fatigue is not felt. Take a final inhalation to finish the sequence. Lie down flat in savasana and rest the entire body.
II.shorthand: [Lying] [Both In - Strong Deep] ↔ [Both Out - Pauses] -> [Exhalation with pauses lying down]

III.title: Stage III
III.technique: Spread a blanket folded lengthwise on the floor. Lay another blanket folded three or four times over the first one to support the head and trunk. Lie flat on the back with the spine positioned exactly in the middle of the folded blanket. Keep the body in a straight line without caving in the rib cage. Close the eyes without tensing the eye-balls and direct the gaze inwards. Keep the inner ears alert and receptive. Place a soft cloth over the eyes to relax the facial muscles. Stay quiet and still for one or two minutes. Exhale quietly through the nose until the lungs feel empty without pressing down upon the abdominal organs. Inhale for two or three seconds through the nose. Immobilize the diaphragm lightly to pause the breath. Hold the breath for two or three seconds. Inhale again for another two or three seconds without letting the diaphragm loose. Pause and hold the breath for another two or three seconds. Continue this process of interrupted inhalation until the lungs are completely full. Hold the breath after the final inhalation for one or two seconds. Exhale through the nose for two or three seconds. Pause the breath and hold it for two or three seconds. Exhale again for another two or three seconds. Pause the breath and hold it for another two or three seconds. Continue this process of interrupted exhalation until the lungs feel completely emptied. Repeat the pauses four or five times during the out-breath. Release the grip on the diaphragm and the abdomen gradually throughout the exhalation. Complete one cycle of interrupted inhalation and interrupted exhalation. Repeat these cycles for eight to twelve minutes or for as long as no strain is felt. Take a final inhalation to finish the sequence. Lie down flat in savasana and rest the entire body.
III.shorthand: [Lying] [Both In - Pauses] ↔ [Both Out - Pauses] -> [Inhalation and exhalation with pauses while lying down]

IV.title: Stage IV
IV.technique: Sit in padmasana, siddhasana, swastikasana, virasana, or any convenient and comfortable meditative position. Keep the back and the spinal column firm. Soften the spinal muscles to allow the torso to adjust during the breath. Lower the head toward the trunk. Lift the inner frame of the chest toward the descending chin. Rest the chin in the notch above the breastbone to form the chin lock (Jalandhara Bandha). Place the back of the wrists on the knees with the arms down. Join the tip of the index finger of each hand with the tip of the thumb to form jnana mudra while keeping the other fingers extended. Close the eyes and keep the eye-balls passive and receptive. Direct the gaze inwards toward the heart. Keep the inner ears alert and receptive. Exhale quietly until the lungs feel empty without pressing down upon the abdominal organs. Inhale for two or three seconds through the nose. Lightly grip the diaphragm to pause the breath. Hold the breath for two or three seconds. Inhale again for another two or three seconds without letting the diaphragm loose. Pause and hold the breath for another two or three seconds. Continue this process of interrupted inhalation until the lungs are completely full. Repeat the pauses four or five times until full capacity is reached. Ensure no strain is felt in the head or chest throughout the practice. Gently draw the abdominal organs toward the spine. Lift the abdominal organs upward toward the diaphragm. Exhale slowly, steadily, and deeply through the nose until the lungs are empty. Release the grip on the abdomen gradually during the out-breath. Complete one cycle of interrupted inhalation and deep exhalation. Repeat these cycles for seven to ten minutes. Finish by breathing normally through the nose two or three times. Raise the head to a neutral position. Lie down flat in savasana and rest the entire body.
IV.shorthand: [Sitting] [Both In - Pauses] ↔ [Both Out - Strong_Deep] -> [Inhalation with pauses sitting]

V.title: Stage V
V.technique: Sit in padmasana, siddhasana, swastikasana, virasana, or any convenient and comfortable meditative position. Keep the back and the spinal column firm. Soften the spinal muscles to allow the torso to adjust during the breath. Lower the head toward the trunk. Lift the inner frame of the chest toward the descending chin. Rest the chin in the notch above the breastbone to form the chin lock (Jalandhara Bandha). Place the back of the wrists on the knees with the arms down. Join the tip of the index finger of each hand with the tip of the thumb to form jnana mudra while keeping the other fingers extended. Close the eyes and keep the eye-balls passive and receptive. Direct the gaze inwards toward the heart. Keep the inner ears alert and receptive. Exhale without strain through the nose until the lungs feel empty. Take one long and deep breath at one stretch without any pauses. Fill the lungs to the brim. Immobilize the diaphragm to prepare for the out-breath. Exhale through the nose for two seconds. Grip the diaphragm and hold the breath for two or three seconds. Exhale again for two seconds. Grip the diaphragm and hold the breath for another two or three seconds. Continue this process of interrupted exhalation until the lungs feel completely emptied. Repeat the pauses four or five times until the air is fully expelled. Release the grip on the diaphragm gradually as the lungs empty. Complete one cycle of deep inhalation and interrupted exhalation. Repeat these cycles for eight to ten minutes. Finish by taking two or three normal breaths through the nose. Raise the head to a neutral position. Lie down flat in savasana and rest the entire body.
V.shorthand: [Sitting] [Both In - Pauses] ↔ [Both Out - Pauses] -> [Inhalation and exhalation with pauses while sitting]

VI.title: Stage VI
VI.technique: Sit in padmasana, siddhasana, swastikasana, virasana, or any convenient and comfortable meditative position. Keep the back and the spinal column firm. Soften the spinal muscles to allow the torso to adjust during the breath. Lower the head toward the trunk. Lift the inner frame of the chest toward the descending chin. Rest the chin in the notch above the breastbone to form the chin lock (Jalandhara Bandha). Place the back of the wrists on the knees with the arms down. Join the tip of the index finger of each hand with the tip of the thumb to form jnana mudra while keeping the other fingers extended. Close the eyes and keep the eye-balls passive and receptive. Direct the gaze inwards toward the heart. Keep the inner ears alert and receptive. Exhale through the nose without strain until the lungs feel empty. Inhale for two or three seconds through the nose. Lightly grip the diaphragm to pause the breath. Hold the breath for two or three seconds. Inhale again for another two or three seconds without letting the diaphragm loose. Pause and hold the breath for another two or three seconds. Continue this process of interrupted inhalation until the lungs are completely full. Repeat the pauses four or five times until full capacity is reached. Hold the breath at the top of the inhalation for two or three seconds. Grip the abdominal organs and move them toward the spine. Exhale through the nose for two seconds. Immobilize the diaphragm to pause the breath for two or three seconds. Exhale again for two seconds. Grip the diaphragm and hold the breath for another two or three seconds. Continue this process of interrupted exhalation until the lungs feel completely emptied. Repeat the pauses four or five times until the air is fully expelled. Release the grip on the diaphragm and the abdomen gradually during the out-flow of breath. Complete one cycle of interrupted inhalation and interrupted exhalation. Repeat these cycles for ten to fifteen minutes or for as long as no strain is felt. Take two or three normal breaths through the nose. Raise the head to a neutral position. Lie down flat in savasana and rest the entire body.
VI.shorthand: [Sitting] [Both In - Pauses] -> Hold (15s) -> [Both Out - Strong Deep]

VII.title: Stage VII
VII.technique: Sit in padmasana, siddhasana, swastikasana, virasana, or any convenient and comfortable meditative position. Keep the back and the spinal column firm. Soften the spinal muscles to allow the torso to adjust during the breath. Lower the head toward the trunk. Lift the inner frame of the chest toward the descending chin. Rest the chin in the notch above the breastbone to form the chin lock (Jalandhara Bandha). Place the back of the wrists on the knees with the arms down. Join the tip of the index finger of each hand with the tip of the thumb to form jnana mudra while keeping the other fingers extended. Close the eyes and keep the eye-balls passive and receptive. Direct the gaze inwards toward the heart. Keep the inner ears alert and receptive. Exhale deeply through the nose until the lungs feel empty without straining. Inhale for two or three seconds through the nose. Lightly grip the diaphragm to pause the breath. Hold the breath for two or three seconds. Inhale again for another two or three seconds without letting the diaphragm loose. Pause and hold the breath for another two or three seconds. Continue this process of interrupted inhalation until the lungs are completely full. Repeat the pauses four or five times until full capacity is reached. Hold the breath for ten to fifteen seconds to perform internal retention (antara kumbhaka). Maintain a firm grip on the diaphragm during this retention. Exhale slowly and deeply through the nose. Relax the hold of the diaphragm gradually as the air leaves the body. Complete one cycle of interrupted inhalation, internal retention, and deep exhalation. Repeat these cycles for fifteen to twenty minutes or as long as no fatigue is felt. Take two or three normal breaths through the nose. Raise the head to a neutral position. Lie down flat in savasana and rest the entire body.
VII.shorthand: [Sitting] [Strong Deep In] -> [Out - Pauses] -> Hold Out (6s) -> [Exhalation with pauses and Bahya Kumbhaka, no Uddiyana Bandha]

VIII.title: Stage VIII
VIII.technique: Sit in padmasana, siddhasana, swastikasana, virasana, or any convenient and comfortable meditative position. Keep the back and the spinal column firm. Soften the spinal muscles to allow the torso to adjust during the breath. Lower the head toward the trunk. Lift the inner frame of the chest toward the descending chin. Rest the chin in the notch above the breastbone to form the chin lock (Jalandhara Bandha). Place the back of the wrists on the knees with the arms down. Join the tip of the index finger of each hand with the tip of the thumb to form jnana mudra while keeping the other fingers extended. Close the eyes and keep the eye-balls passive and receptive. Direct the gaze inwards toward the heart. Keep the inner ears alert and receptive. Slowly exhale until the lungs feel empty without straining. Take one long deep breath through the nose without any pause to fill the lungs completely. Hold the breath for two to three seconds. Exhale through the nose for two seconds. Immobilize the diaphragm to pause the breath. Hold the breath for two or three seconds. Exhale again for two seconds. Grip the diaphragm and hold the breath for another two or three seconds. Continue this process of interrupted exhalation until the lungs feel completely emptied. Repeat the pauses four or five times until the air is fully expelled. Hold the breath for five or six seconds while the lungs are empty to perform external retention (bahya kumbhaka). Relax the abdominal grip and the diaphragm. Inhale normally through the nose to complete the cycle. Repeat these cycles for fifteen to twenty minutes or as long as no fatigue is felt. Take two or three normal breaths through the nose. Raise the head to a neutral position. Lie down flat in savasana and rest the entire body.
VIII.shorthand: [Sitting] [Both In - Pauses] -> Hold + Mula (10s) -> [Both Out - Pauses] -> Hold + Uddiyana (6s) -> Inhalation and exhalation, both with pauses. Antara Kumbhaka with Mula Bandha and Bahya Kumbhaka with Uddiyana Bandha

IX.title: Stage IX
IX.technique: Sit in padmasana, siddhasana, swastikasana, virasana, or any convenient and comfortable meditative position. Keep the back and the spinal column firm. Soften the spinal muscles to allow the torso to adjust during the breath. Lower the head toward the trunk. Lift the inner frame of the chest toward the descending chin. Rest the chin in the notch above the breastbone to form the chin lock (Jalandhara Bandha). Place the back of the wrists on the knees with the arms down. Join the tip of the index finger of each hand with the tip of the thumb to form jnana mudra while keeping the other fingers extended. Close the eyes and keep the eye-balls passive and receptive. Direct the gaze inwards toward the heart. Keep the inner ears alert and receptive. Exhale until the lungs feel empty without straining. Inhale for two or three seconds through the nose. Lightly grip the diaphragm to pause the breath. Hold the breath for two or three seconds. Inhale again for another two or three seconds without letting the diaphragm loose. Pause and hold the breath for another two or three seconds. Continue this process of interrupted inhalation until the lungs are completely full. Contract the muscles of the perineum and lift them toward the navel to perform the root lock (Mula Bandha). Hold the breath for ten to fifteen seconds while maintaining the internal retention. Release the root lock (Mula Bandha). Exhale through the nose for two seconds. Immobilize the diaphragm to pause the breath. Hold the breath for two or three seconds. Exhale again for two seconds. Grip the diaphragm and hold the breath for another two or three seconds. Continue this process of interrupted exhalation until the lungs feel completely emptied. Draw the entire abdominal area back toward the spine and lift the muscles up toward the chest to perform the abdominal lock (Uddiyana Bandha). Hold the breath for five or six seconds during this external retention. Relax the abdominal grip and the diaphragm. Inhale normally through the nose to complete the cycle. Repeat these cycles for fifteen to twenty minutes or for as long as you do not feel fatigue. Take two or three normal breaths through the nose. Raise the head to a neutral position. Lie down flat in savasana and rest the entire body.
IX.shorthand: [Sitting] [Both In - Strong Deep] -> [Both Out - Pauses] -> [Exhalation with pauses sitting]

214.name: Anuloma Pranayama
214.description:
Anuloma Pranayama
Anu means with, along with or connected also in an orderly succession. Anuoma therefore means in regular gradation.with the hair (loma), along the grain or in natural order. In Anuloma Pranayama inhalation is done through both nostrils and exhalation alternating through either nostril, inhaling deeply through both nostrils, holding the breath for five to ten seconds while maintaining Mula Bandha, exhaling through alternating nostrils, and completing five to eight cycles.
Effects: Same effects as Ujjayi, Nadi Sodhana, and Surya Bhedana.
214.technique: Sit in any comfortable position like Padmasana, Siddhasana, or Virasana. Keep the back erect and rigid. Lower the head to the trunk. Rest the chin in the notch between the collar-bones (Jalandhara Bandha). Inhale deeply through both nostrils as in Ujjayi until the lungs are fully filled. Hold the breath after inhalation (antara kumbhaka) from five to ten seconds, according to capacity. Maintain Mula Bandha by squeezing the entire perineal region inward and upward. Bring the right hand to the nose, placing the thumb on the right nostril and the ring finger on the left nostril. Release the Mula Bandha. Exhale slowly from the partially opened right nostril, keeping the left one completely blocked. Completely empty the lungs. Lower the hand. Inhale through both nostrils until the lungs are filled. Hold the breath after inhalation (antara kumbhaka) from five to ten seconds, according to capacity. Maintain Mula Bandha. Bring the right hand to the nose again. Release the Mula Bandha. Close the right nostril completely. Keep the left nostril partially open. Exhale slowly through left nostril and deeply to completely empty the lungs. This completes one cycle of Anuloma Pranayama. Perform five to eight cycles at a stretch. Then lie down in Savasana.

Ia.title: Stage Ia
Ia.technique: Sit in padmasana, siddhasana, swastikasana, virasana, or any convenient and comfortable meditative position. Keep the back and the spinal column firm. Soften the spinal muscles to allow the torso to adjust during the breath. Lower the head toward the trunk. Lift the inner frame of the chest toward the descending chin. Rest the chin in the notch above the breastbone to form the chin lock (Jalandhara Bandha). Place the back of the wrists on the knees with the arms down. Join the tip of the index finger of each hand with the tip of the thumb to form jnana mudra while keeping the other fingers extended. Close the eyes and keep the eye-balls passive and receptive. Direct the gaze inwards toward the heart. Keep the inner ears alert and receptive. Exhale whatever breath is currently in the lungs through both nostrils. Inhale slowly and deeply through both open nostrils until the lungs feel completely full. Raise the right hand toward the face. Bend the index and middle fingers toward the palm to form mrigi mudra. Place the right thumb on the right side of the nose and the ring and little fingers on the left side of the nose. Hold the breath for one or two seconds to prepare for the exhalation. Partially close both nostrils with the tips of the thumb and the fingers. Adjust the fingers to make the inner walls of the nasal passages parallel to and equidistant from the septum. Maintain even pressure on both sides of the nose. Exhale slowly, carefully, and deeply through the narrowed nostrils without using any force. Keep the finger tips firm and sensitive to monitor and equalize the volume of out-flow on each side. Empty the lungs completely. Lower the right hand and rest the wrist on the knee. Repeat these cycles for fifteen to twenty minutes. Finish the session by inhaling through both open nostrils. Raise the head to a neutral position. Lie down flat in savasana and rest the entire body for several minutes.
Ia.shorthand: [Sitting] [Both In - Deep ON] -> Hold + Mula (10s) -> [Both Out - Deep BNPC] -> Hold + Uddiyana (8s) -> [Deep inhalation through open nostrils, Antara Kumbhaka and Mula Bandha for 10-15 seconds, then deep exhalation with partially closed nostrils to prolong the exhalation]

Ib.title: Stage Ib
Ib.technique: Sit in padmasana, siddhasana, swastikasana, virasana, or any convenient and comfortable meditative position. Keep the back and the spinal column firm. Soften the spinal muscles to allow the torso to adjust during the breath. Lower the head toward the trunk. Lift the inner frame of the chest toward the descending chin. Rest the chin in the notch above the breastbone to form the chin lock (Jalandhara Bandha). Place the back of the wrists on the knees with the arms down. Join the tip of the index finger of each hand with the tip of the thumb to form jnana mudra while keeping the other fingers extended. Close the eyes and keep the eye-balls passive and receptive. Direct the gaze inwards toward the heart. Keep the inner ears alert and receptive. Exhale whatever breath is currently in the lungs through both nostrils until they feel empty. Inhale slowly and deeply through both open nostrils until the lungs are completely full. Hold the breath for one or two seconds to bring the right hand to the nostrils. Bend the index and middle fingers toward the palm to form mrigi mudra. Place the right thumb on the right side of the nose and the ring and little fingers on the left side of the nose. Block the left nostril completely with the tips of the ring and little fingers without altering the position of the nasal septum. Partially open the right nostril with the tip of the thumb while keeping its inner wall parallel to the septum. Breathe out slowly and carefully through the partially open right nostril until the lungs feel empty. Control the smooth out-flow of breath with the help of the thumb tip. Ensure that no breath escapes through the left nostril. Lower the right hand and rest it on the right knee. Inhale deeply through both open nostrils until the lungs are completely full. Hold the breath for one or two seconds while raising the right hand to the nose. Block the right nostril completely with the tip of the thumb without altering the position of the septum. Open the left nostril partially with the tips of the ring and little fingers while keeping its inner wall parallel to the septum. Breathe out slowly and completely through the partially open left nostril. Control the smooth out-flow of breath with the finger tips and ensure no breath escapes through the right nostril. Lower the right hand and rest it on the knee. Repeat these cycles for fifteen to twenty minutes. Finish the session by inhaling through both open nostrils. Raise the head to a neutral position. Lie down flat in savasana and rest the entire body for several minutes.
Ib.shorthand: [Sitting] [Both In - Deep] -> Hold + Mula (10s) -> [Alt Out - Deep] -> Hold + Uddiyana (8s) -> Deep inhalation through open nostrils, Antara Kumbhaka and Mula Bandha for 10-15 seconds, then deep exhalation through one partially closed nostril and one partially open, alternating then Bahya Kumbhaka with Uddiyana Bandha

IIa.title: Stage IIa
IIa.technique: Sit in padmasana, siddhasana, swastikasana, virasana, or any convenient and comfortable meditative position. Keep the back and the spinal column firm. Soften the spinal muscles to allow the torso to adjust during the breath. Lower the head toward the trunk. Lift the inner frame of the chest toward the descending chin. Rest the chin in the notch above the breastbone to form the chin lock (Jalandhara Bandha). Place the back of the wrists on the knees with the arms down. Join the tip of the index finger of each hand with the tip of the thumb to form jnana mudra while keeping the other fingers extended. Close the eyes and keep the eye-balls passive and receptive. Direct the gaze inwards toward the heart. Keep the inner ears alert and receptive. Exhale whatever breath is currently in the lungs through both nostrils until they feel empty. Inhale slowly and deeply through both open nostrils until the lungs feel completely full. Block both nostrils firmly by pressing the thumb and the fingers against the nose. Hold the breath for ten to fifteen seconds or as long as you can without strain. Contract the muscles of the area between the anus and the genitals and lift them vertically toward the navel to perform the root lock (Mula Bandha). Maintain this internal retention with a steady and calm mind. Release the root lock gradually. Partially open both nostrils with the tips of the thumb and the fingers while keeping the inner walls of the nasal passages parallel to the septum. Exhale slowly, carefully, and deeply through the narrowed nostrils until the lungs feel empty. Use the finger tips to monitor and equalize the volume of the subtle flow of air on each side. Lower the right hand and rest the wrist on the knee. Repeat these cycles for ten to fifteen minutes. Finish the session by inhaling through both open nostrils. Raise the head to a neutral position. Lie down flat in savasana and rest the entire body for several minutes.
IIa.shorthand: [Sitting] [Deep In - ON] -> [Hold (15s)] -> [Deep Out - BNPC] -> [Deep inhalation through open nostrils, Antara Kumbhaka then deep exhalation with partially closed nostrils to prolong the exhalation]

IIb.title: Stage IIb
IIb.technique: Sit in padmasana, siddhasana, swastikasana, virasana, or any convenient and comfortable meditative position. Keep the back and the spinal column firm. Soften the spinal muscles to allow the torso to adjust during the breath. Lower the head toward the trunk. Lift the inner frame of the chest toward the descending chin. Rest the chin in the notch above the breastbone to form the chin lock (Jalandhara Bandha). Place the back of the wrists on the knees with the arms down. Join the tip of the index finger of each hand with the tip of the thumb to form jnana mudra while keeping the other fingers extended. Close the eyes and keep the eye-balls passive and receptive. Direct the gaze inwards toward the heart. Keep the inner ears alert and receptive. Exhale deeply through both nostrils until the lungs feel empty. Inhale slowly and deeply through both open nostrils until the lungs are full. Raise the right hand toward the face. Bend the index and middle fingers toward the palm to form mrigi mudra. Place the right thumb on the right side of the nose and the ring and little fingers on the left side of the nose. Block both nostrils firmly by pressing the thumb and the fingers against the nose. Hold the breath for fifteen to twenty seconds or for as long as you can without strain. Contract the muscles of the area between the anus and the genitals. Lift these perineal muscles vertically toward the navel to perform the root lock (Mula Bandha). Maintain this internal retention with a steady and calm mind. Release the root lock gradually. Block the left nostril completely with the tips of the ring and little fingers without altering the position of the septum. Partially open the right nostril with the tip of the thumb while keeping its inner wall parallel to the septum. Breathe out slowly and carefully through the partially open right nostril until the lungs feel empty. Control the smooth out-flow of breath with the help of the thumb tip. Lower the right hand and rest it on the knee. Inhale deeply with open nostrils until the lungs are full. Raise the right hand to the nostrils. Block both nostrils firmly again to hold the breath. Maintain this internal retention for the same length of time as the previous hold. Perform the root lock (Mula Bandha) during this retention. Release the root lock gradually. Block the right nostril completely with the tip of the thumb without altering the position of the septum. Open the left nostril partially with the tips of the ring and little fingers while keeping its inner wall parallel to the septum. Breathe out slowly and completely through the partially open left nostril. Control the smooth out-flow of breath with the finger tips. Lower the right hand and rest it on the knee. Repeat these cycles for ten to fifteen minutes. Finish the session by inhaling through both open nostrils. Raise the head to a neutral position. Lie down flat in savasana and rest the entire body for several minutes.

215.name: Pratiloma Pranayama
215.description:
Pratiloma Pranayama
Prati means opposite. This type of Pranayama is the converse of Anuloma it is the inhalation through alternating nostrils then exhalation through both nostrils as in Ujjayi.
Effects: Same effects as Ujjayi, Nadi Sodhana, and Surya Bhedana, Difficult due to rhythm variation (inhalation longer than exhalation), only for advanced pupils, Hazardous for BP/heart/nervous disorders.
215.technique:
Sit in a comfortable position such as the lotus pose or the hero pose. Keep the back erect and rigid. Lower the head toward the trunk. Rest the chin in the notch above the breastbone to form the chin lock (Jalandhara Bandha). Stretch the left arm forward. Rest the back of the left wrist on the left knee. Perform the ja mudra with the left hand by joining the thumb and index finger. Bend the right arm at the elbow. Fold the index and middle fingers of the right hand toward the palm. Bring the ring and little fingers toward the thumb to form mrigi mudra.

Place the right thumb and fingers on the sides of the nose just below the nasal bone. Press the ring and little fingers to block the left nostril completely. Use the right thumb to narrow the right nasal passage. Align the outer edge of the right nostril parallel to the septum. Inhale slowly and deeply through the right nostril. Fill the lungs to the brim. Block the right nostril so both sides of the nose are closed. Apply the root lock (Mula Bandha) by contracting the pelvic floor.

Hold the breath for five to ten seconds. Lower the right hand to the knee. Release the root lock (Mula Bandha). Exhale slowly and deeply through both nostrils as in ujjayi until the lungs are empty. 216.name: Sahita and Kevala Kumbhaka Pranayama
216.note: No plate number in book, image on page 388
216.description:
Sahita and Kevala Kumbhaka Pranayama

Sahita means accompanied by or associated with and refers to breath retention performed with intentional effort whereas Kevala means absolute or perfect and refers to a state where breath retention becomes instinctive and natural.

Effects: drives away impurities of the body, drives away impurities of the mind, allows the divine fire within to blaze forth, makes the mind fit for concentration, makes the mind fit for meditation.
216.technique: When breath retention is instinctive and occurs without deliberate action, it is known as Kevala Kumbhaka. Sahita Kumbhaka is the term used when retention is performed with intentional aid or deliberate accompaniment.

217.name: Chandra Bhedana
217.description:
Chandra Bhedana prāṇāyāma
The name refers to the moon.
Effects: Inhalations are done through the left nostril, all exhalations through the right, Pranic energy in all inhalations is channelled through the Ida or chandra nadi, all exhalations pass through the pingala or sūrya nadi, the technique is done in four stages, similar to those of sūrya bhedana.
217.technique: Sit in a stable meditative asana. Keep the spinal column firm. Soften the spinal muscles to allow the torso to adjust. Lift the inner frame of the chest. Lower the head toward the trunk. Rest the chin in the notch above the breastbone to form the chin lock (Jalandhara Bandha). Place the back of the wrists on the knees. Keep the eyes and ears passive and receptive. Inhale quietly through both nostrils. Raise the right hand toward the face. Form mrigi mudra by bending the index and middle fingers toward the palm. Place the right thumb on the right side of the nose. Place the ring and little fingers on the left side of the nose. Press the thumb to block the right nostril completely. Use the ring and little fingers to narrow the left nasal passage. Inhale slowly and deeply through the left nostril. Fill the lungs to their full capacity. Block both nostrils with the thumb and fingers for one or two seconds. Release the pressure of the thumb on the right nostril. Narrow the right nasal passage with the thumb. Exhale slowly and deeply through the right nostril. Block both nostrils again for a brief pause. Repeat this sequence by inhaling only through the left nostril and exhaling only through the right nostril. Maintain a smooth and steady rhythm for ten to fifteen minutes. Complete the practice with a final inhalation through the left nostril. Finish the entire session with a quiet exhalation through both nostrils. Lower the right hand. Raise the head from the chin lock (Jalandhara Bandha). Relax the body in savasana.
