Rest the chin in the notch above the breastbone to form the chin lock (Jalandhara Bandha). Place the back of the wrists on the knees with the arms down. Join the tip of the index finger of each hand with the tip of the thumb to form jnana mudra while keeping the other fingers extended. Close the eyes and keep the eye-balls passive and receptive. Direct the gaze inwards toward the heart. Keep the inner ears alert and receptive. Exhale whatever breath is currently in the lungs through the nose until they feel empty. Raise the right hand toward the face. Bend the index and middle fingers toward the palm to form mrigi mudra. Place the right thumb on the right side of the nose and the ring and little fingers on the left side of the nose. Block the right nostril completely with the tip of the thumb. Partially close the left nostril with the ring and little fingers. Inhale through the left nostril for two or three seconds. Immobilize the diaphragm lightly to pause the breath. Hold the breath for two or three seconds. Inhale again through the left nostril for two or three seconds. Pause the breath and hold it for another two or three seconds. Continue this process of interrupted inhalation through the left nostril until the lungs are completely full. Block both nostrils firmly by pressing the thumb and the fingers against the nose. Contract the muscles of the area between the anus and the genitals. Lift these perineal muscles vertically toward the navel to perform the root lock (Mula Bandha). Maintain this internal retention for ten to fifteen seconds. Release the root lock (Mula Bandha) gradually. Release the pressure of the thumb on the right nostril. Open the right nostril partially while keeping the thumb tip in contact with the skin. Exhale through the right nostril for two or three seconds. Immobilize the diaphragm to pause the breath. Hold the breath for two or three seconds. Exhale again through the right nostril for two or three seconds. Pause and hold the breath for another two or three seconds. Continue this process of interrupted exhalation through the right nostril until the lungs feel completely empty. Block both nostrils firmly by pressing the thumb and fingers against the nose. Pause the breath immediately without allowing any inhalation. Draw the entire abdominal area back toward the spine. Lift the muscles up toward the chest to perform the abdominal lock (Uddiyana Bandha). Retain this empty state for five or six seconds. Relax the abdominal muscles and bring the abdomen back to its normal position. Repeat these cycles for ten to fifteen minutes. Finish the session by inhaling through both open nostrils. Lower the right hand to the knee. Raise the head to a neutral position. Lie down in savasana and rest the body and mind for several minutes.
XVI.shorthand: [Sitting] [Inh - Deep / LN] -> Hold + Mula (20s) -> [Exh - Deep / RN] -> Hold + Uddiyana (10s) -> [Inhale through left nostril, exhale through right, interrupted inhalation, internal retention, interrupted exhalation, external retention.]

218.name: Dhyana
218.description:
Dhyana
Dhyana means absorption and is the act of self-study, reflection, keen observation, or the search for the Infinite within.
Effects: full integration of the contemplator, the act of contemplation, and the object contemplated upon becoming one, distinction between the knower, the instrument of knowledge and the object known vanishes, sadhaka becomes vibrant, alert and poised, sadhaka becomes free from hunger, thirst, sleep and sex as well as from desire, anger, greed, infatuation, pride and envy, sadhaka becomes unassailable by the dualities of body and mind or mind and self, sadhaka's vision reflects his true self like a well-polished mirror, brings the mind to a state of stability and directs it to proceed from imperfect knowledge to perfection, sadhaka experiences illumination.
218.technique:
Dhyāna means absorption. It is the art of self-study, reflection, keen observation, or the search for the Infinite within. It is the observation of the physical processes of the body, the study of mental states, and profound contemplation. It means looking inward to one’s innermost being. Dhyāna is the discovery of the Self.

When the powers of the intellect and the heart are harmoniously blended, this is dhyāna. All creativity proceeds from it, and its good and beautiful results benefit mankind.

Dhyāna is like deep sleep, but with a difference. The serenity of deep sleep comes as a result of unconsciously forgetting one’s identity and individuality, whereas meditation brings serenity that is alert and conscious throughout. The sādhaka remains a witness (sākṣī) to all activities. Chronological and psychological time have no existence in deep sleep or in total absorption. In sleep, the body and mind recover from wear and tear and feel fresh upon waking. In meditation, the sādhaka experiences illumination.

Dhyāna is the full integration of the contemplator, the act of contemplation, and the object contemplated, becoming one. The distinction between the knower, the instrument of knowledge, and the object known vanishes. The sādhaka becomes vibrant, alert, and poised. He becomes free from hunger, thirst, sleep, and sex, as well as from desire, anger, greed, infatuation, pride, and envy. He is unassailable by the dualities of body and mind, or mind and Self. His vision reflects his true Self like a well-polished mirror. This is Ātma-darśana, the reflection of the Soul.

Jesus said that man does not live by bread alone, but by every word that proceeds out of the mouth of God. Pondering upon the meaning of life, man becomes convinced that within his soul dwells a force or light far greater than himself. Yet in his walk of life he is beset by many cares and doubts. Caught in the environment of artificial civilisation, he develops a false sense of values. His words and actions run counter to his thoughts. Bewildered by these contradictions, he realises that life is full of opposites—pain and pleasure, sorrow and joy, conflict and peace. Seeing these polarities, he strives to attain balance and to find a state of stability so that he may experience freedom from pain, sorrow, and conflict. In his search he discovers the three noble paths of knowledge (jñāna), work (karma), and worship (bhakti), which teach him that his inner light is the only guide leading to mastery over his own life. To reach this inner light, he turns to meditation or dhyāna.

To have a clear notion of the true natures of man, the world, and God, the sādhaka should study the sacred books (śāstras). Then he can distinguish the real from the unreal. Knowledge of these three truths (tattva-traya)—the soul (cit), the world (acit), and God (Īśvara)—is essential for one who seeks liberation. Such knowledge gives insight into life’s problems and their solutions and strengthens spiritual practice. Yet knowledge acquired by reading alone will not lead to liberation. It is through courage and unshakable faith in the teachings of the sacred books, and by putting them into practice until they become part of daily life, that the sādhaka gains freedom from the domination of the senses. Knowledge of the scriptures and sādhana are the two wings by which the sādhaka flies towards liberation.

Man is drawn between two paths. One drags him downwards toward the fulfilment of voluptuous desires and sense gratification, leading to bondage and destruction; the other guides him upwards toward purity and realisation of his inner Self. Desires fog the mind and veil the true Self. It is the mind alone that leads to bondage or to liberation. It is reason or intelligence that either controls the mind or allows itself to be dominated.

An untrained mind flies aimlessly in all directions. The practice of meditation brings it to a state of stability and then directs it to proceed from imperfect knowledge to perfection. The sādhaka’s mind and intelligence work as an integrated team led by will-power. He finds harmony between his thoughts, speech, and actions. His stilled mind and intelligence burn like a lamp in a windless place, with simplicity, innocence, and illumination.

Man has great potentialities that lie dormant within him. His body and mind are like fallow land lying untilled and unsown. A wise farmer ploughs his land (kṣetra), provides it with water and fertiliser, plants the best seeds, carefully tends the crops, and ultimately reaps a good harvest. To the sādhaka, his body, mind, and intellect are the field he ploughs with energy and right action. He sows the finest seeds of knowledge, waters them with devotion, and tends them with unrelenting spiritual discipline to reap the harvest of harmony and peace. He then becomes the wise owner (kṣetrajña) of his field, and his body becomes a sacred place. The germination of good thoughts (savicāra), planted by sound logic (savitarka), brings clarity to the mind and wisdom to the intellect (sasmita). He becomes an abode of joy (āda), as his whole being is filled with the Lord.

The journey to the moon and outer space demanded years of rigorous training and discipline, deep study, research, and preparation. The inward journey of man to reach his inner Self demands the same relentless effort. Years of discipline and long, uninterrupted practice of the moral and ethical principles of yama and niyama, training of the body through āsana and prāṇāyāma, restraint of the senses through pratyāhāra and dhāraṇā, ensure the growth of the mind and inner awareness—dhyāna and samādhi.

Dhāraṇā (derived from the root dhr, meaning “to hold” or concentration) is like a lamp that is covered and does not light up the area outside. When the cover is removed, the lamp illuminates the whole area. This is dhyāna—the expansion of consciousness. The sādhaka acquires a unified mind and maintains a dynamic, unfading awareness in its pristine purity. Like oil in seeds and fragrance in flowers, the soul permeates the whole body.

The lotus is symbolic of meditation. It symbolises purity. Its quiet beauty has given it a prime place in Indian religious thought. It is connected with most Hindu deities and their seats in the cakras. The stage of meditation is like a lotus bud hiding its inner beauty while awaiting transformation into a fully blossomed lotus. As the bud opens to reveal its splendour, so too the sādhaka’s inner light is transformed and transfigured by meditation. He becomes an enlightened soul (siddha) and an inspired sage. He lives in the eternal now—the present—without yesterdays or tomorrows.

This state of the sādhaka is one of passivity known as manolaya (manas meaning mind, and laya meaning absorption or merging). He has fully marshalled his intelligence (prajñā) and energy (prāṇa) to prevent the intrusion of external thoughts. His state is full of dynamic alertness. When both internal and external thoughts are stilled and silenced, there is no waste of physical, mental, or intellectual energy.

Dhyāna is a subjective experience of an objective state. It is difficult to describe in words, for words are inadequate. The delight experienced at the first bite of a delicious mango is indescribable; so it is with meditation. In meditation there is no seeking or searching, for the soul and the goal have become one. The nectar of infinity must be tasted; the abundant grace of the Lord within must be experienced. Then the individual soul (jīvātman) becomes one with the Universal Soul (Paramātman).

The sādhaka experiences the fullness sung by the Upaniṣads:

That is full; this is full.
From fullness comes fullness.
Even when fullness is taken from fullness,
fullness remains.

219.name: Jalandhara Bandha
219.description:
Jalandhara Bandha
It is said to be the lion that kills the elephant named death.
Effects: exercises the diaphragm, through uddiyana bandha the great bird prana is forced to fly up through the sushumna nadi, the main channel for the flow of nervous energy, which is situated inside the spinal column (merudanda).
219.technique: Sit in a comfortable position such as the accomplished pose or the lotus pose. Keep the back erect and rigid. Lift the sternum and the front part of the rib cage toward the ceiling. Stretch the sides of the neck without creating tension. Move the shoulder blades deep into the body. Maintain a concave shape in the thoracic and cervical spine. Bend the head forward and downward from the back of the neck. Keep the neck and throat muscles soft and receptive. Rest the point and both sides of the jawbone evenly in the notch between the collarbones. Lift the top of the chest to meet the descending chin. Align the center of the head and the chin with the middle of the breastbone. Keep the navel and the perineum in a straight vertical line with the chin. Relax the temples and keep the eyes and ears passive. Soften the tongue and the internal throat. Ensure the ribs do not cave inward while the chin rests on the chest. Maintain an even pressure on both sides of the jaw. Relax the facial skin and the forehead completely. Lower the shoulders away from the ears. Keep the spinal column firm and tall throughout the practice.

220.name: Mula Bandha
220.description:
Mula Bandha
The yogi attempts to reach the true source (mula) of all creation.
Effects: The lift of the diaphragm gently massages the muscles of the heart thereby toning them, it tones the abdominal organs, increases the gastric fire, eliminates toxins in the digestive tract, the practitioner acquires moral and spiritual power which will shine forth like the sun.
220.technique: Sit in a stable meditative asana with the spinal column firm and tall. Perform the chin lock (Jalandhara Bandha) by lowering the head toward the trunk. Place the back of the wrists on the knees and keep the eyes and ears passive. Contract the muscles of the principal region between the anus and the genitals. Lift these perineal muscles vertically toward the navel. Press the lower anterior abdomen located below the navel backwards toward the spine. Pull this same lower abdominal area upwards toward the spine. Move the anal sphincter muscles toward the center of the body in the manner of asvini mudra. Draw only the area between the anus and the navel back toward the spinal column. Lift this specific region up toward the diaphragm. Maintain this contraction during the period of internal breath retention after inhalation. Keep the upper abdominal region above the navel soft and unconstricted. Ensure the chest remains lifted and the shoulders stay relaxed. Practice this root lock (Mula Bandha) while performing the camel pose (Ustrasana). Integrate the contraction while staying in the headstand (Sirsasana). Apply the lock during the practice of the shoulder stand (Sarvangasana). Use the muscular lift while in the upward-facing bow pose (Urdhva Dhanurasana). Maintain the internal grip during the seated forward bend (Paschimottanasana). Hold the contraction firmly without straining the facial muscles. Release the pelvic lift gradually before the final exhalation. Lower the right hand and raise the head to a neutral position. Relax the entire body in the corpse pose (Savasana).

221.name: Abhyanga (Self-Massage)
221.note: Focus on moving the pressure in the direction of the heart.
221.description:
Abhyanga (Self-Massage)
This is a seated self-massage routine that systematically targets the upper body, covering the head, face, neck, and chest, and includes toning massages for the arms.
Effects: Invigorates and tones the body, improves circulation, enlivens the neuromuscular system, and prepares the mind and body for deeper meditation.
221.technique: Find a comfortable sitting position with the spine tall. Use the palms and fingers of both hands to press the top of the head. Gradually press and release as the hands move forward over the face, down the neck, and onto the chest. Return to the top of the head and press and release while moving down the back of the neck and around to the chest. To tone the right arm, grasp the fingers of the right hand with the left hand. Press and release firmly and continuously upward along the top of the right arm to the shoulder and across the chest. Repeat the pressing and releasing along the underside of the right arm from the hand to the forearm, shoulder, and chest. Perform the same sequence on the left arm, ensuring both the top and underside are massaged. Maintain firm, gradual, and continuous pressure throughout the process. Complete the routine by allowing the body to feel invigorated and the breath to remain natural.

222.name: Sanchalana (Circulation Flow)
222.note: Always move the massage pressure toward the heart to support lymphatic and venous return.
222.description:
Sanchalana (Circulation Flow)
This is a systematic full-body self-massage routine that moves from the feet and torso upward to the heart area.
Effects: Enhances systemic circulation, stimulates lymphatic drainage, supports kidney and digestive function, and promotes a sense of grounded vitality.
222.technique: Begin by placing the fingertips at the navel. Using both hands, press and release around the abdomen, gradually moving the pressure upward toward the heart. Shift the hands to the lower back and kidney area; continue the press-and-release motion over the ribs, moving upward toward the heart. Transition to the right foot. Grasp and massage the toes, soles, and the top of the foot. Continue the upward motion through the calves, thighs, and hips, then move across the stomach toward the heart. Repeat this sequence on the left side, starting from the left foot and moving up through the leg and hip, finishing at the heart. Maintain firm yet comfortable pressure throughout the routine to encourage the flow of energy and circulation.

223.name: Spinal Rock / Jhulana
223.note: Keep the neck completely relaxed and the breath fluid during the rocking motion.
223.description:
Spinal Rock / Jhulana
This is a simple, gentle supine exercise that uses a rocking motion to release tension and relax the spine and lower back.
Effects: Massages the spinal column, releases tightness in the lumbar region, soothes the nervous system, and promotes physical relaxation before deeper asana practice.
223.technique: Lie flat on the back, lengthening the spine and keeping the head and neck long and free. Draw the knees up to the chest and clasp the hands over the knees. Begin to roll slowly and easily from side to side. Maintain a relaxed neck and breathe normally throughout the movement. Perform five rolls to each side. To finish, release the arms and slowly extend the legs out from the hips, allowing the entire body to rest in a state of complete relaxation.

224.name: Seat Firming Pose—Vajrasana
224.note: Focus on the synchronization of the breath with the lifting and lowering of the body.
224.description:
Seat Firming Pose—Vajrasana
This exercise is a slow, rhythmic movement performed in a kneeling position, coordinated with deep breathing, that focuses on lengthening the spine and keeping the chest open.
Effects: Strengthens the pelvic region, removes tension from the knees and ankles, and builds a strong foundation for the back.
224.technique: Begin by kneeling and sitting with the buttocks on the heels. The feet should be slightly apart and the big toes crossed. Lengthen the spine, widen the rib cage, and slightly lift the chest while keeping the head and neck long and free. Look straight ahead and breathe easily, placing the hands in the lap with the right hand on top of the left, palms up. As you inhale, lift the buttocks off the heels and come up to a full kneeling position. Keep the spine lengthened, the chest open, and the shoulders relaxed. On the exhalation, slowly lower the body back down to the heels. Repeat the movement smoothly and slowly with even breaths, keeping the front and back of the body active and long.

225.name: Pranamasana (Prayer Pose)
225.note: Focus on the firm connection between the palms and the grounding of the feet.
225.description:
Pranamasana (Prayer Pose)
Pranamasana is a grounding posture symbolizing reverence, gratitude, and connection. It is used to center the mind and honor the inner self at the beginning or end of a practice.
Effects: Fosters peace and humility, centers the mind, improves balance, and establishes a calm respiratory rhythm.
225.technique: Stand tall with the feet together, rooting down firmly through the soles. Bring the palms together at the heart center in Anjali Mudra. Ensure the spine is straight, the core is lightly engaged, and the shoulders are relaxed away from the ears. Maintain a soft gaze straight ahead or gently close the eyes. Focus on deep, calm breaths to center the mind and express gratitude. Hold the position while maintaining a vertical line from the crown of the head through the center of the body to the heels, ensuring the weight is distributed evenly across both feet.

226.name: Hasta Uttanasana (Raised Hands Pose)
226.note: Keep the core engaged and legs strong to protect the lower back during the backbend.
226.description:
Hasta Uttanasana (Raised Hands Pose)
A standing posture that involves a gentle backward arch and overhead arm extension to open the front of the body.
Effects: Intensely stretches the spine, chest, and abdomen, expands the lungs to improve breathing capacity, and energizes the entire system. It is a key movement in the Sun Salutation sequence.
226.technique: Begin by standing tall in Tadasana (Mountain Pose) with the feet together and weight evenly distributed. On a deep inhalation, sweep the arms overhead and bring the palms together. Simultaneously lift the chest and gently arch the back, reaching up and slightly behind while lengthening the spine. Maintain a gaze toward the thumbs or slightly upward. Ensure the core remains engaged and the legs stay firm to support the torso. Hold the extension briefly, focusing on the expansion of the ribs, then exhale as you slowly return to a neutral standing position with arms at the sides.

227.name: Equestrian Pose (Ashwa Sanchalanasana)
227.note: Ensure the front knee is directly above the ankle to protect the joint; use a blanket under the back knee for comfort if needed.
227.description:
Equestrian Position (Ashwa Sanchalanasana)
A foundational asymmetrical low lunge that stretches the hips and groin while grounding the body.
Effects: Stretches the hip flexors and psoas muscles, tones the abdominal organs, improves balance, and promotes mental focus and stability.
227.technique: Begin in a standing forward bend (Uttanasana) with the palms on the floor beside the feet. On an inhalation, step one leg far back, resting the knee and the ball of the foot on the mat. Align the front knee at a 90-degree angle directly above the ankle, keeping the thigh parallel to the floor. Place the fingertips or palms on the floor on either side of the front foot, shoulder-width apart. Roll the shoulders back and down to open the chest and lengthen the spine. Gently lower the hips and pelvis toward the floor. Tilt the head slightly backward and direct the gaze forward or slightly upward. Hold the posture while taking slow, deep breaths, sinking the hips further with each exhalation. To release, inhale and step the back foot forward to return to Uttanasana. Repeat the sequence by stepping the opposite leg back.

228.name: Eight Limbs Position (Ashtanga Namaskara)
228.note: Ensure the hips and abdomen remain lifted; only the eight specific points should touch the floor.
228.description:
Eight Limbs Position (Ashtanga Namaskara)
A yoga posture where the body rests on eight points of contact with the floor: both feet, both knees, both hands, the chest, and the chin or forehead. It is a foundational transition in Sun Salutations.
Effects: Strengthens the arms, chest, and core muscles, improves flexibility in the spine and neck, and serves as an excellent preparation for deeper backbending poses.
228.technique: Begin from a plank or equestrian position. On an exhalation, lower the knees to the floor while keeping the toes tucked under. Keeping the elbows hugged tightly in toward the ribs, lower the chest and chin down to the floor between the hands. Ensure the chest touches the ground while the hips and abdomen remain lifted and angled toward the ceiling. Balance the body weight evenly across the eight points of contact: the palms, chin, chest, knees, and toes. Maintain smooth breathing and keep the core slightly engaged to support the lift of the midsection.

229.name: Swastikasana (Auspicious Pose)
229.note: A stable meditative seat; ensure the heels are not pressing against the pubic bone.
229.description:
Swastikasana (Auspicious Pose)
A classical cross-legged sitting posture used for meditation and pranayama. The name is derived from 'Svastika,' meaning auspicious or lucky.
Effects: Keeps the spine straight and stable for long periods, calms the nervous system, and prepares the mind for deep concentration.
229.technique: Sit on the floor with legs extended. Bend the left leg and place the sole against the right inner thigh. Bend the right leg and place the foot between the left thigh and calf muscle, so the feet are locked between the thighs and calves. Keep the spine, neck, and head erect. Rest the hands on the knees in Jnana Mudra or place them in the lap. Maintain a steady and comfortable posture while breathing naturally.

230.name: Half Lotus (Ardha Padmasana)
230.description: Half Lotus (Ardha Padmasana) is a yoga and meditation pose where one foot rests on the opposite thigh, while the other leg stays tucked underneath, requiring significant hip external rotation and flexibility, with benefits like calming the mind, improving circulation, and strengthening the back, but it's crucial to avoid knee pain by using props like cushions or blocks and practicing hip openers first. Proper execution involves flexing the knee, externally rotating the hip, bringing the heel towards the pelvis, and keeping the spine straight, using support to prevent strain.
230.technique: Start in Staff Pose (Dandasana) sitting with the legs straight and the spine long. Bend the left knee fully and bring the foot toward the body. Gently guide the foot by externally rotating the hip so the outer edge of the foot rests on the opposite thigh, nestling the heel into the hip crease near the navel. Tuck the right foot under the left thigh, allowing the left knee to descend toward the floor. Maintain a tall spine and relaxed shoulders while pulling the navel gently inward. Use a cushion under the hips if necessary to ensure the lower back does not round.

232.name: Digital Pranayama (Nasa Mudra)
232.note: This entry focuses on the precise art of digital nostril control, rather than the breathing cycle itself.
232.description:
Digital Pranayama (Nasa Mudra)
The art of using the fingers (digits) to refine the flow of air. This technique focuses on the subtle placement and movement of the hand to control the nostrils without disturbing the equilibrium of the head or neck.
Effects: Develops sensitivity in the fingertips, ensures an even flow of air through the nasal passages, and prepares the practitioner for the advanced stages of controlled respiration.
232.technique: Sit with the spine erect. Raise the right hand and bend the index and middle fingers toward the palm (Vishnu Mudra). Place the thumb on the right side of the nose and the ring and little fingers on the left side, just below the nasal bone where the flesh is soft. The art of placement requires the fingers to move like a balance scale—as one side opens, the other narrows with subtle, firm, yet light pressure. Ensure the fingers do not pull the nose to either side; the bridge of the nose should remain centered. The elbow should be relaxed and tucked close to the chest to keep the hand steady and the arm from fatiguing.
